questions.text: The sebaceous gland synthesizes and releases the sebum, protecting the skin from external factors and dehydration. It is responsible for the suppleness of hair and skin. The microscopic exocrine gland is an example of ?
questions.solution:
The correct option is: 3. Holocrine gland

Explanation of the options:

  1. Paracrine gland: Paracrine glands are glands that secrete substances that act on nearby cells, usually within the same tissue. They don't release their secretions into a duct, but rather influence neighboring cells through diffusion of their secreted molecules. An example of a paracrine gland is the pancreatic islets that secrete insulin and glucagon.

  2. Apocrine gland: Apocrine glands are a type of exocrine gland that release their secretions by pinching off a portion of their cell, along with the secretion, to form a vesicle. This vesicle is then released into a duct, which carries the secretion to the surface. Apocrine glands are found in limited areas of the body, such as the axillary and genital regions. They're responsible for producing sweat that can be acted upon by bacteria to cause body odor.

  3. Holocrine gland: Holocrine glands are a type of exocrine gland in which the entire cell becomes filled with the secretory product and then disintegrates, releasing the secretion along with cell debris. Sebaceous glands, which secrete sebum to lubricate the skin and hair, are a classic example of holocrine glands. The statement you provided about sebaceous glands is accurate, as they synthesize and release sebum, which has various protective and moisturizing functions for the skin and hair.

  4. Eccrine gland: Eccrine glands are another type of exocrine gland responsible for producing sweat, primarily for thermoregulation. These glands release their secretion directly onto the skin surface through a duct, without any destruction of the glandular cell. Eccrine glands are distributed throughout most of the body and play a vital role in controlling body temperature.

questions.text: 11-year-old girl with fever, sore throat, and bilateral swellings between palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal folds, which lymph nodes should be evaluated to assess the initial spread of infection from the affected lymphoid tissue?
questions.solution:
Option D: Jugulodigastric

  • This is a case of tonsillitis involving the jugulodigastric lymph node.
  • The Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are deep cervical lymph nodes.
  • Deep cervical lymph nodes are related to the internal jugular vein.
  • The jugulodigastric lymph nodes drain lymph from the tonsils.
  • The jugulodigastric lymph node (tonsillar lymph node) is located near the angle of the mandible where the posterior belly of digastric muscle crosses the internal jugular vein. It receives lymph from the tongue and pharynx and is commonly enlarged with tonsillitis.

Option A: Submental

  • The submental lymph nodes are superficial cervical lymph nodes. They drain lymph from the submental region.
  • The apex of the tongue, frenulum, and central part of the lower lip drain into submental lymph nodes that can be palpated, when enlarged, in the submental triangle.

Option B: Submandibular

  • The submandibular lymph nodes are superficial cervical lymph nodes draining lymph from the submandibular region.
  • Most of the skin of the face, lateral part of the body of the tongue, and the floor of the mouth drain into the submandibular lymph nodes. These lymph nodes lie superficial to the submandibular gland and, when enlarged, can be palpated along the inferior border of the body of the mandible.

Option C: Parotid

  • The parotid lymph nodes are also a part of superficial cervical lymph nodes draining lymph from the parotid area.
  • They are located on the capsule of the parotid gland and drain the lateral aspect of the face, scalp, and eyelids.

questions.text: A 6-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. He feeds 10 to 12 times a day. He was born at 38 weeks gestation and weighed 1800 g. He currently weighs 1700 g. His mother has Graves’ disease and received propylthiouracil during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), his pulse is 180/min, and his respirations are 50/min. Examination shows mild diaphoresis and a firm 2-cm midline neck swelling. The actively secreting follicles of the structure involved in the patient's pathology are lined by one of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Columnar epithelium

  • This is a case of Hyperthyroidism.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium (central spherical nucleus, with a height of the cell equal to breath)
  • Since the question asked is regarding the secretary follicle, the answer is a columnar epithelium.
  • Secreting active thyroid follicles are lined by a columnar type of epithelium.

Option B: Cuboidal epithelium

  • The thyroid follicle epithelial lining depends on the cells' activity in the secretion of thyroxine.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium (central spherical nucleus, with a height of the cell equal to breath).
  • Secreting active thyroid follicles are lined by a columnar type of epithelium.

Option C: Squamous epithelium

  • Simple Squamous: Thin rim of cytoplasm above flat /globular nucleus
  • Scanty (resting follicle): Simple squamous

Option D: Pseudostratified squamous

  • The pseudostratified epithelium is very rare in cuboidal and squamous cells. It is seen in columnar form and lines the respiratory tract, male genital tract etc.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium(not pseudostratified).

questions.text: As a first-year resident in the Orthopaedics department, you observe a 15-year-old male presenting with frequent fractures every 3 months. Suspecting osteogenesis imperfecta type I, which type of collagen is involved in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Option A: Type I

  • Type I collagen is the most common type and is found in;
    • Bones
    • Fibro-cartilage [atypical cartilage]
    • Dermis [skin]
    • Old scar
  • Type I: Decreased production in osteogenesis imperfecta type I.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta type I is a genetic disorder that results in skeletal deformities and deformity of bones.
  • The genetic mutation of the COL1A1 gene.
  • ↓ Formation of the hydrogen and disulfide bonds between type I pre-procollagen molecules → ↓ triple helix formation → ↓ synthesis of normal type I collagen → impaired bone matrix formation (osteogenesis).
  • Clinical features are:
    • Delay of growth.
    • Brittle bones, skeletal deformities.
    • Saber shins and bowing of bones.
    • Childbirth fracture.
    • Recurrent fracture from minimal trauma.
    • Deformation atrophy of the ossicles leads to progressive loss of hearing.
    • Lack of dentin leads to dentinogenesis imperfecta, brittle, opalescent teeth.
    • Blue sclerae.

Option B: Type II

  • Type II collagen is found in hyaline & elastic cartilage.

Option C: Type III

  • Type III collagen is found in
    • Lymphoid organs with reticular tissue [liver, spleen, lymph nodes]
    • Healing/Granulation tissue
  • Type III: Deficient in the uncommon, vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Option D: Type IV

  • Type IV collagen is found in
    • Basal lamina/membrane
    • Type IV: Under the floor (basement membrane). Defective in Alport syndrome; targeted by autoantibodies in Goodpasture syndrome.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presenting with fatigue, recurrent shoulder and patella dislocations, abnormal joint hypermobility, and skin hyperextensibility, a high-frequency mid-systolic click is heard on auscultation. Which type of collagen is defective in the vascular type of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Type III

  • The above given is a case of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.
  • Hypermobility predisposes joint dislocation and hyperextensible skin.
  • Sometimes, it is associated with valve prolapses.
  • Type III: Deficient in the uncommon, vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.
  • The EDS is on clinical criteria.
  • Genetic testing is for confirming or ruling out other diagnoses.
  • There is no specific treatment. The management focuses on monitoring complications and preventive care.
  • Type III collagen is found in:
    • Lymphoid organs with reticular tissue [liver, spleen, lymph nodes].
    • Healing/granulation tissue.

Option A: Type I 

  • Type I collagen is the most common type and is found in:
  • Bones
  • Fibro-cartilage [atypical cartilage]
  • Dermis [skin]
  • Old scar
  • Type I collagen decreased production leads to osteogenesis imperfecta.

Option B: Type II

  • Type II collagen is found in hyaline & elastic cartilage.

Option D: Type IV

  • Type IV collagen is found in
    • Basal lamina/membrane
    • Type IV: Under the floor (basement membrane). Defective in Alport syndrome; targeted by autoantibodies in Good pasture syndrome.

questions.text: Which muscle is responsible for the vocal cord's abduction?
questions.solution:
Option C: Posterior cricoarytenoid muscle

  • The only abductor of the vocal cords is the posterior cricoarytenoid.
  • It is essential in coughing, speaking, sniffing, and respiration.
  • As it is the only muscle that opens the vocal cords. Its paralysis can cause asphyxia.

Option A: Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle

  • Lateral cricoarytenoid muscle and Interarytenoid muscle are adductors of the vocal cords.

Option B: Vocalis muscle

  • Vocalis can tense the vocal cords and plays a role in changing the pitch of voice. It does not abduct the vocal cords.

Option D: Cricothyroid muscle

  • Cricothyroid muscle tenses the vocal cords.

questions.text: An image of the shoulder joint region is given in the figure. Identify the type of epiphyses A, B, and C respectively:

choices.text: A. Atavistic, B. traction and C. pressure
A. Traction, B. atavistic and C. pressure
A. Atavistic, B. aberrant and C. traction
A. Atavistic, B. pressure and C. traction

questions.solution:
Option D: A. Atavistic, B. pressure and C. traction

Mark A - Coracoid process (Atavistic epiphysis)

  • The atavistic epiphysis is phylogenetically independent but fused to the nearest bone for nutrition seen in:
  • Coracoid process of scapula
  • Os trigonum (talus)

Mark B - Head of humerus (Pressure epiphysis)

  • Pressure epiphysis takes part in the joint formation and is intracapsular. They transmit weight seen in:
  • Head of the humerus.
  • The lower end of the radius etc.

Mark C - Greater tubercle (Traction epiphysis)

  • Traction epiphysis is non-articular and does not take part in weight transmission.
  • Appear later than pressure epiphysis seen in
  • Mastoid process
  • Greater and lesser tubercle of the humerus
  • Greater and lesser trochanter of femur.

Option A: A. Atavistic, B. traction and C. pressure

  • It is an incorrect option because the correct order is:
  • A. Atavistic, B. traction and C. pressure

Option B: A. Traction, B. atavistic and C. pressure

  • It is an incorrect option because the correct order is:
  • A. Atavistic, B. traction and C. pressure

Option C: A. Atavistic, B. aberrant and C. traction

  • It is an incorrect option because the correct order is:
  • A. Atavistic, B. traction and C. pressure

questions.text: Which of the following ganglia do not have postganglionic parasympathetic fibers?
questions.solution:
Option A: Celiac

  • The celiac ganglion is a sympathetic prevertebral (collateral) ganglion that contains postganglionic neurons that are sympathetic.
  • Celiac ganglia are nerve bundles in the upper abdomen as part of the autonomic nervous system that is functionally responsible for innervating the digestive tract and abdominal visceral tissue. The ganglia serve as integrative centres for coordinating intestinal motility, secretion, and absorption throughout the digestive tract.
  • Sympathetic system
    • Thoracolumbar flow (T1-L2).
    • Sympathetic ganglia are close to CNS.
    • Pre ganglionic fibres are shorter.
    • Pre ganglionic fibres are myelinated (white).
    • Postganglionic fibres are unmyelinated (grey matter).
  • Parasympathetic system: Cranial: 3, 7, 9, 10 and Sacral: S2 - S4 flow.
    • Parasympathetic ganglia are close to the target organ.
    • Postganglionic fibres are shorter.
  • The sympathetic & parasympathetic systems use the neurotransmitter acetylcholine at the ganglia level.
    • Acetylcholine: Parasympathetic postganglionic (effector) neurotransmitter.
    • Adrenaline: Sympathetic postganglionic (effector) neurotransmitter except in skin where acetylcholine is secreted.

Option B: Ciliary

  • The parasympathetic system (cranial part) has four small peripheral ganglia.
    • Ciliary.
    • Pterygopalatine.
    • Submandibular and.
    • Otic.
  • Hence, its postganglionic fibres are parasympathetic.

Option C: Otic

  • Its postganglionic fibres are parasympathetic.

Option D: Pterygopalatine

  • Its postganglionic fibres are parasympathetic.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought by his parents with complaints of difficulty in speech, sagging of the soft palate, and tongue deviation. His clinical features and examination findings are suggestive of a cleft palate with the bulbar syndrome.Branch of which of the following pretrematic nerve passes caudally to the first pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Option C: Chorda tympani

  • Trigeminal nerve (CNV) (maxillary and mandibular divisions) is the nerve of the first pharyngeal arch.
  • The first arch is also supplied by the chorda tympani nerve, a pretrematic branch of the facial nerve—the nerve of second arch.
  • Each pharyngeal arch is innervated by a mixed nerve, but the nerves of the first three arches also have a purely sensory branch that innervates the arch rostral to its 'own' arch; this sensory nerve is called the branch because it extends rostral to the cleft (trema) between the two arches.
  • The nerve that runs along cranial border of the arch is known as post-trematic nerve and nerve that runs along its caudal border is called pretrematic nerve.

Option A: Vagus nerve

  • The nerve of the 3rd arch → Glossopharyngeal nerve
    • Pretrematic nerve → Auricular branch of the vagus nerve.
  • The nerve of the 4th arch → Pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve.
  • The nerve of the 6th arch → Recurrent laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

Option B: Glossopharyngeal

  • Nerve of 3rd arch → Glossopharyngeal nerve.
    • Pretrematic nerve → auricular branch of the vagus nerve

 

Option C: Trigeminal

  • The nerve of 1st arch → Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve

questions.text: A bulge known as the Torus aorticus is present superior to the coronary sinus and anterior to the fossa ovalis on the interatrial septum. Which of the following structures is the most likely reason for the bulge?

choices.text: Aortic sinus bulging into the left atrium
Aortic sinus bulging into the right atrium

questions.solution:
Option C: Aortic sinus bulging into the right atrium.

  • The interatrial septum is a thin wall between the right and the left atria. It has a depression known as fossa ovalis. The fossa ovalis has a prominent margin known as annulus ovalis or limbus. There is a bulge in the right atrial septum, which is anterior to the fossa ovalis and superior to the opening of the coronary sinus. This bulge is known as the Torus aorticus.
  • The torus aortic (aortic mound) is the prominent region of the right atrial septum, which marks the projection of the non-coronary aortic sinus into the right atrial wall.
  • The aortic sinus has three parts, the anterior aortic sinus, the left posterior aortic sinus and the right posterior aortic sinus. The right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus. The left coronary artery arises from the left posterior aortic sinus. The right posterior aortic sinus (non-coronary sinus) does not give off any artery. It forms a bulge in the right atrial septum known as the Torus aorticus (aortic mound).

Option A:  Atrium bulging into the aorta.

  • The Torus aorticus (aortic mound) is not produced by the bulging of the atrium into the aorta. It is produced by the bulging of the non-coronary aortic sinus into the right atrial septum.

Option B: Aortic sinus bulging into the left atrium.

  • The Torus aorticus (aortic mound) is not produced by the bulging of the non-coronary aortic sinus into the left atrium. It is produced by the bulging of the aortic sinus into the right atrial septum.

Option D: Aortic wall tear.

  • The Torus aorticus (aortic mound) is not produced by aortic wall rupture. It is produced by the bulging of the non-coronary aortic sinus into the right atrial septum.
  • Aortic wall tear will lead to aortic dissection or aortic rupture.
  • Aortic rupture can be caused by trauma, and a widened mediastinum will be seen on the chest radiograph.
  • Aortic dissection presents with sudden onset chest pain radiating to the back and unequal arm pulses and blood pressures. It can lead to organ ischemia, aortic rupture or death.

questions.text: Which of the following are the two muscles between which the Rotter’s nodes lie?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pectoralis major and pectoralis minor 

  • Rotter lymph nodes are located in the interpectoral fascia in the Rotter space, between the pectoralis major and pectoralis minor .
  • Their number varies from one to four.
  • Breast cancer can metastasize to these nodes, which may be positive even without the disease.
  • Spread to the Rotter's nodes suggests the retrograde spread of the tumor.
  • They receive lymphatic fluid from the muscles and the mammary gland.
  • They deliver lymphatic fluid to the axillary lymphatic plexus.
  • During surgery, if pectoralis major has to be preserved, the Rotter's nodes also need to be preserved.

Option A: Serratus anterior and trapezius

  • Serratus anterior main part lies deep under the scapula and the pectoralis .
  • The trapezius is located on the posterior aspect of the neck and thorax.
  • The Rotter’s nodes are not located between these two muscles.

Option B: Latissimus dorsi and serratus anterior

  • Rotter’s nodes are located in the interpectoral fascia between the two pectoral muscles.

Option D: Deltoid and pectoralis major

  • A deltoid is a thick triangular muscle covering the shoulder joint and used for raising the arm away from the body.
  • Rotter's nodes are also not present between these two muscles.

questions.text: The scapula's inferior angle lies at the level of ?
questions.solution:
Option D: T8

  • The scapula or shoulder blade is the bone that connects the clavicle to the humerus. It is a sturdy, flat, triangular bone that forms the shoulder girdle's posterior.
  • The scapula, along with the clavicle and the manubrium of the sternum, makes up the pectoral (shoulder) girdle, which connects the upper limb of the appendicular skeleton to the axial skeleton.
  • The scapula overlies the second to seventh ribs.
  • The inferior angle of the scapula lies at the level of the spine of the T7 vertebra (vertebral body T8).
  • The body of vertebra T7 articulates with the head of the seventh and eighth ribs. At this level lies the lower border of the heart; the inferior vena cava passes through the diaphragm's central tendon to enter the heart's right atrium.

Option A: T3

  • The spine process of the scapula lies at the level of the spinous process of T3.

Option B: T4

  • Nipples lie at the level of T4

Option C: T7

  • The inferior scapular angle lies at the spinous process level, not the body of the T7.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy brought to OPD by his parents. He has had foul-smelling watery diarrhoea for the last 5 months. His weight and height are below the 50th percentile. To estimate total body fat, a subscapular skin fold thickness is needed. What is the name of this device is used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Option C: Harpenden Callipers

  • Harpenden callipers are used to measure the skin fold thickness.
  • Measured over the following areas:-
    • Subscapular
    • Biceps
    • Triceps areas

Option A: Orchidometer

  • An orchidometer is a medical device that can precisely measure volume and ascertain the size of the testes.
  • It consists of a sequence of ellipsoids (beads) of increasing volume.

Option B:  Vernier callipers

  • It is used to measure diameter of object.

Option D: Shakir's tape

  • It measures the mid-upper arm circumference of pregnant women and children.
  • It helps in the diagnosis of malnutrition.

questions.text: A preterm jaundiced newborn is born to a mother with a history of diabetes and hypertension. The mother also gave an account of jaundice in her second trimester. She also has a previous record of jaundice during both last pregnancies. A baby has a disorder of bile transport that led mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. In which of the following is this seen?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dubin johnson syndrome

  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia in infancy is seen in Dubin-Johnson syndrome.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It results from impaired hepatic excretion of bilirubin.
  • It causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Signs and Symptoms include:
    • Jaundice
    • Abnormal urine colour
    • Biliary tract abnormality

Option A: Gilbert syndrome

 

  • It is a condition in which the liver doesn't properly process bilirubin.
  • It is an inherited genetic condition, an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • Patients mostly have elevated unconjugated bilirubin.

Option B: Crigler Najjar syndrome

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder in which UDP-GT activity is absent.
  • Patients develop severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • If untreated, death occurs by 28-24months of age.

Option D: erythroblastosis fetalis

 

  • It causes hemolytic anaemia in newborns.
  • There is a transplacental transmission of maternal antibodies to fetal RBCs.
  • The main cause is an incompatibility between maternal and fetal blood groups.

questions.text: A final year student is presenting a case of a 15-months old child who, upon examination, has a  mongoloid slant of eyes, epicanthic fold, and simian crease. Her growth is retarded, with no dentition; there is also history of delayed dentition in one of the siblings. At what age is the dentition considered to be delayed?
questions.solution:
Option D: 13 months

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette is a case of Down syndrome with the delayed eruption of primary teeth.
  • Delayed dentition is usually considered when no teeth have erupted by 13 months.
  • Normally temporary teeth eruption is completed by 2 to 2.5 years of age

Causes of delayed tooth eruption

Mnemonic- FRIED ChoP

  • Familial
  • Rickets
  • Idiopathic
  • Endocrine
    • Congenital hypopituitarism
    • Congenital hypothyroidism
  • Down syndrome
  • Cleidocranial dysostosis
  • Progeria

Option A:18 months

  • The delayed eruption is when there is no teeth eruption till 13 months of age.

Option B: 6 months

  • The first teeth to erupt are the lower and upper central incisors, which erupt between 6-12 months.
  • The eruption is considered delayed when there is no eruption for 13 months.

Option C:16 months

  • The delayed eruption is defined as when there is no eruption of teeth till 13 months of age(not 16 months)

questions.text: Marie is a cute little girl. Her mother spends the entire day with her and teaches her new words, she tries to do whatever her mother asks her to do, and speaks the words that her mother asks her to say. With her increasing age, she can grasp more words. What would her vocabulary be on her second birthday?
questions.solution:
Option C: 100 Words

  • Although every child grows at his or her own pace, a toddler's speech or vocabulary development follows a standard or predictable sequence.
  • At the age of two years, most children can:
    • Follow easy commands and understand easy questions.
    • Use simple phrases like “more milk”.
    • Be understood most of the time by parents and other care providers.
  • Between the ages of two and three, most children can:
    • Speak sentences.
    • Use a minimum of 200 words at this age and a maximum of 1000 words.
    • Tell them their name.
    • Use pronouns like 1, me, and mine
  • Vocabulary:
    • Vocabulary at 2 years is 100 words.
    • 18 months, 8–10 words
    • 12 months, 2-3 words

questions.text: A child presents with his stepmother in the outpatient department with complaints of fever and continuous irritability. She does not know his exact age. On examination, the baby was in a tripod position, had a bi-dextrous approach, had stranger anxiety, and could speak monosyllables. Based on the above findings, what is the estimated age of the baby?
questions.solution:
Option A: 7 months

  • Age of the Baby- 7 months as:
  • Baby can sit in a tripod position for 6 months.
  • Bi-dexterous approach by 5th month.
  • Monosyllables by 6th month.
  • Stranger anxiety by 7th  month

Option B: 12 months

  • At the age of 12 months, the child can read 1 word.
  • At the age of 12 months, the baby starts to take the first step on his own

Option C: 9 months

  • At the age of 9 months, the child can speak bisyllables.
  • A child can push up to a crawl position.

Option D: 10 months

  • At the age of 10 months, children have improved motor skills.
  • Baby is able to male 1 or 2 words.

questions.text: A 1-week-old preterm male infant with low birth weight presents in the emergency department with the complaint of high-grade fever, seizures, poor feeding and irritability. His mother had a history of prolonged labour (> 18 hours) and poor socioeconomic status. On general physical examination, he is tachypneic and has a bulging anterior fontanelle and delayed capillary refill pressure. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Neonatal Sepsis

  • In this case, a 1-week-old preterm male infant with low birth weight presents in the emergency department with the complaint of high-grade fever, seizures, poor feeding and irritability. His mother had a history of prolonged labour (> 18 hours) and poor socioeconomic status. On general physical examination, he is tachypneic and has a bulging anterior fontanelle and delayed capillary refill pressure. Based on these findings, neonatal sepsis is the most appropriate diagnosis.
  • It is a clinical syndrome of systemic illness resulting from metabolic and circulatory collapse due to infection in the neonate.
  • Poor feeding, lethargy, tachycardia or bradycardia, seizures, respiratory distress and abdominal distension are the first non-specific clinical findings.
  • Maternal factors include prolonged labour, maternal chorioamnionitis, intrapartum maternal fever and poor socioeconomic status.

Option A: Cerebral oedema

  • It is related to hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.
  • It is caused due to birth asphyxia.

Option B: Meningitis

  • The hallmark signs are sudden fever, stiff neck, drowsiness and sensitivity to bright light.
  • In newborns, the most common causes are group B Streptococci.

Option D: Intraventricular haemorrhage

  • IVH is a disorder of premature/preterm infants.
  • It originates in the periventricular subependymal germinal matrix with the subsequent entry of blood into the ventricles.
  • USG is the procedure of choice for diagnosis.
  • Risk factors include extreme prematurity, prolonged and difficult labour, sudden arterial blood pressure elevation, and hypertonic fluids administration.

questions.text: A 39-year-old primigravida pregnant woman presented to an obstetric emergency and delivered a baby at 30 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1000 grams. On a general physical examination, the baby was bradycardic and hypotensive. The baby was searched for an IV line as the baby requires fluid administration due to hypovolemic shock caused by perinatal blood loss. What would be the 24-hour fluid requirement on day 1 for this preterm baby?
questions.solution:
Option C: 80 ml/kg

  • In this case, a 39-years old primigravida presented to an obstetric emergency and delivered a baby at 30 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1000 grams. The 24-hour fluid requirement for a preterm neonate with a birth weight of <1500 grams would be 80 ml/kg.

Option A: 120 ml/kg

  • For babies with <1000g body weight, the fluid requirement for them is 120 ml/kg on day 03

Option B: 60 ml/kg

  • For babies with birth weight ≥1500 grams, it would be 60 ml/kg day 01.

Option D: 100 ml/kg

  • For babies with a birth weight of less than 1000g, the fluid requirement on day 02 is 100 ml/kg.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of illness in a 14-month-old boy born to an HIV positive mother who presents with symptoms of fever, vomiting, profuse watery diarrhea, moderate dehydration, and deep-set eyes, along with examination findings of normal body temperature, elevated heart rate, and low blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cryptosporidium

  • This child is likely suffering from Cryptosporidium, Caused by a microscopic parasite. Cryptosporidium is a common aetiology responsible for most deaths in children younger than 5 years and will be even more severe in presenting in children living with HIV. Diarrhoea is the commonest presentation. The primary initial treatment for cryptosporidiosis in children is ART (anti-retroviral therapy).

Option B: Entamoeba Histolytica

  • Amebiasis, caused by Entamoeba Histolytica parasites, has similar features. Patients who are very young, elderly, and those using corticosteroids all have the more severe form of Amebiasis, but it's not as common in patients with HIV as cryptosporidium. After ingesting the parasite, asymptomatic infections are frequent. The most typical symptom is diarrhoea.

Option C: Giardia lamblia

  • AIDS and non-AIDS individuals are susceptible to intestinal malabsorption and diarrhoea from Giardia, Giardiasis. Due to a humoral immunological deficiency, AIDS patients have a greater incidence rate of diarrhoea caused by Giardia than people without AIDS. The three most typical symptoms are abdominal discomfort, watery diarrhoea, and weight loss.

Option D: Lactose intolerance

  • Those who are lactose intolerant have symptoms after consuming lactose-containing dairy products, such as milk. From mild discomfort to a severe reaction, symptoms can vary. Most lactose-intolerant persons can consume some lactose without developing symptoms. Common symptoms of lactose intolerance are Nausea, Flatulence that causes cramps and bloating in the abdomen or diarrhoea; there is no such history in the above scenario.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit after surgery following a motor vehicle collision. She has received a total of four units of packed red blood cells. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and flat neck veins. Serum studies show a creatinine of 2.1 mg/dL, and urine microscopy shows granular, muddy-brown casts. A renal biopsy specimen is obtained and examined under light microscopy. Which of the following irreversible cellular changes is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Option C: Vacuolization of the endoplasmic reticulum

Cell death:

  • Cell death is a biological process leading to the irreversible cessation of the cell's vital functions. The main types include apoptosis (programmed cell death), necrosis, pyroptosis, and autophagy.
  • The late stage of hypoxia is characterized by irreversible membrane damage and cell death
  • Degradation of phospholipids in the plasma membrane causes rupture of the cell membrane, leads to the release of cytosolic enzymes (e.g., troponin, creatinine kinase) into the serum and influx of Ca2+ into the cytoplasm, causing activation of lysosomal enzymes and p(e.g., calpain) causing increased breakdown of cellular protiens and damage to cytoskeleton resulting in autolysisRupture of lysosomes and release of lysosomal enzymes causing autolysis
  • Increased mitochondrial membrane permeability causes the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria and activation of apoptosis, causing cytoplasmic vacuolization
  • Development of amorphous densities/inclusions in the mitochondrial matrix
  • Damaged mitochondria cause a dysfunctional electron transport chain resulting in decreased ATP.
    • Nuclear degeneration in the form of the following effects:
    • Pyknosis: shrinkage of the nucleus due to chromatin condensation
    • Karyorrhexis: fragmentation of the nucleus (mediated by endonucleases)
    • Karyolysis: disintegration or dissolution of the nucleus

 

 

  • Vacuolization of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is also seen in hypoxic cell injury. A decreased synthesis of ATP (shift to anaerobic glycolysis due to kidney tissue hypoxia) in the mitochondria impairs the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, leading to an influx of Na+ and water into the cell and the ER.
  • This causes the dilation of the ER and the formation of small vacuoles. However, vacuolization of the ER is an irreversible change rather than a reversible change.

Option A: Low oxygen and ATP

Early stage: characterized by reversible cellular swelling (e.g., hydropic degeneration)

  • Tissue hypoxia leads to decreased ATP production:
  • Decreased function of Na+/K+ ATPase → diffusion of Na+ and water into the cell → ↑ passive Ca2+ efflux and expansion of the cell wall with swelling of the mitochondria, cytosol, endoplasmic reticulum, and Golgi apparatus (earliest morphologic changes)
  • Disrupted Ca2+ ATPase pump activity → ↑ active Ca2+ removal from the cytoplasm into the extracellular space → Ca2+ accumulation inside the cell → activation of degradative enzymes
  • Low oxygen and ATP → anaerobic respiration → ↑ lactate and ↓ intracellular pH → denaturation of proteins and clumping nuclear chromatin.

Option B: Plasma membrane blebbing

Membrane blebbing

  • A process by which protrusions of cell membrane separate from a cell. Part of the process of apoptosis. Also used by gram-negative bacteria to release endotoxin.
  • It is a part of reversible cell injury and not irreversible cell injury.

 

 

Option D: Swelling of the mitochondria

  • Mitochondrial swelling due to hydropic degeneration is one of the earliest reversible changes following hypoxic cell injury.
  • Acute hypoxia results in the depletion of ATP in cells, causing a switch to anaerobic glycolysis. The energy generated by this reaction is much less than that generated by oxidative phosphorylation, causing ATP levels to decrease further and impairing the Ca2+ pump and Na+/K+ ATPase.
  • Decreased Na+/K+ ATPase activity causes an influx of Na+ and water into the cell, resulting in cellular and mitochondrial swelling.
  • Other reversible changes of cell injury include membrane blebbing, nuclear chromatin clumping, and detachment of ribosomes and polysomes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been admitted to the surgical emergency for resectioning pheochromocytoma. During the ward round, the attending surgeon asks the junior residents about the metastatic potential of the pheochromocytoma. Which of the following is the most reliable feature of malignant transformation of pheochromocytoma?

choices.text: Presence of metastasis to other organs

questions.solution:
Option B: Presence of metastasis to other organs

  • There is no histologic feature that reliably predicts malignant pheochromocytoma.
  • Cellular & nuclear pleomorphism, including the presence of giant cells & mitotic figures, are often seen in benign pheochromocytomas, while cellular monotony is paradoxically associated with aggressive tumours.
  • Even capsular and vascular invasion may be encountered in benign lesions.
  • Therefore, the definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of metastases.

Pheochromocytoma:

  • A pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumour that typically develops in the adrenal medulla.
  • Pheochromocytomas are usually benign (∼ 90% of cases) but may also be malignant.
  • Classic clinical features are due to excess sympathetic nervous system stimulation and involve episodic blood pressure crises with paroxysmal headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations, and pallor.
  • However, pheochromocytomas may also be asymptomatic or manifest with persistent hypertension.
  • Elevated catecholamine metabolites in the plasma or urine confirm the diagnosis, while imaging studies in patients with positive biochemistry are used to determine the tumour's location.
  • Surgical resection is the treatment of choice but is only carried out once alpha-adrenergic blockade with phenoxybenzamine has become effective.

Option A: Presence of mitotic figures

  • The presence of mitotic figures is characteristic of any malignancy.
  • However, these findings cannot predict the metastatic transformation in pheochromocytoma.

Option C: Vascular/ capsular invasion

  • Vascular invasion or capsular invasion does not predict the metastatic transformation of the pheochromocytoma
  • Rather, metastasis to other organs is the most reliable predictor.

Option D: All of the above

  • The most reliable predictor of malignant transformation of pheochromocytoma is metastasis to other organs.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after right-sided weakness and impaired speech onset. On admission, she is diagnosed with thrombotic stroke and treatment with alteplase is begun. Neurologic examination four weeks later shows residual right hemiparesis. A head CT scan shows hypoattenuation in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery. Pyogenic infection and brain infarction are associated with which type of necrosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Liquefactive necrosis

  • Infarction in most tissues is associated with coagulative necrosis, but brain infarcts cause liquefactive necrosis for reasons that are not completely understood.
  • Liquefactive necrosis begins as early as 24-72 hours, most likely due to neutrophil infiltration into the infarct zone.
  • Neutrophils release lysosomal enzymes that digest infarcted tissue ("liquefaction").
  • By 3-5 days, macrophages infiltrate into the infarct zone and phagocytose cellular debris.
  • The late changes associated with liquefaction necrosis are softening of the brain parenchyma and the appearance of cystic spaces in the brain.
  • Encephalomalacia causes hypoattenuation of the infarcted region on imaging. In addition to liquefactive necrosis, the infarcted region may also be surrounded by scar tissue due to reactive gliosis by astrocytes.
  • Liquefactive necrosis is typically seen in cerebral infarctions and can also occur in bacterial abscesses (pyogenic renal abscesses).

Option A: Coagulative necrosis

  • Coagulative necrosis is the most common type and typically results from tissue ischemia in solid organs such as the heart, liver, spleen, and kidneys. This patient's infarct was in the brain, which is not subject to coagulative necrosis.

Option C: Caseous necrosis

  • Caseous necrosis is associated with granulomatous infections such as nocardiosis, tuberculosis, and histoplasmosis.

    Tuberculous granulomas can affect the CNS, but they appear as focal, round or lobulated nodules with surrounding oedema.

  • A different type of necrosis is associated with brain infarcts.

Option D: Fat necrosis

  • Fat necrosis is most commonly seen in patients with acute pancreatitis or traumatic breast lesions.

    This patient's infarct was in the brain, which is not subject to fat necrosis.

questions.text: A medical student is learning about bradykinin. Bradykinin is a peptide that promotes inflammation in response to infection. It causes arterioles dilation by releasing nitric oxide, prostaglandins, and hyperpolarizing factors. The synthesis and metabolism of bradykinin are shown in the image below. The role of bradykinin in the process of inflammation is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Smooth muscle relaxation: Bradykinin is a peptide that plays a key role in inflammation and is involved in various processes, including vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, and smooth muscle relaxation. However, its primary effect is smooth muscle relaxation, which contributes to vasodilation and increased blood flow to the site of inflammation. This increased blood flow helps deliver immune cells and nutrients to the area, facilitating the inflammatory response.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Vasoconstriction: Bradykinin does not cause vasoconstriction; rather, it promotes vasodilation.

Option B: Bronchodilation: While bradykinin can induce bronchoconstriction (narrowing of the airways), this effect is generally less significant than its role in vasodilation and smooth muscle relaxation.

 

Option D: Increased vascular permeability: Bradykinin does indeed increase vascular permeability, which allows fluid and immune cells to enter the tissue at the site of inflammation. However, this effect is secondary to its role in smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation.

questions.text: A college laboratory experiment is done to evaluate the chemotactic potential of a group of potential mediators in inflammation. Chemotactic factors are substances that are responsible for cellular locomotion. Chemotactic factors induce leukocyte movement and enhance leukocyte adhesion. Which of the following substances most likely has the greatest affinity for neutrophils?
questions.solution:
Option A: C5a

  • Several substances have the chemotactic potential for neutrophils.
  • C5a is a prominent example.

Chemotactic Factors

Factor

Description

Chemotactic For

Formylated peptides

Bacterial products of Escherichia coli

Neutrophils

C5a

Activated complement component

Neutrophils

HETE, LTB

Leukotrienes

Neutrophils

Kallikrein

Product of factor XIIa – mediated conversion, and other cells

Neutrophils

PAF

AGEPC; from basophils, mast cells, and other cells

Eosinophils

PDGF

From platelets, monocytes – macrophages, smooth muscle cells and endothelial cells

Neutrophils and macrophages

TGF-β

From platelets, neutrophils, macrophages, lymphocytes, and fibroblasts

Macrophages and fibroblasts

 

  • Leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2 is caused by the absence of sialyl-Lewis X, the fucose-containing ligand for E- and P-selectins, as a result of a defect in a fucosyltransferase, an enzyme that attaches fucose moieties to protein backbones.
  • This results in a failure of leukocyte adhesion to endothelium, preventing the cells from migrating into tissues and making patients prone to bacterial infections, which are often recurrent and frequently life-threatening.

Option B: Fucosyl transferase

  • The defect in fucosyltransferase causes leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2.
  • The H antigen is synthesized by fucosyltransferase.

Option C: P-selectin

  • P-selectin is a protein which is produced by activated platelets.
  • The absence of P-selectin causes leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2.

Option D: TNF-α

  • It is an inflammatory cytokine which is produced by macrophages.
  • TNF alpha is an inflammatory cytokine involved in scar formation and regression.

questions.text: A college laboratory experiment is done to evaluate the chemotactic potential of a group of potential mediators in inflammation. He learned that the leukocytes roll for several seconds over endothelial cells before arresting. The electron microscopy image below depicts the rolling of leukocytes on endothelial cells; identify the protein involved in this process.
questions.solution:
Option A: Selectins

  • Rolling interactions of leucocytes are mediated by a family of proteins called selectins

  • 3 types of selectins: L – selectins (on leucocytes), E – selectin ( on endothelium ), and P-selectin (on platelets, endothelium).

  • Integrins: Firm adhesion of leucocytes to the endothelial cell is mediated by a family of leucocyte surface proteins called integrins.

  • Transferrin: Iron transporting protein

  • PECAM-1: (platelet endothelium cell adhesion molecule)

  • Present in the inter-cellular junction between endothelial cells

  • Help in the migration of leucocytes.

Option B: Integrins

  • Integrins are transmembrane receptors that facilitate cell-extracellular matrix adhesion.

  • Firm adhesion of the leukocyte to the endothelial cell is mediated by a family of leukocyte surface proteins called integrins.

Option C: Transferrin

  • Transferrin is an iron-transporting protein and is responsible for ferric-ion delivery.

  • It transports iron to various tissues through the blood.

Option D: PECAM-1

  • PECAM-1 is present in the inter-cellular junction between endothelial cells

  • It helps in the migration of leucocytes.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man develops a significant respiratory stridor within minutes following a bee sting with dyspnea and wheezing. An epinephrine injection helps reverse these events completely, and then he recovers within a few minutes. Which of the following chemical mediator is not involved in the pathogenesis of this man's condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Myeloperoxidase

  • Myeloperoxidase (MPO) is an enzyme present in primary (or azurophilic) granules of neutrophils and takes part in the formation of reactive oxygen species.
  • In the presence of a halide such as Cl-, MPO converts H2O2 to HOCl.
  • Hypochlorous radical is used during the process of the respiratory burst.

Option A: Tumor necrosis factor-a (TNF-a)

  • It causes the adhesion of leukocytes to endothelium and their migration through vessels.
  • It is produced by activated macrophages and dendritic cells.
  • It is also released from T lymphocytes and mast cells.
  • It mainly contributes to local and systemic reactions of inflammation. The role of TNF-a in inflammation is as follows:
  • Endothelium activation causes the endothelium to induce a spectrum of changes called endothelium activation. These changes include:
  • Increased expression of endothelial adhesion molecules
  • Increased production of cytokines and chemokines, and eicosanoids
  • Increased procoagulant activity
  • Activation of leukocytes and other cells- It increases the response of neutrophils and stimulates the microbicidal activity of macrophages.
  • System acute-phase responses- including fever
  • It regulates energy balance by promoting lipid and protein catabolism and suppressing appetite.

Option B: Interleukin-1

  • Interleukin-1 is produced by macrophages, endothelial cells and some epithelial cells.
  • It stimulates the expression of endothelial adhesion molecules and the secretion of other cytokines.
  • It also has systemic effects (systemic acute-phase response).

Option D: Prostaglandins

  • They are produced by mast cells, macrophages and endothelial cells.
  • They are involved in vascular and systemic reactions of inflammation. The most important prostaglandins in inflammation are PGE2, PGD2, PGF2a, PGI2 and TXA2.
  • Prostaglandins causes:
  • TXA2- It promotes vasoconstriction and platelet aggregation.
  • PGE2- It causes vasodilation and increases vascular permeability.
  • PGI2-It causes vasodilation and inhibits platelet aggregation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of smoking and hypertension presents to an outdoor urology clinic with complaints of severe lower back pain associated with anorexia and unintentional weight loss of 15kg in six months. He denies associated urinary urgency, frequency, hesitancy, dysuria, or nocturia. Digital rectal examination reveals a firm, hard, asymmetrical, and stony prostate with a rough nodular surface, suggestive of prostate malignancy. A transrectal biopsy of prostatic tissue is taken and sent for histopathological analysis. Which of the following tumour markers is not useful in the immunohistochemistry analysis of prostatic carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ki-67

  • The diagnosis of prostatic carcinoma is confirmed in histopathology. If any suspicion is found on histopathological analysis, then immunohistochemistry is ordered to cross-check the diagnosis, and various markers help assist in this procedure.
    • Here are a few markers used for establishing the diagnosis of CA prostate on immunohistochemistry.
      • AMACR
      • EGR/TMPRSS2
      • NKX3.1
  • Ki-67 is a nuclear protein associated with ribosomal RNA synthesis and may be necessary for cell-cycle proliferation. It makes Ki-67 an important molecular prognostic marker rather than a diagnostic marker for prostatic carcinoma and has very little to no proven benefit for the diagnosis of prostatic carcinoma.
    • Ki-67 is used as a marker for HPV infection in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia.

Option A: NKX3.1

  • NK3 homeobox 1 (NKX3.1) is a validated prostate-specific marker. Most high-grade prostatic adenocarcinomas have distinct nuclear staining in tumour cells.
    • As it lines the benign prostatic epithelium, the loss/absence of NKX3.1 in a biopsy specimen indicates a non-benign (malignant/carcinomatous) process. Hence, prostatic adenocarcinoma is in the differentials.

  • Prostatic adenocarcinoma cells (arrows) show strong nuclear staining for NKX3.1.
  • In the large benign prostatic glands (arrowheads), secretory cells also show strong nuclear staining for NKX3.1, and some benign basal cells also show weaker nuclear staining.

Option B: AMACR

  • AMACR, also known as P504S, is an integral component of the immunohistochemistry (IHC) cocktail and is a molecular marker for prostatic adenocarcinoma - identified by complementary DNA microarray technology.

Option C: TMPRSS2

  • A fusion gene between ERG and the transmembrane protease, serine 2 (TMPRSS) gene, is found in prostatic adenocarcinoma.
    • ERG protein immunostaining has been used to detect the ERG/TMPRSS2 fusion protein, a fusion gene product.
    • This fusion gene product is fairly specific for prostate cancer.
    • It has potential diagnostic value in determining the prostatic origin of a metastatic focus and possibly differentiating a small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma that arose in the prostate from one arising elsewhere (e.g., the lung). ​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 23-years-old patient presented to the outpatient department with complaints of change in colour of stools to black, fatigue, and weakness. He also experiences shortness of breath and occasionally chest pain. He has a present history of peptic ulcer disease and gastritis. On laboratory investigation, his faecal blood test turned out to be positive. He is referred to a gastroenterology clinic. He is taking large amounts of unidentified drugs that inhibit platelet activity. Which of the following product helps to promote platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction in the metabolic pathway of the arachidonic acid (AA') metabolism?
questions.solution:
Option B: Thromboxane A2

  • Platelets contain the enzyme thromboxane synthase, which produces thromboxane A2, the major platelet aggregator.
  • It is a potent platelet-aggregating agent and vasoconstrictor, thus promoting thrombosis.

Option A: C5a

  • C5a is an anaphylatoxin that promotes the release of histamine from mast cells.
  • It causes:
  • Increased vascular permeability
  • Vasodilation
  • It is a chemotactic agent for neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • It activates the lipoxygenase pathway of arachidonic acid metabolism in neutrophils and monocytes, causing the release of inflammatory mediators.

Option C: Leukotriene B4

  • Leukotriene B4 is produced by neutrophils and some macrophages. It is a potent chemotactic agent.
  • It is a potent activator of neutrophils, causing aggregation and adhesion of cells to venular endothelium.
  • It promotes the generation of reactive oxygen species and the release of lysosomal enzymes.

Option D: C1 activators

  • Activation of C1 occurs through:
  • Classic pathway-Fixation of C1 to antibody IgM or IgG bound to the antigen.
  • Alternative pathway-Binding of microbial surface molecules (endotoxin, lipopolysaccharide) and complex polysaccharide to C1 protein causes its activation.
  • Lectin pathway-Plasma mannose-binding lectin binds to carbohydrates on microbes leading to activation of the C1 protein.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child has been brought to the clinic with easy bruising and fatigue for the past few weeks. On examination, no abnormal findings are noted. Bone marrow study has revealed the myeloblasts and promonocytes in the bone marrow of more than 20%. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which genetic mutation is present in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Chromosomal Inversion

  • One of the molecular mechanisms involved in AML is genetic inversion.

AML

  • AML develops due to genetic changes in a hematopoietic precursor cell that alters normal growth and differentiation, resulting in large numbers of abnormal, immature myeloid cells in the bone marrow and blood.
  • These aberrant cells can divide and proliferate but cannot normally differentiate into mature, fully functional hematopoietic cells.
  • Many chromosomal abnormalities and gene mutations are associated with prognosis in AML.
  • Cases of AML may demonstrate mutations in oncogenes (e.g., NRAS, FLT3) and/or loss of tumour suppressor genes (e.g., TP53, WT1 [Wilms tumour suppressor gene]).
  • Any hematologic malignancies are associated with specific chromosomal translocations that generate chimeric fusion genes that are never expressed in wild-type cells.
  • Chromosomal aberrations in AML commonly involve transcription factors that regulate hematopoiesis.
  • The chromosomal aberrations t(8;21)(q22;q22) and the inv(16)(p13q22) in AML involve subunits of the core-binding factor (CBF) group of transcription factors.
  • Members of the CBF group function as heterodimeric complexes regulating diverse target genes involved in tissue differentiation.
  • The cytogenetic hallmark of APL is a translocation involving the retinoic acid receptor-alpha (RARA) locus on chromosome 17.
  • These translocations lead to the formation of chimeric fusion transcripts from each of the derivative chromosomes.

Option A: Trinucleotide repeat expansion

  • Increased repetition of base triplets that leads to faulty protein synthesis or folding
  • Characterized by genetic anticipation
  • Seen in Fragile X syndrome and Huntington's disease

Option B: Anticipation

  • A phenomenon in which disease onset occurs earlier and/or the disease manifestation is more severe in offspring than in parents.
  • Seen in Huntington's disease

Option C: Heteroplasmy

  • The presence of both normal and mutated mtDNA results in variable expression in mitochondrially inherited disease.
  • Seen in mitochondrial disorders

questions.text: A 20-year-old military trainee is brought to the emergency department due to a high-grade fever for 2 days. It is associated with nausea, vomiting and headache. His medical history is positive for viral meningitis at the age of 6 years. His previous records show that he lacks membrane attack complex (MAC). Physical examination shows neck rigidity. Laboratory investigations reveal TLC 15x109cells/L with a neutrophil count of 7x109cells/L. Which of the following is the most likely cause of infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Neisseria meningitidis

  • The patient presents with a deficiency of MAC and symptoms of meningitis.
  • MAC is responsible for cell lysis.
  • MAC is formed when C5b attaches to the C6-9 complex.
  • MAC forms holes in the cell membrane, making the cell-permeable to water and ions. This leads to cell lysis.
  • MAC is important for killing microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria.
  • Hence, deficiency of this terminal complex predisposes an individual to disseminated meningococci and gonococci infections.

Option A: Streptococcus pneumoniae

  • Vitamin D deficiency is associated with an increased risk of infections, including those caused by Streptococcus, especially community-acquired streptococcal pneumonia, tonsillitis, and pharyngitis.

Option C: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

  • Disorders of the immune system are associated with high-risk pseudomonal infections.
  • Pseudomonal infections are also seen in patients with diabetes and cystic fibrosis.

Option D: Staphylococcus aureus

  • Disorders of the immune system and Vitamin A deficiency are associated with an increased risk of Staphylococcal infections

questions.text: A 39-year-old female known case of chronic liver disease presented to the emergency department with complaints of generalized body weakness, malaise, and easy fatigability for one month. On examination, she was pale-looking; the digital rectal examination was performed, which was insignificant. Her complete blood count showed microcytic anaemia with Hb 6.8 g/dL. An iron profile was also ordered. Which among the following is the best parameter for the assessment of body iron stores?
questions.solution:
Option C: Serum ferritin

  • Because plasma ferritin is derived largely from the storage pool of body iron, its levels correlate well with body iron stores.
  • Ferritin is a ubiquitous protein-iron complex found at the highest levels in the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and skeletal muscles.
  • Intracellular ferritin is located in the cytosol and in lysosomes, in which partially degraded protein shells of ferritin aggregate into hemosiderin granules.
  • Iron in hemosiderin is chemically reactive and turns blue-black when exposed to potassium ferrocyanide, which is the basis for the Prussian blue stain.
  • With normal iron stores, only trace amounts of hemosiderin are found in the body, principally in macrophages in the bone marrow, spleen, and liver, most being stored as ferritin.
  • In iron-overloaded cells, most iron is stored in hemosiderin.
  • The normal amount of serum ferritin is 24-336 mcg/L for men and 11-307 mcg/L for women.

Option A: Serum iron

  • Serum iron measures how much amount of iron is circulating in the serum.

  • About 90% of circulating iron is bound to transferrin.

  • Total body iron stores cannot be measured through this test because only the circulating amount is being measured and not the storage form in other organs.

  • Normal serum iron levels are 60-170 mcg/L.

Option B: Serum TIBC

  • TIBC stands for total iron binding capacity or transferrin iron binding capacity.

  • Iron circulates in our body by binding to transferrin.

  • This test measures the binding capacity of transferrin with iron in the blood, not the actually stored iron in the body.

  • Normal levels of serum TIBC are 240-450 mcg/dL.

Option D: Serum transferrin

  • Transferrin is a glycoprotein found in blood plasma.

  • It carries the iron in circulating blood by binding to various organs such as the spleen, bone marrow, and liver.

  • The amount of serum transferrin can be measured through TIBC; the higher the TIBC, the less iron-bound transferrin is present.

  • As it only measures the bound and non-bound iron in the circulating blood, it cannot be the best test to show the storage amount of iron in the total body.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the gynaecology department with complaints of recurrent abortions over the last two years. She is further evaluated, and it is revealed that chromosomal abnormalities caused the recurrent abortions. A study shows that when a chromosome splits along an axis, the axis is perpendicular to the conventional division axis. What is formed when a chromosome is applied along an axis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Isochromosome

  • The female mentioned above has been having recurrent abortions for the last two years. Further examination revealed that chromosomal abnormalities are the cause.
  • Isochromosome formation occurs when one arm of a chromosome is deleted while the other is duplicated.
  • This results in a chromosome with only two short arms or two long arms.
  • Genetic information in both limbs is morphologically identical.
  • The centromere misdivision is the cause of the creation of an isochromosome
  • Instead of dividing longitudinally to separate the two sister chromatids, the centromere undergoes a transverse split that separates the two arms.
  • Examples: Xq, 17q, 12p

Option A: Ring chromosome

  • A ring chromosome is an aberrant whose ends have fused to form a ring.

Option C: Acrocentric chromosome

  • An acrocentric chromosome is where the centromere is not central and is located near the end.
  • Humans generally have five pairs of acrocentric autosomes (chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, 22).
  • The Y chromosome is also acrocentric.

Option D: Subtelocentric chromosome

  • A sub-telocentric chromosome is a centromere between its middle and end but closer to the end.

questions.text: A 26-year-old African-American pilot working in the military develops fatigue, weakness and lethargy a week after redeploying to a new area. On examination, he has pallor, jaundice and splenomegaly. His investigations reveal anaemia, hemoglobinuria and hemoglobinemia. He gives a history of having received primaquine chemoprophylaxis for Plasmodium vivax malaria on redeploying to a non-malarious area. Which is the most severe variant of G6PD deficiency?
questions.solution:
Option D: G6PD-Mediterranean

  • The 26-year-old male patient had acute onset of weakness and lethargy a week after receiving primaquine.
  • His physical examination revealed jaundice, pallor and splenomegaly.
  • The investigations showed anaemia, hemoglobinemia and hemoglobinuria.
  • This suggests an acute onset hemolytic anaemia, most likely due to G6PD deficiency.
  • In G6PD deficiency, episodic hemolytic anaemia occurs after exposure to exacerbating factors.
  • Stress causes lysis of elderly erythrocytes, thus producing self-limiting hemolysis.
  • The Mediterranean variant is the most severe variant of G6PD deficiency anaemia.

Option A: G6PD-B

  • G6PD B is one of the less severe variants.
  • It is the normal variant or wild type of allele.

Option B: G6PD-A

  • One of the two common variants, A and A+, occurs in African-American males.
  • It is associated with low levels of G6PD enzymes.

Option C: G6PD-A+

  • G6PD-A is common in African-American men.
  • The G6PD A+ variant is associated with high enzyme levels and no hemolysis.

questions.text: A medicine internee discusses the various cell types at a clinicopathological conference in the embryology department. He demonstrates the ability of the stem cells to cross the barrier of differentiation to transform into the cell of another lineage. This cell expresses the molecular characteristics of different cell types with the capacity to perform the function of the new cell type. What is this new cell type called?
questions.solution:
Option C: Trans-differentiation

  • Stem cells are unique cells that can produce unaltered daughter cells and generate specialised cell types (potency).
  • Once cells are differentiated, their phenotypes become stable.
  • Tissue stem cells, which are thought to be lineage-committed multipotent cells, can differentiate into cell types outside their lineage restrictions known as trans-differentiation or stem cell plasticity).
  • Example:
    • Hematopoietic stem cells may be converted into neurons and germ cells.

Option A: Dedifferentiation

  • Dedifferentiation is a cellular process.
  • In this process, cells grow reverse, from a partially or terminally differentiated stage to a less differentiated stage within their lineage.

Option B: Re-differentiation

  • Dedifferentiated cells lose their capacity to divide through the process of re-differentiation.
  • Dedifferentiated cells progress backwards along their lineage, from partially or terminally differentiated to less differentiated.

Option D: Cellular differentiation

  • A stem cell changes from one type to another throughout cellular differentiation.
  • As an illustration, consider the transformation of a single-celled zygote into a multicellular embryo and then into the multisystem of various cell types that is a foetus.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the hospital with chest pain and respiratory distress. A prominent pansystolic heart murmur and a prominent third heart sound are heard on cardiac auscultation. The patient expires despite intense supportive measures. At autopsy, microscopic findings are as shown in a given image. The mechanism of developing a given disease is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cross-reactivity with self antigens

  • This patient is affected by acute rheumatic fever, and the image shows “Aschoff body”.
  • It results from the immune response to group A streptococci (Strep. Pyogenes) cross-react with the host tissue.
  • Antibodies directed against streptococcal M proteins cross-react with cardiac autoantigens.
    • In addition, CD4+T cells, which are specific for streptococcal peptides, also react with self-proteins in the heart and produce cytokines that activate macrophages.
    • Therefore, cardiac tissue damage combines antibody and T-cell-mediated responses.
  • In patients with acute rheumatic fever, lesions are found in various tissues.
  • These inflammatory lesions are most pronounced in the heart, called the "Aschoff body".
  • They consist of foci of eosinophilic material surrounded by T lymphocytes, occasionally plasma cells, and bulging macrophages called “Anitschkow cells".
  • These characteristic cells have abundant cytoplasm and round-to-void central nuclei in which the chromatin is arranged in a central, thin, wavy band (caterpillar cells).
  • These lesions are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever.

Option B: inflammation of the endocardium

  • Infective endocarditis is a disease which affects the inner layer of the heart, valvular endothelium, chordae tendineae and mural endocardium.
  • The following pathogens mostly cause it:
    • S. Aures (acute)
    • Viridans streptococci (sub-acute)
  • It causes the following signs/symptoms:
    • Fever
    • New murmur
    • Roth spots
    • Osler nodes
    • Splinter haemorrhages
    • Janeway lesions

Option C: Decrease organ perfusion

  • Decrease organ perfusion and delivery of nutrients cause shock in the patient.
  • These are necessary for normal tissue and cellular function.
  • It is a life-threatening condition if not treated timely.
  • It is caused by dehydration, haemorrhage (hypovolemic shock), sepsis, anaphylaxis, CNS injury (distributive shock), and cardiac embolism (obstructive shock).

Option D: Release of atrial natriuretic peptide

  • The atrial myocytes release it in response to increased blood volumes and atrial pressure.
  • It plays an important role in vasodilation and decreases Na reabsorption at the renal collecting tubule.
  • It dilates the afferent renal arteriole and constricts the efferent arterioles.
  • It promotes diuresis and contributes to the “aldosterone escape” mechanism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chronic diarrhea and weight loss. Investigation reveals a dysfunction in the mechanism of intestinal sugar absorption mediated by the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase pump. Which of the following sugars require Sodium for absorption?
questions.solution:
Option A: Glucose

  • Glucose is transported into mucosal cells by an active, energy-requiring process that requires a concurrent uptake of sodium ions and this transport protein is SGLT-1 (Sodium-dependent Glucose Transport).

Sodium-dependent transporter of Glucose:

SGLT-1 → Small intestine and Kidneys → for Glucose and Galactose

SGLT-2 → Kidneys → only for Glucose

Option B and D: Sucrose and maltose

  • The sucrose and maltose, upon digestion by intestinal enzymes, also give rise to Glucose.
  • However, if we read the question carefully, the question is asking about absorption only but not digestion and then absorption of these sugars.
  • The conversion of disaccharides to monosaccharides is considered under digestion. So, it is more apt to choose all (A, B, and C) only if there is digestion and absorption mentioned in the question.

Option C: Fructose

  • Fructose uptake requires a sodium-independent monosaccharide transporter GLUT-5 for its absorption (see fig).
  • It is present in the small intestine and testis (seminal fluid) as the primary energy source of sperm is fructose.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrics OPD with complaints of irritability, poor feeding, and vomiting. His mother also added that his urine smells like burnt sugar. After a proper physical examination, his urine sample is sent to the laboratory for analysis. Which of the following amino acids will not be found in this patient’s urine test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B : Phenylalanine

  • This patient is suffering from maple syrup urine disease. A burnt sugar-like smell is a characteristic feature of this disease.
  • Valine, isoleucine, and leucine will be found in urine tests, but not phenylalanine.
  • Phenylalaine is present in the urine in case of phenylketonuria patients which also show musty body odor.

Option A, C and D: Leucine, Isoleucine, Valine

Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD):

  • It is a rare autosomal recessive disease.
  • Typically present in children between 5 months to 7 years of age.
  • It occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched-chain keto-acid decarboxylase resulting in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids - valine, isoleucine, and leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in the urine.
  • It may cause increased alfa-ketoacid in blood, especially leucine.
  • Typical clinical presentation includes poor feeding, irritability, vomiting, loss of appetite, and poor muscle tone.
  • Urine smells like maple syrup or burnt sugar.
  • It may cause progressive neurological decline.
  • Mental retardation may occur due to increased isoleucine.
  • In untreated cases, the disease may progress to life-threatening coma or respiratory failure, and death can occur within a few months.
  • Treatment: Isoleucine, leucine, and valine restriction in diet and thiamine supplement.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors is defective in Renal glycosuria?
questions.solution:
Option D: SGLT-2

Renal Glycosuria/Familial Renal Glucosuria/Glycosuria

  • In this disease, blood glucose is normal, but still Glucose appears in urine.
  • It is due to defect/mutation in SGLT-2, which is major glucose transporter (90% glucose reabsorption) present in kidneys for the reabsorption and transport of Glucose (see fig below).

Option A: GLUT-1

  • GLUT-1 is an insulin-independent transporter for basal uptake of glucose in brain, placenta and RBCs.

Option B: GLUT-2

  • GLUT-2 is present in hepatocytes and pancreatic beta cells and intestine.
    • In intestine: help in basolateral transport of glucose in intestine.
    • In hepatocytes: Glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis in fed state.
    • In pancreatic cells: release of insulin by acting as glucose and energy sensor. GLUT-2 expression is also increased in the presence of insulin.

Option C: SGLT-1

  • SGLT-1 is major transporter in intestine for absorption of glucose and galactose and is also responsible for 10% glucose reabsorption in kidneys.
  • So, mutation in SGLT-1 leads to glucose-galactose malabsorption

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician by the mother for abdominal distention and leg pain. Physical examination discloses developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly. Further, fundoscopic examination reveals the presence of cherry-red spots in the macula. Histological examination of the bone marrow shows foamy macrophages. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Neimann Pick disease

  • Neimann Pick disease is an inherited metabolic disorder of autosomal recessive type.
  • It is common in people of Ashkenazi Jewish origin.
  • It occurs due to a genetic deficiency of the enzyme acid sphingomyelinase.
  • It is characterized by the accumulation of sphingomyelin in various body organs.
  • It has 3 types that vary in presentation and severity.
  • Commonly affected organs are the liver, spleen, central nervous system, and lungs.
  • Symptoms:
    • Mental retardation
    • Hepatosplenomegaly present
    • Cherry red spots present
    • Lymphadenopathy
      ​​​​​​​

  • There is no specific treatment for the disease. Only symptoms are treated.

Option A: Sandhoff’s disease

  • Sandhoff’s disease is a rare genetic disorder in which the nerve cells of the brain and spinal cord are destroyed.
  • It is caused by the deficiency of the enzyme beta-hexosaminidase, which results in the accumulation of specific lipids in the brain and other organs.

Option B: Gaucher’s disease

  • In Gaucher’s disease, there is an accumulation of glucosylceramide.
  • The deficient enzyme of Gaucher’s disease is β-Glucocerebrosidase.

Option D: Fabry’s disease

  • In Fabry’s disease, there is excessive deposition of glycosphingolipids in the vascular endothelium.
  • The α-Galactosidase enzyme is either absent or markedly deficient.
  • The enzyme deficiency leads to the accumulation of  Globotriaosylceramide in multiple body organs.

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy is brought to the pediatric outpatient clinic by his parents with the complaint of failure to thrive, and the baby has been passing bulky, foul-smelling stool for the last 3 weeks. The baby was diagnosed with cystic fibrosis at 3 months of age. His mother says that her sister's daughter, who is 3 months younger, has more height and weight than her baby boy. Doctor suspects deficiency of a compound with molecular formula C17H31COOH due to fat malabsorption secondary to cystic fibrosis. The molecular formula mentioned is of which of the following compound?
questions.solution:
Option A: Linoleic acid

  • In the case of a saturated fatty acid, the number of hydrogens is double the number of carbons.
  • In this fatty acid, the number of carbons is 18. The number of hydrogens is 32.
  • In the case of saturated fatty acid, if carbons are 18, then Hydrogen must be 36 (double).
  • So there is a loss of 4 H (2 double bonds). So, this is Linoleic acid with 18 C, 2 double bonds.
  • It is an omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acid.
  • Found in plant oils and seeds.
  • They help lower LDL and increase HDL, which keeps cardiovascular health good.
  • The following image shows the structure of linoleic acid.

Option B: Linolenic acid

  • The molecular formula for linolenic acid is C18H30O2.
  • It has 18 carbons and 3 double bonds.
  • An essential fatty acid that can be found in many plant seeds and oils.
  • It shows evidence of improving heart health and helps in maintaining normal rhythm and pumping.

Option C: Archidonic acid

  • The molecular formula for arachidonic acid is C20H32O2.
  • It has 20 carbons and 4 double bonds.
  • It promotes the growth of skeletal muscle tissue.

Option D: Timnodonic acid

  • The molecular formula for timnodonic acid is C20H30O2.
  • It has 20 carbons and 5 double bonds.
  • Found in fish oils.
  • It is a precursor for many essential substances in human nutrition.

questions.text: Omega-3 fatty acids are found in “oily” fish and are considered beneficial for heart health. A food containing which one of the following would not fall into this category?
questions.solution:
Option D: γ-Linolenic acid

  • Delta system—when counting starts from carboxy end
  • Omega system—when counting starts from the methyl group (omega C)

  • γ-Linolenic acid (18:3 cis Δ6,9,12) is a ω6 fatty acid.

Option A: α-Linolenic acid

  • an ω3 fatty acid with 18:3 cis-(Δ9,12,15)
  • Dietary Source: Flaxseed oil, Soya bean oil
  • α–Linoleic acid is precursor of ω-6 category

Option B: Eicosapentaenoic acid

  • Aka Timnodonic acid
  • An ω3 fatty acid with 20:5 cis-(Δ5, 8, 11, 14, 17)
  • Dietary Source: Fish oil

Option C: Docosahexaenoic acid

  • aka Cervonic acid
  • an ω3 fatty acid with 20:6 cis-(Δ4, 7, 10, 13, 16, 19)
  • Dietary Sources:
    • Fish oil
    • It is required for brain development of first 2-3 years of life so, Health drinks are fortified with DHA.
    • Breast milk always contains DHA.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding lipoprotein lipase?

choices.text: Anchored to the endothelium by positively charged heparan sulfate

questions.solution:
True Statements:

Option A: Functional plasma enzyme

  • Lipoprotein lipase is an extracellular enzyme secreted by the vascular endothelial surface of extrahepatic tissues, especially adipose tissue, skeletal muscle and cardiac tissue.
  • It functions is to hydrolytically remove triglycerides from circulating chylomicrons and VLDL releasing fatty acids and glycerol, most of which are taken by tissues and can be used as fuel or converted into triglycerides, and a small amount circulates in plasma as Albumin-FFA complex.
  • Lipoprotein lipase is activated by insulin by binding to its cofactor Apo C-II.
  • Lipoprotein lipase is anchored by heparan sulfate, which is negatively charged.

Option B: Activated by Insulin

  • Lipoprotein lipase is activated by insulin by binding to its cofactor Apo C-II.

Option C: Located on the walls of blood capillaries

  • Lipoprotein lipase is an extracellular enzyme secreted by the vascular endothelial surface of extrahepatic tissues, especially adipose tissue, skeletal muscle and cardiac tissue.

False Statements:

Option D: Anchored to the endothelium by positively charged heparan sulfate

  • Lipoprotein lipase is anchored to endothelium by heparin sulfate, which is negatively charged GAG.

Option E: Glucagon is an activator

  • Lipoprotein lipase is activated by insulin and inhibited by glucagon.

questions.text: The oxidation of glucose by the HMP pathway produces which of the following as final products?
questions.solution:
Option A: 6 NADPH

  • In the oxidative phase,2 NADPH are produced from 1 glucose molecule to give a final product of ribulose-5-P.
  • To complete the non-oxidative phase, at least three molecules of ribulose-5-P need to enter this phase.

  • To form three ribulose-5-P, 3 glucose 6-P will need to be oxidized initially, out of which 2 molecules are recovered again at the end.
  • Hence, the total reaction of the HMP pathway can be written as:

  • So, in a net reaction, a single glucose molecule is broken to glyceraldehyde-3-P and 3 CO2 and 6 NADPH.
  • Or, for a complete cycle with 3 glucose-6-P molecules, 6 NADPH are produced
  • Or we can say the final products of HMP are 6 NADPH

Option B, C and D: refer to explanation of A

questions.text: A patient presented to casualty with nausea and vomiting. Intravenous glucose was given & the patient recovered. After a few months, the patient presented with the same complaints, along with increased blood glutamine and elevated uracil levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency

  • In the urea cycle, ammonia combines with carbon dioxide and forms carbamoyl phosphate. The carbamoyl phosphate combines with ornithine and forms citrulline. The enzyme responsible for the reaction is carbamoyl phosphate synthase and ornithine carbamoyl transferase, respectively.
