  • If the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase is deficient, it leads to elevated levels of ammonia in the blood and carbamoyl phosphate from in liver mitochondria .
  • The excess carbamoyl phosphate from mitochondria enters the cytoplasm and takes part in pyrimidine synthesis leading to increased uracil synthesis (see fig).
  • Orotic acid, OMP, and UMP are all increased in OTC defect.

  • Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency presents with the symptoms of refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, seizures, etc.
  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder. It is the most common urea cycle disorder.
  • It is characterized by decreased levels of blood urea nitrogen.
  • CPS-II (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-II) is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine synthesis, not in the urea cycle.

Choice A: CPS-I deficiency

  • CPS-I enzyme is involved in the urea cycle. It is present in the mitochondria.
  • It leads to elevated ammonia levels in the blood, which can have toxic effects on the brain.
  • It does not lead to elevated levels of orotic acids in the blood.

Choice B: Arginosuccinate synthetase deficiency

  • Arginosuccinate synthase enzyme is a part of the urea cycle. It is involved in the synthesis of argininosuccinate via the enzyme argininosuccinate synthase.
  • If citrulline is increased, then it means that Arginosuccinate synthetase is the deficient enzyme.

Choice C: CPS-II deficiency

  • CPS-II is involved in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine.
  • It is activated by ATP and is inhibited by UMP.
  • ​​​​​​​Its deficiency is associated with the decreased synthesis of pyrimidine.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major source of NADPH for fatty acid synthesis?
questions.solution:
Option A: HMP shunt

  • Reductases in fatty acid synthesis require NADPH as reducing power
  • Out of all the options, NADPH is produced by the HMP shunt only.
  • Insulin is lipogenic. It increases the production of enzymes in the HMP shunt.

 

Other minor pathways producing NADPH are:

  • The malic enzyme (NADP Malate Dehydrogenase)
  • Cytoplasmic Isocitrate dehydrogenase
  • Glutamate dehydrogenase

Option B: Tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA)

  • The tricarboxylic acid cycle is a chemical reaction that takes place in mitochondria that releases energy by the oxidation of acetyl-CoA.
  • The energy released by this cycle is stored in the form of GTP, FADH2, and NADH.

Option C: Glycolysis

  • It is a reaction that splits glucose into pyruvate to extract energy.
  • It does not require any oxygen molecule.

Option D: Uronic acid pathway

  • It is used for the synthesis of glucuronic acid, pentose, ascorbic acid, and vitamins.
  • In this pathway, free sugar is involved.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A seminar is being conducted by the department of physiology on membrane channels. It is described that hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channels are encoded by four genes (HCN1,2,3,4), with HCN4 being widely expressed in the SA node. It has also been dubbed an "f" channel, and the current is produced as a funny current. Which of the following is a function of these channels?
questions.solution:
Option B: Generation of sinus rhythm

  • Funny currents are also called HCN channels (Hyperpolarization cyclic nucleotide). They are a special type of Na+ currents.
  • Heart: Generating sinus rhythm is the function of funny currents.
  • Funny currents or HCN channel is a Na+ channel (permeable to Na+ and K+ ions, with increased permeability to Na+), consisting of four identical or non-identical subunits that are integrally embedded in the cell membranes of SA nodal cells to create an ion-conducting pore.
  • Also referred to as the "h" channel (activated following hyperpolarization), the current through the h channels is called the "h" current (Ih). Because of its unusual (funny) activation, it has also been dubbed an “f” channel, and the current is produced as a funny current.

Option A: Conduction of impulse

  • Conduction of nerve impulse occurs due to active and electronic potentials along the conductors.
  • Conduction of impulse is not included in the function of funny currents.

Option C: To maintain the cytoplasmic hyperpolarization

  • If a cell has Na+ or Ca 2+ currents at rest, inhibiting those currents will also result in hyperpolarization.
  • This voltage-gated ion channel response is how the hyperpolarization state is achieved.
  • It is not included in the function of funny currents.

Option D: To maintain mitochondrial membrane potential

  • The mitochondrial membrane potential generated by proton pumps (Complexes I, III, and IV) is an essential component in the process of energy storage during oxidative phosphorylation.
  • It is not included in the function of funny currents.

questions.text: A professor explains the different types of transport across cell membranes and different types of transporters. ATP-binding cassette (ABC) acts as pumps, channels, or regulators and is responsible for the ATP-powered translocation of many substrates across membranes. Which of the following is the example of an ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter?
questions.solution:
Option C: SUR (Sulfonylurea receptor) in the pancreas

  • The sulfonylurea receptor (SUR) in the pancreas is an ATP-binding cassette transporter. 
  • ATP-dependent transporters are of two types:
    • ATPase ion transporters.
    • ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporters.
  • (ABC) ATP binding cassette transporter:
    • ABC transport proteins have a motif in their amino acid sequence. That is an ATP-binding cassette (ABC).
    • ABC transporters can act as pumps, channels, or regulators.
    • Sulfonylurea is a class of anti-diabetic drugs with receptors (SUR) on the pancreatic b-cell.
    • Have one domain where ATP will be bound
    • Other parts of protein will act as a channel or carrier
    • Examples
      • Multidrug Resistance transporter (MDR) transporter, P-glycoprotein
      • Found in cancer cells & XDR (extremely drug-resistant)
      • Critical concentration not achieved → Resistance: SUR (Sulfonyl Urea transporter); CFTR → Chloride channel
      • Voltage clamp technique: Voltage across membranes
      • Cathode Ray Oscilloscope: Action potential

Option A: F0-F1 pump

  • F0-F1 pump in the mitochondrial membrane is F-type ATPase.

Option B: SERCA in the skeletal muscle

  • SERCA is P-type ATPase. (P-type is also called E1-E2ATPase.)

Option D: Band 3

  • Band 3 protein is the Cl-/HCO3- exchanger (antiporter).

questions.text:
A 36-year-old female presented with diarrhea for the last 3 days while on vacation. On examination, she looked dehydrated, and her capillary fill was 3 seconds. Her vital signs are normal. On the chest, auscultations are S1 and S2 heart sounds and normal respiratory sounds. The following findings are given:

                                       


	
		
			
			Hemoglobin
			
			
			14
			
		
		
			
			WBCs           
			
			
			12,000/mm3
			
		
		
			
			ALT               
			
			
			52 U/L
			
		
		
			
			AST         
			
			
			39 U/L
			
		
		
			
			PH                 
			
			
			7.28
			
		
		
			
			Pco2             
			
			
			23 mm hg
			
		
		
			
			Bicarbonate   
			
			
			11 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Serum electrolytes
			
		
		
			
			Potassium =
			
			
			3.1 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Sodium =
			
			
			132 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Chloride=
			
			
			110 mEq/L
			
		
	


Which of the following is the correct diagnosis for this patient??
questions.solution:
Option A: Metabolic acidosis

  • This female presented with diarrhea for the last 3 days with low PH, low potassium, low sodium, and low bicarbonate and normal anion gap (anion gap= Na - ( K + Hco3), and has a most likely diagnosis of metabolic acidosis.
  • An acidic PH, along with decreased bicarbonate and decreased Pco2, is consistent with metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation, e.g., hyperventilation.
  • The main causes of metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap are: Remember that
    • H for hyperchloremia
    • A for alimentation
    • A for Addison disease
    • R for renal tubular acidosis
    • D for diarrhea
    • A for acetazolamide
    • S for spironolactone
    • S for saline infusion
  • Diarrhea causes loss of bicarbonate, so that's why it causes metabolic acidosis.
  • The easiest way to find the cause of acidosis is first to check the pco2 and bicarbonates. If pco2 is more than 44 mmHg, it would be respiratory acidosis, or if bicarbonate is less than 20 mEq/L, it would be metabolic acidosis. If it is metabolic acidosis, then check the anion gap. If the gap is more than 12 mEq/L, it would be high anion gap metabolic acidosis, or if it is less than 12 mEq /L, it would be non-anion gap metabolic acidosis

Option B: Metabolic alkalosis

  • In metabolic acidosis, pH would be increased, and bicarbonate would also be increased, but in this patient, PH and bicarbonate are low.

Option C: Respiratory acidosis

  • In respiratory acidosis, the pH would be low, and pco2 would be greater than 44 mmHg, but in the patient, pco2 is very low, and pH is also low, so that's why this is not respiratory acidosis.

Option D: Respiratory alkalosis

  • In respiratory alkalosis, PCO2 should be less than 36 mmHg and pH greater than 7.45.

questions.text: Your professor is giving a lecture on Charcot Marie Tooth Disease. He conducts a pre-test before the start of the lecture. One of the questions mentioned in the paper is, "Which among the following defective connexin causes the disease?" Choose the right answer among the following option.
questions.solution:
Option B: Connexin 32

  • Charcot Marie Tooth disease results from defective connexin-32 that forms gap junctions between adjacent Schwann cells.
  • Charcot Marie Tooth disease is peripheral neuropathy.
  • It is a group of inherited disorders that cause nerve damage. This damage is mostly in the arms and legs (peripheral nerves).
  • Defective myelination is the result of defective myelination.

Option A: Connexin 30

  • Mutations in the GJB6 gene encoding connexin 30 can cause dominant forms of non-syndromic deafness.

Option C: Connexin 36

  • Connexin 36 (Cx36): Expressed in pancreatic islet beta cells.
  • Loss of Cx36 prevents the generation of pulses of insulin release in a single islet.
  • Cx36 defect: Results in altered serum insulin oscillations and glucose intolerance.

Option D: Connexin 40

  • Defect in connexin 40: Idiopathic atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct pairing of its nuclei and respective function?

choices.text: Satiety center: lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus
Reward center: Ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus
Circadian rhythm: preoptic nuclei of the hypothalamus
Oxytocin secretion: paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D: Oxytocin secretion: paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus

  • Hypothalamus is the control center for the body, which maintains homeostasis in the body through its hormone secretions.
  • It is composed of three zones. One of its zones is the periventricular zone, and the other is lateral and medial.
  • These zones control and regulate specific functions.
  • Medial and lateral zones of the hypothalamus are concerned with autonomic and somatic functions.
  • The periventricular zone is concerned with the regulation of the endocrine system.
  • Hypothalamus is composed of multiple nuclei, which are responsible for multiple functions in the body.
  • The paraventricular and supraoptic nuclei serve the function of oxytocin secretion and ADH secretion.
  • The preoptic, anterior, and posterior nuclei serve the temperature regulation function.
  • The suprachiasmatic nucleus regulates the release of hormones, circadian rhythm, and behavior.
  • The ventromedial nucleus serves as the satiety center of the body.
  • Similarly, the dorsomedial nucleus regulates rage, and the medial forebrain bundle serves as the body's reward center.

Option A: Satiety center: lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus

The pair does not represent the correct pairing of the nucleus and respective function.

  • The ventromedial nucleus serves as the satiety center.
  • The lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus does not serve as the satiety center.

Option B: Reward center: Ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus

The pair does not represent the correct pairing of the nucleus and respective function.

  • The media forebrain bundle serves as the reward center.
  • The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus does not serve as the reward center.

Option C: Circadian rhythm: preoptic nuclei of the hypothalamus

The pair does not represent the correct pairing of the nucleus and respective function.

  • The suprachiasmatic nucleus is involved in regulating circadian rhythm.
  • The preoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus is not involved in the regulation of circadian rhythm.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the cardiology clinic for a routine wellness visit. ECG shows no P wave but has a normal QRS complex and a normal T wave. With this given information, which is the most probable location of the pacemaker in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Atrioventricular (AV) node

  • There are absent P waves in the ECG when there is no atrial depolarisation. Therefore, the pacemaker is not situated in the sinoatrial node.
  • Since the QRS and T waves are normal, the depolarisation and repolarisation of the ventricle should be in the normal sequence.
  • This situation can occur if the pacemaker is located in the atrioventricular (AV) node.
  • When the pacemaker is placed in the bundle of His or the Purkinje system, the ventricles will be activated in the abnormal sequence, and the QRS complex in ECG will have an abnormal configuration.
  • Ventricular muscle does not have pacemaker properties.

Option A: In the Sinoatrial (SA) node,

  • There are absent P waves in the ECG when there is no atrial depolarisation. Therefore, the pacemaker is not situated in the sinoatrial node.

Option C: Bundle of His

  • When the pacemaker is placed in His bundle, the ventricles will be activated in the abnormal sequence, and the QRS complex in ECG will have an abnormal configuration.

Option D: Purkinje system

  • When the pacemaker is placed in the Purkinje system, the ventricles will be activated in the abnormal sequence, and the QRS complex in ECG will have an abnormal configuration.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypertension presents to the emergency with severe chest pain for the last 2 hours. ECG is performed. What will be his heart rate according to his lead II recording?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 70:

  • The heart rate can be calculated with the R-R interval. It is calculated by dividing '60' with the R-R interval of 0.86 sec.
  • This results in a heart rate of 70 beats/min. (1500/No. of small squares between R-R interval; 300/No. of large squares between R-R interval; but R-R interval should be regular).
  • So, as there are 21 small boxes in between two R-R intervals hence 1500/21 = 71
  • Approximately 70 heartbeats/min

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D: Refers to the option A explanation

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman presents in the emergency with prolonged bleeding during a dental procedure 3 hours ago. She has been unable to control bleeding since then. On inquiring further, she says that she suffered from frequent nosebleeds and profuse bleeding from minor cuts during her childhood. She has a history of heavy menstrual flow as well. The laboratory tests show increased bleeding time and abnormal ristocetin cofactor assay. The coagulation profile reveals an increased PTT but a normal PT. 

Which of the following is not responsible for synthesizing the factor deficient in the etiology of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hepatocytes

  • In the clinical scenario above, the patient has von-Willebrand disease due to a deficiency of the von-Willebrand factor. An autosomal dominant disorder causes an intrinsic pathway coagulation defect and defective platelet plug formation.
  • Clinical findings most commonly include epistaxis and hematomas. Prolonged bleeding from minor cuts, oral cavities, and heavy menstrual flow are also common. Lab value shows increased bleeding time, PTT, and abnormal ristocetin cofactor assay but normal PT and platelet count.
  • The von-Willebrand factor is a glycoprotein that circulates in the blood plasma. It is synthesized and released from the storage granules in endothelial cells (main source) and platelets.
  • It plays a significant role, firstly, in the adhesion of platelets to sites of vascular injury and, secondly, in the binding and stabilization of factor 8 in the intrinsic coagulation pathway.
  • The liver is responsible for synthesizing many clotting factors such as factors 2, 7, 9, 10, protein C, and protein S. These are present in their inactive forms and are activated in the presence of vitamin K in the liver. Factor 8, however, is not synthesized in the liver. It has two components:
    1. Factor 8c (coagulant factor 8): Synthesized in the liver (main source) and kidney.
    2. Von Willebrand factor (vWF): Synthesized in the endothelium (main source) and megakaryocytes.

Option A: Endothelial cells

  • Von Willebrand factor is a multimeric glycoprotein in blood plasma, sub-endothelial matrix, and the Weibel-Palade bodies in the endothelial cells. This factor is released from the storage granules in endothelium in response to vascular injury.

Option B: Megakaryocytes

  • Von Willebrand factor is a glycoprotein circulating in the blood plasma. It is present in the alpha granules of megakaryocytes and released in response to tissue injury to take part in the intrinsic coagulation pathway and platelet plug formation at the sites of vascular injury.

Option D: None

  • Von Willebrand factor is synthesized, stored in granules, and then released from the endothelium and platelets. However, hepatocytes are not responsible for synthesizing the von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: A professor explains the glomerular filtration rate in a physiology class. GFR is the amount of plasma ultrafiltrate formed each minute and can be measured by measuring the plasma level of a substance and the amount of the substance that is excreted. A substance to be used to measure GFR must be freely filtered through the glomeruli and must be neither secreted nor reabsorbed by the tubules. Which change tends to increase GFR?
questions.solution:
Option C: Increased glomerular capillary filtration coefficient

  • Increasing the glomerular capillary filtration coefficient tends to increase GFR.
  • Glomerular capillary filtration coefficient = hydraulic conductivity x surface area of the glomerular capillaries.
  • Increased afferent arteriolar resistance, decreased efferent arteriolar resistance, increased Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure, and decreased glomerular hydrostatic pressure tend to decrease GFR

Option A: Increased afferent arteriolar resistance

  • Increased afferent arteriolar resistance tends to decrease GFR.

Option B: Decreased efferent arteriolar resistance

  • Decreased efferent arteriolar resistance tends to decrease GFR.

Option D: Increased Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure

  • If hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's capsule increases, GFR will decrease.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and diarrhea for 1 week. She was on a trip to rural areas 10 days ago. However, she had no such symptoms while her stay in the village. Based on her laboratory results, the physician suspects metabolic acidosis. Her lungs and kidneys are functioning normally. All of the following findings are associated with this patient’s condition except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Increased plasma HCO3− concentration

  • Chronic metabolic acidosis is associated with decreased HCO3−, not increased plasma HCO3− concentration.

Metabolic acidosis

  • It is the acid-base imbalance characterized by excess accumulation of organic acids in the body, which is caused by abnormal metabolic processes.
  • Organic acids such as lactic acid, ketoacids, and uric acid are formed by normal metabolism.
  • The quantity of these acids increases due to abnormality in the metabolism.
  • Chronic metabolic acidosis: It, by definition, is associated with
    • Decreased HCO3−
    • Increased excretion of NH4Cl occurs with renal compensation for the acidosis.
    • Respiratory compensation for acidosis increases the ventilation rate, decreasing plasma PCO2.
  • Biochemical changes in arterial blood during acid-base disturbance:
Parameter Acidosis Alkalosis
Respiratory Metabolic Respiratory Metabolic
H+ Increases Increases Decreases Decreases
pH Decreases Decreases Increases Increases
pCO2 Increases Decreases Decreases Increases
HCO3- Increases slightly Decreases very much Decreases slightly Increases very much

Option A: Increased renal excretion of NH4Cl

  • In Chronic metabolic acidosis, increased excretion of NH4Cl occurs with renal compensation for the acidosis.

Option B: Decreased urine pH

  • Chronic metabolic acidosis is associated with decreased urine pH.

Option C: Decreased urine HCO3− excretion

  • Chronic metabolic acidosis is associated with decreased urine HCO3− excretion.

questions.text: In which of these locations is the sodium-iodide symporter not present?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ovaries.

Sodium-iodide symporter:

  • The sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) is responsible for thyroidal, salivary, gastric, intestinal, and mammary iodide uptake.
  • NIS is an integral plasma membrane glycoprotein that mediates the active transport of iodide into the cells of various body organs.
  • It co-transports two sodium ions and one iodide, with the transmembrane sodium gradient as the driving force for iodide uptake.
  • The sodium-potassium ATPase pump generates the energy for this.

Option A: Thyroid glands

 

 

  • Sodium-iodide symporter is present in thyroid glands.
  • It helps to transport iodides from the blood into the thyroid glandular cells and follicles due to the ability of the basal membrane of the thyroid cell to pump iodide actively to the interior of the cell. This is achieved by the action of the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS), which co-transports one iodide ion along with two sodium ions across the basolateral plasma membrane into the cell. The energy for this process is driven by the sodium-potassium ATPase pump.
  • Concentrating the iodide, called iodide trapping, is an important process in synthesizing thyroid hormones.
  • TSH in the thyroid glands regulates the sodium iodide symporter expression.

Option B: Mammary glands

  • Sodium iodide symporter is present in mammary glands.
  • It is expressed in the normal breast only late in pregnancy and during lactation. Lactation is critical as milk is the only source of iodide ions for the newborn.
  • The sodium iodide symporter expression is regulated by oxytocin, prolactin, and estrogen in the mammary glands.

Option C: Placenta

  • Sodium-iodide symporter is present in the placenta.
  • In placenta. NIS is expressed at the apical membrane of cytotrophoblasts. It regulates the transport of iodide ions from the maternal to the fetal circulation, a process critical for normal fetal thyroid function.
  • The presence of sodium-iodide symporter has been reported in the human placental endometrial glands during the first trimester of pregnancy. Also, it has been reported in postmenopausal and sterile women but to a lesser extent in fertile women. Therefore, it can be used as a biomarker for distinguishing between sterile and fertile endometrial mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about gastric secretion?

choices.text: Gastric phase accounts for 80% of gastric secretion
Enterochromaffin-like cells in gastric mucosa secrete somatostatin
Trefoil peptides prevent erosion of gastric mucosa by gastric acid
Daily gastric secretion is approximately 1.0 L

questions.solution:
Option C: Trefoil peptides prevent erosion of gastric mucosa by gastric acid

  • Trefoil peptides (TTF) are 40 amino acids peptides related to mucin-associated secretory molecules mediating many physiological roles that maintain and restore gastrointestinal mucosal homeostasis.
  • The surface cells of gastric mucosa secrete primarily mucus and bicarbonate.
  • This protects the stomach from digesting itself, as well as substances, are known as trefoil peptides that stabilize the mucus bicarbonate layer.
  • TTF is constitutively expressed in the gastrointestinal tract and is involved in defense and repair by promoting epithelial restitution.
  • Damage to these proteins causes erosions and even ulcers in the stomach.

Option A: Gastric phase accounts for 80% of gastric secretion

  • The gastric phase accounts for 60% of gastric secretion.

Option B: Enterochromaffin-like cells in gastric mucosa secrete somatostatin

  • Enterochromaffin-like cells in gastric mucosa secrete Histamine.

Option D: Daily gastric secretion is approximately 1.0 L

  • Gastric secretion 1.5-2.5 L/day

questions.text: A research group wants to assess a new drug's safety and toxicity profile. A clinical trial is conducted with 20 healthy volunteers to estimate the maximum tolerated dose and monitor the apparent toxicity of the drug. The study design is best described as which of the following clinical trial phases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A : Phase I

  • The clinical trial phase involves administering doses of a new drug to healthy volunteers to determine its safety and preliminary pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic properties.
  • Following the initial evaluation of the drug to assess for its pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic properties (phase 0 trial), phase I clinical trials assess drug safety and determine tolerable drug dosages.
  • The results of the phase I trials are used to organize trials with a larger sample size that assess drug efficacy (phase II trials and phase III trials).

 

Option B: Phase II

  • The phase of a clinical trial in which a small number of individuals with the disease of interest take the drug to determine its efficacy, effective dosing, and adverse effects.
  • Phase II trials are the first trials that evaluate drug efficacy among a small group of patients with the disease of interest. The drug dosing of a phase II trial would be based on the research group's toxicity and side effect profile.

Option C: Phase III

  • The clinical trial phase involves a large-scale, randomized study to compare the experimental drug with a placebo or the current "gold standard" of treatment.
  • Phase III trials generally require large numbers of volunteers participating in a randomized control trial rather than the small number of volunteers studied here. Moreover, the primary goal of a phase III trial is to evaluate drug efficacy against the “gold standard” treatment rather than to study the safety, toxicity, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of a drug.
  • “The purpose of phase III trials is to obtain adequate data about the efficacy and safety of drugs in a larger number of patients of either sex in multiple centres usually in comparison with the standard drug.”

Option D: Phase IV

  • A post-approval/post-marketing stage in drug development assesses the effects of long-term drug use. This can result in the withdrawal of the drug from the market.
  • Phase IV trials are long-term “surveillance” trials. Often commenced and continued even after FDA approval, phase IV trials are meant to identify the long-term risks of drug treatment beyond those discovered during initial trials. Phase IV trials involve thousands of patients, many more than the small group of healthy volunteers included in the study.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes phase IV clinical trials?

choices.text: It is done for pediatric drugs
It is done for rare drugs
It is post-marketing surveillance of drugs
It is also called human pharmacology and safety studies

questions.solution:
Option C: It is post-marketing surveillance of drugs

Phase IV clinical trials:

  • Post-marketing surveillance compares the real-life efficacy to that described in research studies.
  • Safety studies following approval (esp. evaluation of rare and long-term side effects)
  • The study population is many patients with a specific disease after drug approval.
  • The study design is open-label.

Option A: It is done for pediatric drugs

  • Phase IV clinical trial includes the post-marketing studies. Phase IV trails are meant to identify the long-term risks of drug treatment beyond those discovered during initial trials. 
  • They are not just done for pediatric drugs to assess the long-term adverse effects of any drug being sent to the market.

Option B: It is done for rare drugs

  • Phase IV clinical trials are done for all the approved drugs from phases one to three. Thus include the post-marketing studies of all drugs and assess the long-term adverse effects.

Option D: It is also called human pharmacology and safety studies

  • Phase I clinical trial is known as human pharmacology and safety studies.
  • Phase I clinical trials assess drug safety and determine tolerable drug dosages.

questions.text: A 37-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of eye pain, nausea, and headache associated with blurred vision with coloured halos for 4 days. The general physical examination was unremarkable. On ocular exam, there is a hazy cornea, the pupils are non-reactive, and the angle of the anterior chamber is completely closed. Which of the following medication should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Timolol

  • Based on the symptoms and signs, the diagnosis is angle-closure glaucoma. In the given scenario, a beta-antagonist drug, timolol, will be used.
  • Timolol is a non-selective beta-adrenergic receptor blocker.
  • It reduces intraocular pressure by reducing the production of aqueous humour.
  • It should be administered twice a day.

Option A: Corticosteroids

  • In the given scenario, corticosteroids will not be used.
  • Corticosteroids, used frequently as anti-inflammatory drugs, can increase the risk of glaucoma by raising the intraocular pressure when administered exogenously (topically, peri-ocularly, or systemically) and in certain conditions such as Cushing's syndrome.

Option C: Ipratropium

  • In the given scenario, ipratropium will not be used.
  • Beta-agonist drugs can increase intraocular pressure, which can aggravate angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Ipratropium is used to help control the symptoms of pulmonary diseases such as asthma, chronic bronchitis, and emphysema.

Option D: Atropine

  • Atropine is an anti-cholinergic that acts via nonselective muscarinic receptor blockade.
  • Anti-cholinergic drugs are contra-indicated in angle closure glaucoma because they increase the IOP by closing the canal of Schlemm.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient, who has diabetes & hypertension presents to the eye clinic with decreased visual acuity, changes in color perception, and difficulty reading associated with nausea and headache for 4 days. On the fundoscopy, macular thickening with hard exudates is seen. On ocular examination, non-reactive mid-dilated pupils with hazy cornea are noted. Which of the following drugs might be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acetazolamide

  • Based on the symptoms and signs in the scenario, the most likely diagnosis is diabetic macular oedema with glaucoma.
  • According to the clinical diagnosis, acetazolamide will be given in this scenario.
  • It is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and will decrease the rate of aqueous humour formation, eventually resulting in the reduction of intraocular pressure.
  • Acetazolamide also reduces macular oedema and improves visual acuity in some patients.

Option A: Bimatoprost

  • Bimatoprost is a prostaglandin (PG) analog.
  • All PG analogues can cause cystoid macular oedema. Therefore, bimatoprost will be contraindicated in the patient already having macular oedema, and only acetazolamide will be given.
  • Bimatoprost lowers the intraocular pressure by increasing the aqueous's outflow through the trabecular meshwork and uveoscleral routes.

Option C: Topical epinephrine

  • Topical epinephrine can lead to epinephrine-induced cystoid macular oedema. Therefore, it will be avoided in this scenario.
  • Topical epinephrine is an effective agent for controlling intraocular pressure in patients with open-angle glaucoma.

Option D: Latanoprost

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue as well.
  • All PG analogues can cause cystoid macular oedema. Therefore, latanoprost will be contraindicated in the patient already having macular oedema, and only acetazolamide will be given.
  • It increases the outflow of aqueous humour, helping lower intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male comes in with complaints of episodic, intense joint pain in her left big toe for the past 4 months. On examination, you notice an erythematous swelling, which is tender on palpation. You make a diagnosis of Chronic Gout. Which of the following anti-gout drugs would you prescribe, given that it acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase?
questions.solution:
Option C: Allopurinol

  • The patient’s intense joint pain and erythematous swelling in the left big toe indicate gout. Gout is defined as inflammatory monoarthritis caused by the accumulation of monosodium urate crystals in joints.
  • The most common risk factors for gout include Male sex, Diabetes, Hypertension, Dyslipidemia, and Alcohol use.
  • Allopurinol is the first-line drug for the treatment of chronic gout. It acts by competitively inhibiting the xanthine oxidase, causing a decrease in the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine into urate.
  • Allopurinol can also be used in leukaemia and lymphoma to prevent tumour lysis syndrome –associated with urate nephropathy.
  • There is an increased risk of toxicity of Azathioprine and 6 –Marceptopurine when taken with Allopurinol as the former are degraded by the action of xanthine oxidase.
  • The most common side effects of Allopurinol include rash (Steven Johnson Syndrome), fever, chills, abnormal liver function tests, nausea, diarrhoea and an increase in gout attacks on initial intake due to increased mobilisation of tissue urate stores.
  • Generally, Allopurinol is considered safe for long-term use, making it an ideal drug for chronic gout

DRUGS USED IN CHRONIC GOUT

Group Mechanism Drugs
Uric acid synthesis inhibitors Xanthine oxidase inhibitors Allopurinol, Febuxostat
Uricosuric agents URAT-1 transporter inhibitors Probenecid, Sulfinpyrazone, Benzbromarone, Lesinurad
Recombinant uricase Cause oxidation of urate to allantoin Rasburicase, Pegloticase

Option A: Probenecid

  • Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that can be used as an adjunct (not first-line) treatment in Chronic Gout.

Option B: Rasburicase

  • Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase that causes the oxidation of urate into allantoin, a substance that the kidney can easily execrate.

Option D: Sulfinpyrazone

  • Sulphinpyrazone is a URAT-1 transporter inhibitor that causes decreased reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal convoluted tubule. It is not the first-line agent for the treatment of chronic gout

questions.text: What items are essential to have on hand in an emergency situation when administering opioids to a patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Naloxone

  • The complaints of lower abdominal pain at term suggest labour pains. The patient is given Tramadol (opioid analgesic), and its effect can be reversed by giving Naloxone.
  • Naloxone is an opioid antagonist given intravenously.
  • It blocks mu, kappa, and delta receptors.
  • It is the drug of choice for opioid toxicity.
  • Tramadol is an atypical opioid that relieves pain. It is a µ opioid receptor agonist and relieves pain. Its affinity for µ opioid receptor is low, while that for K and delta is very low.
  • Unlike other opioids, it inhibits the reuptake of NA and 5-HT, increases 5-HT release, and thus activates monoaminergic spinal inhibition of pain (descending inhibitory pathway), which relieves pain.
  • The opioid antagonist naloxone only partially reverses its analgesic action.

Option A: Lignocaine

  • Lignocaine belongs to the aminoamide class of local anaesthetics.
  • It is used as an anaesthetic lubricant.
  • Lignocaine is also indicated in ventricular arrhythmia.
  • It is not indicated in the reversal of opioid effects.

Option C: Diphenhydramine

  • Diphenhydramine is a first generation antihistaminic.
  • It temporarily relieves symptoms of hay fever, upper respiratory allergies, and the common cold.
  • It works by blocking histamine in the body.
  • It does not have opioid antagonist properties.

Option D: Fentanyl

  • Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid. It doe not have any opioid antagonist effect.
  • Indications for fentanyl include:
    • Preoperative analgesia
    • Anaesthesia adjunct
    • Regional anaesthesia adjunct
    • General anaesthesia
    • Postoperative pain control

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by her friend after an overdose of the drug ‘x’.  The patient’s friend talks about his habit of excessive drinking. His AST and ALT values are abnormally high. On seeing the empty blister packs of the tablet, the resident on duty instructs the nurse to give N-acetyl-cysteine as an antidote. Which of the following is drug x?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acetaminophen

  • Acetaminophen is a cyclooxygenase inhibitor that acts mainly in the central nervous system. Its toxicity manifests as abnormally high AST and ALT (>1000)   values on liver function tests.

  • Alcoholics are more likely to have acetaminophen toxicity because chronic alcoholism induces CYP enzymes, especially CYP2E1, which is involved in the conversion of acetaminophen to the toxic metabolite NAPQI.

  • It is metabolised to N-acetyl paraaminobenzo quinoneimine (NAPQ) by microsomal enzymes.

  • When a huge dose of paracetamol is taken, glucuronidation capacity is saturated; more of the minor metabolite is formed, leading to the depletion of glutathione stores.

  • This metabolite has a high affinity for sulfhydryl groups and can combine with enzymes and other biomolecules resulting in hepatotoxicity characterised by hepatic necrosis.

  • Acetaminophen toxicity can be decreased by providing sulfhydryl donors like N-acetylcysteine (antidote of choice). It is given orally to patients with overdose. It replenishes the body’s glutathione stores.

Option A: Heparin

  • Heparin is an anticoagulant that acts on factor II and factor X by potentiating antithrombin III. Protamine sulfate is used as its antidote.

Option C: Morphine

  • Morphine is an opioid that acts as a μ-receptor agonist. Its overdose can cause constipation, Miosis and respiratory depression. Naloxone is used as its antidote.

Option D: Benzodiazepine

  • Benzodiazepine is a GABA-A receptor agonist used in various manifestations such as status epilepticus and alcohol withdrawal. Its antidote is flumazenil

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with epilepsy and schizophrenia was admitted for difficulty walking, eye spasms, protruding tongue, extended neck, agitation, hand tremors, speech difficulties, and repetitive facial movements worsening over four weeks. She's been on carbamazepine and haloperidol for over a decade. Least likely to cause extrapyramidal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option C: Carbamazepine

  • Carbamazepine is an anti-seizure medication used for monotherapy and adjunctive therapy in the treatment of patients with focal onset seizures and generalized onset seizures.
    • It is also used as monotherapy in the acute treatment of hypomania and mild to moderate mania or episodes with mixed features associated with bipolar disorder.
    • It is also used for the treatment of trigeminal or glossopharyngeal neuralgia.
  • In addition to anti-seizure effects, carbamazepine has anticholinergic, antineuralgic, antidiuretic, muscle relaxant, antimanic, anti-depressive, and antiarrhythmic properties; it may depress activity in the nucleus ventralis of the thalamus or decrease synaptic transmission or decrease summation of temporal stimulation leading to neural discharge by limiting the influx of sodium ions across the cell membrane, stimulates the release of ADH and potentiates its action in promoting the reabsorption of water; chemically related to tricyclic antidepressants.
    • Carbamazepine has no dopamine D2 antagonist activity, which is the basis for causing extrapyramidal symptoms; therefore, carbamazepine does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option A: Chlorpromazine

  • Being a first-generation antipsychotic and a dopamine D2 antagonist, chlorpromazine is more likely to produce extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option B: Fluphenazine

  • Being a first-generation antipsychotic and a dopamine D2 antagonist, fluphenazine is more likely to produce extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option D: Haloperidol

  • As a first-generation antipsychotic and a potent dopamine D2 antagonist, haloperidol is well-known for extrapyramidal side effects limiting its use in the clinical practice where better and safer alternatives are available.

questions.text: A 41-year-old female presents to the outdoor patient department with complaints of increased frequency of urination and increased thirst. Her BSR chart shows that her postprandial glucose levels are in the range of 400-500 mg/dL. The doctor prescribes her a drug to take during the first part of the meal. Which of the following drugs is taken during the first part of the meal for the purpose of delaying the absorption of dietary carbohydrates?
questions.solution:
Option A: Acarbose

  • Acarbose is a complex oligosaccharide that inhibits both membrane-bound intestinal alpha-glucoside hydrolase and pancreatic alpha-amylase in a manner that is both competitive and reversible. Alpha-amylase originates in the pancreas and is secreted into the small intestine, where it is responsible for hydrolysing complex carbohydrates into oligosaccharides. 
  • An enzyme known as intestinal alpha-glucosidase hydrolase is responsible for converting oligosaccharides, trisaccharides, and disaccharides (such as sucrose and maltose) into monosaccharides. 
  • This conversion takes place in the brush border of the small intestine (such as glucose and fructose). Because it causes a delay in the digestion of carbohydrates, acarbose is effective in lowering the amount of glucose that is absorbed after a meal. Because of this, the amount of glucose that is present in the blood after a meal is reduced.
  • Glipizide is a sulphonylurea of the second generation that assists in the body's natural production of insulin.
  • The metabolic production of glucose is inhibited by the biguanide drug metformin.
  • Exenatide is a GLP-1 analogue that delays stomach emptying, reduces hunger, and increases glucose output.

Option B: Glipizide

  • Glipizide is a second-generation sulphonylurea which helps in the secretion of insulin.

Option C: Metformin

  • Metformin is a biguanide which decreases the synthesis of glucose.

Option D: Exenatide

  • Exenatide is a GLP-1 analogue that delays gastric emptying, decreases appetite, and increases glucose secretion.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia for 15 years is admitted to the psychiatry ward with difficulty walking, eye spasms/blinking, protruding tongue, extended neck, agitation, hand tremors, difficulty speaking and repetitive facial movements ongoing for about four weeks and worsening gradually. Her husband mentions that she has been using some medications prescribed by her primary physician. Which of the following drugs are likely to cause these symptoms in the patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Antipsychotics

  • The scenario mentioned above is a case of schizophrenia being managed with antipsychotics, and now the patient has presented with extrapyramidal symptoms, as mentioned.
  • Antipsychotics are known for their extrapyramidal symptoms, including akathisia, rigidity, bradykinesia, tremors, acute dystonic reactions and tardive dyskinesia.
    • First-generation antipsychotics include haloperidol, chlorpromazine, fluphenazine, pimozide and thioridazine.
    • Second-generation antipsychotics include clozapine, olanzapine, aripiprazole, risperidone and quetiapine.
  • EPS are caused by the blockade of dopamine D2 receptors affecting dopamine transmission via the nigrostriatal tract.
    • EPS are managed initially by the dose adjustment of antipsychotics.

Option A: Antidepressants

  • Antidepressants are not the drugs of choice for the management of schizophrenia. Therefore it is least likely that the patient was prescribed some antidepressants in this case.
    • Secondly, the common side effects of antidepressants include hypotension, bone fractures, seizures, teratogenicity, sexual dysfunction and antimuscarinic side effects.

Option C: Antiepileptics

  • Antiepileptics are not the drugs of choice for the management of schizophrenia. Therefore it is least likely that the patient was prescribed some antidepressants in this case.
    • Secondly, common side effects of antiepileptics include hyponatremia, suicidal ideation and bone diseases. EPS are not associated with the use of antiepileptics.

Option D: Antiparkinson drugs

  • Carbidopa and levodopa are antiparkinson drugs not prescribed for the management of schizophrenia.
    • Common side effects include nausea and vomiting, peripheral neuropathy, dyskinesia, impulsive control disorders, compulsive sexual behaviour, pathological gambling, orthostatic hypotension, withdrawal syndrome/Parkinsonism-hyperpyrexia syndrome and psychosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was brought into the emergency department after he was found to have fits. After taking a clear history, it is evident that it was a focal seizure and he had only one prior seizure episode. Liver function tests and renal function tests turned out to be normal. Which of the following drugs is the drug of choice for such seizures?
questions.solution:
Option D: Carbamazepine

  • Carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine (related drugs), phenytoin, lamotrigine and topiramate are currently the drugs of choice approved for the initial treatment of partial seizures, including those that secondarily generalise.
  • Overall they have very similar efficacy.
  • However, differences in pharmacokinetics and toxicity are the main determinants for use in a given patient.
  • Carbamazepine's metabolism follows first-order pharmacokinetics, and the relationship between drug dose, serum levels, and toxicity is linear. 
  • Oxcarbazepine
    • Keto analogue of carbamazepine
    • Advantage of being metabolised (glucuronide conjugation) in a way that avoids an intermediate metabolite associated with some of the side effects of carbamazepine.
    • The potency of enzyme induction is less.
    • Fewer drug interactions than carbamazepine.

Option A: Valproate

  • Valproate is an anticonvulsant that increases Na+ channel inactivation and GABA concentration by inhibiting GABA transaminase.
  • It is generally used for tonic-clonic seizures but can be used for treating partial (focal).
  • It is the drug of choice for absence seizures in India.
  • It is also used for prophylaxis for migraines, myoclonic seizures, and bipolar disorder.

Option B: Pregabalin

  • Pregabalin and the antiepileptic medication gabapentin share molecular similarities, and both treatments act on the alpha2-delta protein, a supporting subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels.
  • Pregabalin treats epilepsy, neuropathic pain, fibromyalgia, restless leg syndrome, opioid withdrawal, and generalised anxiety disorder. Pregabalin has antiallodynic effects as well.
  • Dizziness, tiredness, difficulty concentrating, fuzzy vision, dry mouth, weight gain, and swelling of the hands or feet are the most typical side effects of pregabalin.
  • If these side effects are minor, they can disappear in a few days or weeks.

Option C: Levetiracetam

  • Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic medication that binds to SV2A, a synaptic vesicle integral membrane protein that acts as a positive activator of synaptic vesicle exocytosis.
  • The vesicle-bound neurotransmitter SV2A inhibits glutamate's release, which is an excitatory neurotransmitter.
  • Levetiracetam is commonly used to treat focal seizures, generalised tonic-clonic seizures, and juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.Weight gain, double vision, double dipping, GI distress or nausea, agitation, disorientation, anxiety, and imbalance.
  • Independent of a clinical history of a psychiatric illness, adverse behavioural reactions such as anger, violence, and suicidal thoughts and behaviours are also observed.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male with a history of schizophrenia and allergies to second-generation antipsychotics presents to the psychiatry clinic with complaints of restlessness, tremors and insomnia following a two-week treatment with haloperidol. The patient describes it as the need to move his feet constantly, the inability to sit for a long time, and the need to rock his feet during the daytime if he had to remain seated. The psychiatrist tapers off haloperidol based on the adverse effects and prescribes propranolol regularly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Akathisia

  • The scenario mentioned above is a classic example of haloperidol's extrapyramidal side effects of first-generation antipsychotics.
    • This clinical presentation is consistent with akathisia, characterized by restlessness, tremors, insomnia, inability to sit for a long time, agitation and need to move feet, repeated leg-crossing, weight-shifting and stepping in place.
  • Acute akathisia needs to be differentiated from tardive akathisia.
  • The distinction depends primarily on the temporal relationship between symptoms and drug exposure.
    • Tardive akathisia usually occurs late in the antipsychotic drug treatment with no subjective feelings of motor restlessness and is associated with dyskinesia elsewhere in the body. It should be considered and managed as tardive dyskinesia.
    • Acute akathisia occurs early in the antipsychotic drug treatment and is characterized by a subjective feeling of motor restlessness.
    • The symptomatology is more or less the same in both types.

Option A: Dystonia

  • Dystonia is one of the extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotics, characterized by sustained or intermittent muscle contractions causing abnormal, often repetitive movements, postures, or both; dystonic movements are typically patterned and twisting and may be tremulous.
    • Dystonia is often initiated or worsened by voluntary action and is associated with overflow muscle activation.  

Option B: Restless Leg Syndrome

  • Restless leg syndrome (RLS) is a common sleep-related movement disorder characterized by an often unpleasant urge to move the legs that occurs during periods of inactivity, particularly in the evenings, and is transiently relieved by movement.
    • During sleep, most patients with RLS have characteristic limb movements called periodic limb movements of sleep (PLMS), which may or may not be associated with arousal from sleep.

Option D: Anhedonia

  • Anhedonia is the inability to feel pleasure and is a common symptom of unipolar major depression. It may be social anhedonia or physical anhedonia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man suddenly leaves his home and travels to a different city. He is unable to recall his past and assumes a new identity. However, he is able to maintain his basic self-care. Which of the following best describes the condition this man is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Dissociative Fugue

  • The scenario describes a case of dissociative fugue. The individual suddenly travels away from home, experiences amnesia for their past, and assumes a new identity. The person can still maintain their basic self-care during this period. This pattern aligns with the features of dissociative fugue.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bipolar disorder: it is characterized by episodes of mood swings involving periods of mania and depression. It does not explain the sudden travel, amnesia, and identity change described in the scenario.

Option C - Generalized anxiety disorder: It involves persistent and excessive worrying and anxiety about various aspects of life, but it does not account for the sudden travel, amnesia, and identity change seen in the scenario.

Option D - Antisocial personality disorder: It is characterized by a disregard for the rights of others, deceitfulness, and a lack of empathy, but it does not explain the sudden travel, amnesia, and identity change described in the scenario.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to altered sensorium and hypotension. She has been a known case of major depressive disorder for 2 years. She is being treated with amitriptyline. A cardiac monitor attached shows wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation. Which of the following is the next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:Option A: Sodium bicarbonate

  • TCAs include amitriptyline, nortriptyline, imipramine, amoxapine, doxepin, and desipramine.
  • TCAs block the transporter site for norepinephrine and serotonin, thus increasing their synaptic concentrations.
  • Secondary effects include antagonism at the muscarinic acetylcholine, histamine H1, alpha 1, and alpha 2 receptors.
  • TCAs are used for major depressive disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, agoraphobia, neuropathic pain, childhood enuresis, narcolepsy, nightmare disorder, and post traumatic stress disorder.
  • Side effects resulting from the antagonism include:
    • Constipation
    • Sedation
    • Dry mouth
    • Lightheadedness
    • Blurred vision
    • Delirium
    • Urinary retention
    • Orthostatic hypotension
    • Tachycardia
    • Q-T prolongation
    • Myoclonic twitches and tremors of the tongue
    • Exanthematous rashes
  • It may aggravate narrow-angle glaucoma, which requires emergency treatment.
  • Switch to mania or hypomania can also occur with the use of TCAs.
  • Amoxapine may lead to symptoms of Parkinson’s disease.
  • Clomipramine and amoxapine lower the seizure threshold.
  • TCAs interact with monoamine oxidase inhibitors, beta-blockers, dopamine receptor antagonists, opioids, alcohol, anxiolytics, hypnotics, over-the-counter cold medications, sympathomimetic drugs, oral contraceptives, and nicotine.
  • TCAs should not be taken within 14 days of monoamine oxidase inhibitors administration.
  • Q-T prolongation is one of the side effects of TCAs. It presents as hypotension and tachycardia, and arrhythmias.

.

  • TCAs inhibit fast sodium channels in the His-Purkinje tissue and the myocardium to decrease conduction speed, increase phase 0 depolarization, and prolong the refractory period. This can prolong the QRS interval and cause arrhythmias.
  • TCAs decrease calcium influx into the myocardium and increase vasodilation leading to hypotension.
  • TCA overdose also causes acidemia and a mild increase in serum potassium.
  • Sodium bicarbonate is the most effective agent for managing TCA-induced cardiotoxic effects. It increases serum pH and extracellular sodium. The increased pH modifies TCAs to their neutral form, making them less available to bind to the rapid sodium channels. The elevated extracellular sodium increases the electrochemical gradient across cardiac cells and affects TCAs' ability to bind to the fast sodium channels.
  • Patients refractory to sodium bicarbonate are treated with magnesium or lidocaine.

Option B: Hemodialysis

  • QRS prolongation by TCAs overdose is corrected with sodium bicarbonate.
  • Hemodialysis is ineffective because of the large volume of distribution and high protein binding of TCAs.

Option C: Fomepizole

  • Fomepizole is the treatment of ethylene glycol or methanol poisoning.
  • It does not affect TCAs overdose.

Option D: Flumazenil

  • Flumazenil is a selective GABA receptor antagonist.
  • It is used for the reversal of the sedative effects of benzodiazepines.
  • It has no role in the reversal of TCAs effects.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the primary gains observed in dissociative disorders?

choices.text: Primary gains involve external benefits and advantages.
Primary gains are achieved by keeping internal conflicts outside of awareness.
Primary gains are gains derived from personal achievements and accomplishments.
Primary gains reduce conscious conflicts by producing external symptoms.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Secondary gains are achieved by keeping internal conflicts outside of awareness.

  • Secondary gains are achieved by keeping internal conflicts outside of awareness.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Primary gains involve external benefits and advantages: Primary gains involve internal conflict reduction rather than external benefits.

Option C - Tertiary gains are gains derived from personal achievements and accomplishments: Tertiary gains are derived from significant others rather than personal achievements.

Option D - Primary gains reduce unconscious conflicts by producing external symptoms: Primary gains involve reducing internal conflicts rather than producing external symptoms.

questions.text: What is the process of admission for a person with mental illness who is unable to make treatment decisions and requires high support?
questions.solution:
Correct option C: Supported admission

  • It involves the admission of a person with mental illness who is unable to make treatment decisions and requires high support. A nominated representative can provide consent for admission.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Independent admission: Refers to the voluntary admission of a person with mental illness who has the capacity to make treatment decisions.

Option B - Admission of a minor: Pertains to the process of admitting a minor for mental health care or treatment.

Option D - Emergency admission: It typically applies in urgent situations where immediate intervention is necessary to prevent harm or danger to the individual or others.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to conduct criminal abortion?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ripe fruit of papaya

  • Unripe fruit of papaya used for procuring criminal abortion.

Option B/ C/ D: Saffron/ Seeds of carrot/ Unripe fruit of pineapple

  • Saffron, Seeds of carrot, and unripe fruit of pineapple are used for procuring criminal abortion.

questions.text: Which among the following is a method of direct local violence to conduct criminal abortion?
questions.solution:
Option D: Cupping

  • Cupping is a direct method of local violence for procuring criminal abortion.
  • CUPPING: A form of direct local violence, A mug is turned mouth downwards over a lighted wick and placed on the hypogastrium and the mug is pulled, which results in partial separation of the placenta. This is usually practiced in advanced pregnancy.

Option A/B/C: Abortion stick/ Electricity/ Syringing

  • All these are local methods used in criminal abortion

questions.text: Punishment for seeking prenatal diagnostic facilities for purpose of sex selection is:

choices.text: 1 year imprisonment and fine upto Rs.10000
3–5 years imprisonment and fine Rs.50000 – 1 lakh
1 year imprisonment and fine Rs.50000 – 1 lakh

questions.solution:
Option B: 3-5 years imprisonment and fine Rs.50000 – 1 lakh

  • Punishment for a person seeking prenatal diagnostic facilities for purpose of sex selection is 3–5 years imprisonment and a fine Rs.50000 – 1 lakh.

Learning Objective

  • Section 23(3) PCPNDT ACT [Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, 1994]
  • Punishment for a person seeking prenatal diagnostic facilities for purpose of sex selection is 3–5 years imprisonment and a fine Rs.50000 – 1 lakh.

questions.text: Specimens for toxicological (Chemical) analysis are commonly preserved using a solution, which is easily available and cheap. It can be used for all poisons except corrosive acids. Which among the following is being described here?
questions.solution:
Option D:Saturated solution of common salt

  • Saturated solution of common salt is easily available and cheap and it can be used for all poisons except corrosive acids.

Option A: Rectified spirit

  • 95% pure ethanol is referred to as the rectified spirit, with 5% water.
  • Rectified spirit is the best preservative for chemical analysis.

Option B: Alcohol

  • Rectified spirit contraindicated in: Alcohol, Formaldehyde & Formic acid.

Option C: 10% Formaldehyde

  • 10% Formaldehyde is used as a preservative for chemical analysis

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Naphthalene poisoning?

choices.text: It causes hemolysis in G-6-PD deficiency patients
It causes hypothermia due to formation of naphthylamines
Oily and fatty preparation should be avoided during treatment

questions.solution:
Option B: It causes hypothermia due to formation of naphthylamines

  • It causes hyperthermia due to the formation of naphthylamines, NOT Hypothermia.

Option A: It causes hemolysis in G-6-PD deficiency patients

  • It causes hemolysis with subsequent blocking of renal tubules and hepatic necrosis. Patients with a hereditary deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G-6- PD) in the red cells are more susceptible to hemolysis.

Option C: Oily and fatty preparation should be avoided during treatment

  • Milk, Oily, and fatty meals should be avoided as they facilitate absorption.

Option D: Fatal dose – 2 grams

  • Fatal dose is 2 to 5 gm.

Learning Objective

NAPHTHALENE:

  • Uses: Deodorant in lavatories, as a pesticide in mothballs, and in the dye industry for the manufacture of indigo and certain azo dyes.
  • It causes hemolysis in G-6-PD deficiency patients.
  • It causes hyperthermia due to the formation of naphthylamines.
  • Oily and fatty preparation should be avoided during treatment.
  • Fatal dose: Approximately 2 to 5 grams.
  • Fatal period: Few hours to 2–3 days.
  • Chronic exposure can result in aplastic anemia, hepatic necrosis, and jaundice.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of Schizophrenia presented to the emergency after ingesting a large glass of a pesticide diluted with water in response to auditory hallucinations. He was alert and in no apparent distress but had persistent hypotension and tachycardia that was unresponsive to fluid resuscitation. On day 2 a reddish rash appeared on palms, soles, buttocks, and scrotum. It was documented as "Boiled lobster rash". This is seen in cases of poisoning with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Boric acid:

  • Boiled lobster’s rash is seen in poisoning with Boric acid.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sulphuric acid:

  • Sulphuric acid is most commonly used for Vitriolage (Vitriol Throwing).
  • Discoloration and staining of the skin and clothing (brown or black in sulphuric acid, and yellow in nitric acid).
  • Poison having local action: Sulphuric acid.

Option C - Carbolic acid:

  • Poisoning by carbolic acid is known as carbolism.
  • Chronic poisoning (phenol/carbol marasmus): It is characterized by anorexia, progressive weight loss, excess production of saliva, headache, vertigo, dark urine, and pigmentation of skin and sclera (ochronosis). It was a common occupational disorder of physicians and their assistants during the mid 19th century when carbolic acid sprays were commonly used for antisepsis in operating rooms.
  • Gastric lavage can be done in poisoning with Carbolic acid.
  • Fatal dose: 1–2 gms of phenol, or 25–50 ml of household phenol. Fatal period: 3–4 hrs.

Option D - Formic acid:

  • Action: It has a corrosive action on (coagulation necrosis) on G.I. mucosa. It cause hemolysisis leading to acute renal failure. ATP synthesis is diminished.
  • Fatal Dose: 50 to 200 ml.
  • Postmortem Appearances: Corrosion and blackening of gastric mucosa and pulmonary oedema.
  • Poisoning is suicidal or accidental.

questions.text: A 48 years old chronic alcoholic patient presents in the outdoor department with a complaint of swelling in the groin for one year. On examination, the patient has a swelling in the inguinoscrotal region with positive cough impulse, which is reducible. The deep ring occlusion test is positive. The patient is admitted for hernioplasty. After two days of admission to the surgical ward, there is a complaint of nausea, vomiting, irritability, insomnia, and hallucinations. A psychiatrist's opinion was obtained, and the patient was under treatment. The patient belongs to which ASA class?
questions.solution:
Option C: III

  • The patient has alcohol dependence, and he belongs to ASA class III.
  • A patient with the severe systemic disease is categorised as ASA class 3.
  • In adults, substantive functional limitations like one or more moderate to severe diseases are under ASA 3. Poorly controlled DM or HTN, COPD, morbid obesity (BMI ≥40), active hepatitis, alcohol dependence or abuse, implanted pacemaker, moderate reduction of ejection fraction, ESRD undergoing regularly scheduled dialysis, history (> 3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents.
  • In the pediatric population, uncorrected stable congenital cardiac abnormality, asthma with exacerbation, poorly controlled epilepsy, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, morbid obesity, malnutrition, severe OSA, oncologic state, renal failure, muscular dystrophy, cystic fibrosis and history of organ transplantation is under ASA 3.

Option A: I

  • Normal healthy patient.
  • Healthy, nonsmoking, no or minimal alcohol use, and normal BMI percentile for age.

Option B: II

  • A patient with mild systemic disease.
  • Mild diseases only without substantive functional limitations.

Option D: IV

  • A patient with severe systemic disease that constantly threatens life is categorised as ASA class 4.
  • For example, recent (<3 months) MI, CVA, TIA or CAD/stents, ongoing cardiac ischemia or severe valve dysfunction, severe reduction of ejection fraction, shock, sepsis, DIC, ARDS or ESRD not undergoing regularly scheduled dialysis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female with symptomatic cholelithiasis is planned for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anaesthesia. She had a previous history of lumpectomy in the right breast under general anaesthesia and severe nausea and vomiting in the post-operative ward. The patient was induced with Inj. Propofol 200 mg and endotracheal intubation facilitated with Inj. Succinylcholine. Anaesthesia was maintained with oxygen/nitrous oxide, sevoflurane, and vecuronium. Intraoperative analgesia with 150 micrograms of fentanyl was given. The intraoperative and postoperative course was uneventful. Inj. Tramadol was used for analgesia in the post-operative ward. The patient complained of nausea and vomiting in the postoperative ward, which was treated with Inj. Ondansetron 4mg IV. Which risk factor predicts postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) in this patient?

choices.text: Inj. propofol as the induction agent

questions.solution:
Option A: Female gender

  • The patient has a previous history of having postoperative nausea and vomiting after her lumpectomy under general anaesthesia.
  • She is likely to develop the same complaint this time.
  • Female gender is one of the most important risk factors for postoperative nausea and vomiting.
  • The term postoperative nausea and vomiting is typically used to describe nausea and vomiting or retching in the post-anaesthesia care unit or the immediate 24 postoperative hours. 
  • Other risk factors include non-smokers and post-operative use of opioids.
  • The cause of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is the complex mechanical and chemical interactions between the brain (vomiting centre, chemoreceptor trigger centre and middle ear) and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Treatment of postoperative nausea and vomiting includes anticholinergics, NK 1 receptor antagonists, corticosteroids, antihistamines, phenothiazines, butyrophenones, prokinetics, serotonin receptor antagonists and vasopressors.

Option B: Inj. Propofol as the induction agent

  • Propofol is an induction agent that reduces the chance of postoperative nausea and vomiting.
  • It has strong antiemetic properties.

Option C: Smoking

  • Smokers are at less risk of developing post-operative nausea and vomiting.

Option D: Obesity

  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting are unrelated to the patient's body mass index.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman receives neuraxial opioids for postoperative analgesia. What is the most common side effect she is most likely to experience with this intervention?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pruritus

  • Pruritus is the most common side effect of neuraxial opioids. It may be generalised but is more likely localised to the face, neck or upper thorax.
  • Pruritus is a medical term that means itching. It refers to a feeling or sensation in which the patient wants to scratch on the skin.
  • Pruritus can be painful or irritating and could be localised to one area of the body or spread throughout several rooms.
  • The advantage of nalbuphine is that it is less likely to reverse the analgesic effects of neuraxial opioids. The pruritus is self-limiting, and the severity diminishes in the first hour.
  • Most side effects are dose-dependent and may be more common if the opioid is administered intrathecally.
  • Epidural opioids enhance the analgesic effects of local epidural anaesthetics without prolonging the motor block. Combining local anaesthetic and opioids reduces each drug's dose-related adverse effects.
  • The analgesic benefits of neuraxial opioids must be balanced against the dose-dependent side effects. Lipophilic opioids such as sufentanil are found in lower concentrations in CSF than hydrophilic opioids such as morphine and hydromorphone and are readily absorbed in the systemic circulation. That is the principal analgesic mechanism.

Option A: Respiratory depression

  • The overall risk of respiratory depression after neuraxial opioids is less than 1%.
  • Most side effects are dose-dependent and may be more common if the opioid is administered intrathecally.
  • Respiratory depression is the most potentially dangerous adverse reaction to opioid administration.
  • An overdose of fentanyl can cause serious adverse effects and life-threatening symptoms. When people overdose on fentanyl, their breathing can slow or stop. That can decrease the amount of oxygen reaching the brain; a condition called hypoxia.

Option C: Urinary retention

  • Urinary retention is when the patient cannot empty all the urine from the bladder.
  • The symptoms of urinary retention can range from severe abdominal pain and the inability to urinate to few or no symptoms. Urinary retention results from either a blockage that partially or fully prevents the flow of urine or the bladder's inability to maintain a strong enough force to expel all the urine.
  • It can't always prevent urinary retention, but by staying in tune with the body and bathroom habits, taking medicine as prescribed, strengthening the pelvic floor muscles, and making good dietary choices.

Option D: Sedation

  • One common pain control type is sedation, which relaxes the patient and sometimes makes them fall asleep. Sedation, also known as monitored anaesthesia.
  • An analgesic is a medication used to achieve analgesia or pain relief and is often combined with sedation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female, P2 L2 posted for puerperal sterilization in a family welfare camp in a hilly area. The Bain circuit was used to provide total intravenous anaesthesia with spontaneous ventilation as some major leaks in the circle system carbon dioxide absorber. Carbon dioxide elimination in this patient mainly depends on which factor?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fresh gas flow

  • To eliminate CO2 and prevent rebreathing, these systems depend on a higher rate of fresh gas inflow.
  • Fresh gas flow refers to the mixture of medical gases and volatile anaesthetic agents which is produced by an anaesthetic machine. The flow rate and composition of the fresh gas flow are determined by the anaesthetist.
  • Typically the fresh gas flow emerges from the common gas outlet, a specific outlet on the anaesthetic machine to which the breathing attachment is then connected.
  • Some older forms of breathing attachment, such as the Magill attachment, require high fresh gas flows (e.g. 7 litres/min) to prevent the patient from rebreathing their own expired carbon dioxide. More modern systems, e.g. the circle breathing attachment, use soda lime to absorb carbon dioxide, so that expired gas becomes suitable to re-use. With a very efficient circle system, the fresh gas flow may be reduced to the patient's minimum oxygen requirements (e.g. 250ml/min), plus a little volatile.

Option A: Type of circuit

  • All non-rebreathing (NRB) circuits lack unidirectional valves and soda lime carbon dioxide absorption.
  • The amount of rebreathing is highly dependent on the dilution of expirations with the high fresh gas flow (FGF) in all. Work of breathing is low in all (no unidirectional valves or soda lime granules to create resistance).
  • Minimum FGF in practice, most anaesthetists will provide a minimum of 5 L/min for children up to adults to prevent rebreathing.

Option C: Type of ventilation

  • There are two main types of anaesthesia ventilators: bellows type and piston type. We will discuss each one in depth.
  • Keep in mind, however, that machines can also be classified by what power source each one uses (purely pneumatic, pneumatic and electrical, or purely electrical).
  • Although it is important to know how your anaesthesia ventilator is powered, we prefer to classify them as to their mechanism of action.
  • The third type of anaesthesia ventilator is the servo type. Formerly made by Siemens, they are now produced and marketed by Maquet. Those clinicians with experience in critical care may be familiar with the servo ventilator. These ventilators were modified to deliver volatile agents, and some even had rebreathing capability from an attached carbon dioxide absorber.

Option D: Age of patient

  • Ageing is associated with a progressive loss of functional reserve in all organ systems.
  • However, there is considerable individual variability in the onset and extent of these changes.
  • Nevertheless, even the healthy older adult has reduced physiologic reserve such that organ systems may be compromised during illness and/or surgical stress.
  • Physiologic changes specifically impact anaesthetic care, in part by increasing susceptibility to anaesthetic drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following types of radiation has the highest penetrating power?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Gamma rays

  • Gamma rays are electromagnetic radiation of high energy and frequency. They have no charge and no mass. Gamma rays have the highest penetrating power among the three types of radiation. They can travel long distances through air and can penetrate most materials, including thick layers of lead or concrete. They require dense materials like lead or several meters of concrete to reduce their intensity significantly.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alpha particles: It consist of two protons and two neutrons, and they have a positive charge. They have the lowest penetrating power among the three types of radiation. Due to their relatively large mass and positive charge, they interact strongly with matter and are easily absorbed. They can be stopped by a sheet of paper or a few centimeters of air.

Option B - Beta particles: Beta particles are high-energy electrons or positrons. They have a negative charge and are lighter than alpha particles. Beta particles have a higher penetrating power than alpha particles but lower than gamma rays. They can penetrate a few millimeters to a few centimeters of material, such as aluminum or plastic.

Option D - Neutrons: Neutrons are electrically neutral particles found in the nucleus of an atom. While neutrons are not classified as radiation themselves, they can be emitted in certain radioactive processes. Neutrons have high penetrating power due to their lack of charge, but their ability to penetrate depends on their energy level. Higher energy neutrons can penetrate materials more effectively, while lower energy neutrons are more easily absorbed.

In summary, Radiation can be classified into three main types: alpha particles, beta particles, and gamma rays. Each type has different properties, including their ability to penetrate matter.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident with multiple injuries, blood loss and severe abdominal pain suggestive of organ injury. What are the four points of probe placement in focused abdominal sonograms for trauma (FAST)?

choices.text: SUBXIPHOID, UMBILICAL REGION, PLEURAL CAVITY, COSTOPHRENIC ANGLE
HEPATO RENAL POUCH, SPLENORENAL POUCH, PELVIS, UMBLICAL REGION
SPLENORENAL POUCH, PELVIS, UPPER CHEST , PLEURAL CAVITY

questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A SUBXIPHOID, HEPATORENAL, SPLENORENAL, PLEURAL CAVITY

EXPLANATION: eFAST

  • Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) examination is a bedside screening tool to identify free intraperitoneal, pleural and pericardial fluid. It is a limited ultrasound examination with 6 views.

  • The average time to perform a complete FAST examination is 2–4 minutes.

  • The four points of probe placement in focused abdominal sonogram for trauma (FAST) in thoracoabdominal trauma:

 

1) Subxiphoid To look for pericardial fluid & 4 chamber view of the heart
2) Right intercostal oblique view To look for right pleural effusion
3) Right coronal view To look for free fluid in Morrison’s pouch and paracolic gutter
4) Left intercostal oblique view To look for left pleural effusion, free view fluid in subphrenic space
5) Left coronal view For the left paracolic gutter
6) Pelvic (longitudinal/ transverse) views To detect free fluid in The cul-de-sac

 OPTION B: SUBXIPHOID, UMBILICAL REGION, PLEURAL CAVITY, COSTOPHRENIC ANGLE

  • THE UMBILICAL REGION IS NOT CHECKED IN FAST

OPTION C: HEPATO RENAL POUCH, SPLENORENAL POUCH, PELVIS, UMBILICAL REGION

  • THE UMBILICAL REGION IS NOT CHECKED IN FAST

OPTION D: SPLENORENAL POUCH, PELVIS, UPPER CHEST , PLEURAL CAVITY

  • UPPER CHEST IS NOT CHECKED IN FAST

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding NCCT (Non-Contrast CT) and CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT)?

choices.text: NCCT is used for diffused lung conditions, while CECT is used for space-occupying lesions.
In NCCT, the aorta appears grey, while in CECT, it appears white due to the iodinated contrast.
NCCT is preferred for fractures, except stress fractures, while CECT is preferred for inflammatory or infectious pathology.
Both NCCT and CECT cannot visualize acute hemorrhage

questions.solution:
