Correct Option C: NCCT is preferred for fractures, except stress fractures, while CECT is preferred for inflammatory or infectious pathology

  • NCCT (Non-Contrast CT) and CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT) are two different types of CT scans that serve different purposes in clinical practice.
  • NCCT is preferred for fractures (excluding stress fractures) because it provides excellent visualization of bone structures. On the other hand, CECT is preferred for evaluating inflammatory or infectious pathology, as the contrast agent helps in highlighting areas of increased vascularity or abnormal enhancement.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - NCCT is used for diffused lung conditions, while CECT is used for space-occupying lesions: The statement in option A is not accurate. NCCT is typically used for conditions such as bone fractures, renal stones (calcification), and acute hemorrhage. On the other hand, CECT is commonly employed for the visualization of space-occupying lesions, such as metastasis.

Option B - In NCCT, the aorta appears grey, while in CECT, it appears white due to the iodinated contrast: In NCCT, the aorta appears white due to its intrinsic density on CT, while in CECT, the iodinated contrast agent enhances the blood vessels, making them appear brighter or white.

Option D - Both NCCT and CECT can visualize acute hemorrhage, but chronic hemorrhage is better visualized with MRI: The statement in option D is not accurate. Both NCCT and CECT can visualize acute hemorrhage, but chronic hemorrhage, which involves the deposition of iron or hemosiderin, is better visualized with MRI.

questions.text: What is the principle behind an ultrasound machine/ scan?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Change in frequency

  • The Doppler effect in ultrasound involves the measurement of changes in the frequency of ultrasound waves reflected from moving objects, such as blood cells or tissues. The frequency shift provides information about the velocity and direction of blood flow or movement of structures within the body.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Attenuation of sound waves: It refers to the gradual decrease in the intensity or energy of sound waves as they propagate through a medium. While attenuation is a characteristic of ultrasound waves, it is not the principle behind the Doppler effect.

Option C - Absorption of sound waves: It refers to the process in which sound waves are absorbed by tissues, leading to a decrease in their energy. Although sound waves can be absorbed by tissues in ultrasound imaging, absorption is not the principle behind the Doppler effect.

Option D - Reverberation of sound waves: Reverberation occurs when sound waves bounce back and forth between surfaces, causing multiple echoes. While reverberation is a phenomenon encountered in ultrasound imaging, it is not the principle behind the Doppler effect.

questions.text: Psoriasis is strongly associated with certain human leukocyte antigen (HLA) genes. Among the following, which HLA gene is most commonly linked to psoriasis susceptibility?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: HLA-B27

  • HLA-B27 is the HLA gene most commonly linked to psoriasis susceptibility. Human leukocyte antigens (HLAs) are proteins that play a crucial role in the immune system, as they help the body recognize self from non-self. Specific HLA genes have been found to be associated with various autoimmune diseases, including psoriasis.
  • HLA-B27 has been strongly associated with psoriasis, as well as other conditions like ankylosing spondylitis. While the exact mechanisms linking HLA-B27 to psoriasis are not fully understood, it is believed that certain variations in the HLA-B27 gene may increase the risk of developing psoriasis by triggering an autoimmune response against the skin cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: HLA-A

  • HLA-A has not been strongly linked to psoriasis susceptibility. While HLA genes in general are involved in the immune system's functioning, HLA-A is not a major player in psoriasis development.

Option C: HLA-DRB1 

  • HLA-DRB1 is associated with certain autoimmune diseases, but it is not the primary HLA gene commonly linked to psoriasis. Instead, it is more commonly associated with diseases like rheumatoid arthritis.

Option D: HLA-DQB1

  • HLA-DQB1 is also involved in the immune system's response, but it is not the most commonly linked HLA gene for psoriasis susceptibility. It has been associated with conditions like celiac disease.

questions.text: What is a "Woronoff Ring" associated with in the context of psoriasis?

choices.text: Excessive scratching and rubbing in psoriatic plaques

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Excessive scratching and rubbing in psoriatic plaques

  • A "Woronoff Ring," also known as the "Auspitz Sign," is a clinical finding associated with psoriasis. It refers to the phenomenon where pinpoint bleeding occurs after removing scales or scratching the surface of psoriatic plaques.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Skin infection secondary to psoriasis:

  • While psoriasis can increase the risk of skin infections due to compromised skin barrier function, a "Woronoff Ring" is not specifically related to a secondary infection.

Option C: Reverse Koebner phenomenon in psoriasis 

  • The Koebner phenomenon is the development of new skin lesions at sites of trauma or injury. However, the "Woronoff Ring" is not related to the reverse Koebner phenomenon.

Option D: Gradual resolution of psoriatic lesions:

  • The "Woronoff Ring" does not indicate the resolution of psoriatic lesions. Instead, it is an immediate response observed during examination when scales are removed or the psoriatic plaque is disrupted.

questions.text: A 30-year-old laboratory worker develops a rash on her hands after handling various chemicals in the lab. Upon examination, the rash presents as erythematous, edematous, and with vesicles. Patch testing reveals a positive reaction to specific chemicals she handled. Which of the following statements accurately differentiates between irritant contact dermatitis (ICD) and allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) in this patient's case?

choices.text: The positive patch test reaction suggests ICD, as ACD does not involve delayed hypersensitivity reactions.
The presence of vesicles and a positive patch test indicates ACD, which is exclusively caused by an allergic reaction to irritants.
The development of vesicles supports ACD, while ICD typically presents with a dry, scaly rash.
Both ICD and ACD can cause vesicles, but the positive patch test confirms ACD, involving a delayed hypersensitivity response.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Both ICD and ACD can cause vesicles, but the positive patch test confirms ACD, involving a delayed hypersensitivity response:

  • In this scenario, the patient's presentation of erythematous, edematous rash with vesicles is characteristic of both irritant contact dermatitis (ICD) and allergic contact dermatitis (ACD). Both types of contact dermatitis can lead to the formation of vesicles as part of the inflammatory response.
  • However, the key difference lies in the patch testing results. Patch testing is used to identify the specific allergens responsible for allergic contact dermatitis (ACD). If a patient shows a positive reaction to specific chemicals they handled during the patch testing, it confirms the diagnosis of ACD. A positive patch test indicates a delayed hypersensitivity response, which is characteristic of ACD. This means the rash is caused by the immune system's delayed reaction to an allergen, leading to inflammation and the development of vesicles.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The positive patch test reaction suggests ICD, as ACD does not involve delayed hypersensitivity reactions:

  • This statement is incorrect because ACD, in fact, involves a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to allergens. A positive patch test, as seen in the scenario, confirms the diagnosis of ACD, not ICD.

Option B - The presence of vesicles and a positive patch test indicates ACD, which is exclusively caused by an allergic reaction to irritants:

  • This statement is incorrect because ACD is caused by an allergic reaction to allergens, not irritants. ICD is caused by direct exposure to irritants, but ACD involves an allergic reaction to specific allergens.

Option C - The development of vesicles supports ACD, while ICD typically presents with a dry, scaly rash:

  • This statement is incorrect because both ACD and ICD can cause vesicles. The presence of vesicles alone does not distinguish between the two types of contact dermatitis. Additionally, the description of ICD as a "dry, scaly rash" is not accurate as ICD can also present with erythematous, edematous, and vesicular features.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with multiple, well-demarcated, hyperpigmented, rough-surfaced papules and plaques on his face, neck, and chest. The lesions have slowly developed over the past few years, and the patient reports no pain or itching associated with them. Whatis the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hyperpigmented, well-demarcated papules or plaques:

  • Seborrheic keratosis (SK) is a common benign skin condition characterized by the development of hyperpigmented, well-demarcated papules or plaques on the skin. These lesions typically have a rough or warty surface and are light to dark brown in color. They are usually painless and may vary in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters.
  • The term "Sign of Lesser-Trelat" refers to the sudden appearance or eruption of multiple seborrheic keratoses over a short period of time. This phenomenon is considered to be a potential marker of an underlying internal malignancy, and it may indicate the presence of an occult cancer. However, it is essential to remember that not all cases of seborrheic keratosis represent a paraneoplastic manifestation, and most SKs are benign and unrelated to cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sudden onset of painful blisters:

  • This description is not characteristic of seborrheic keratosis. SKs are typically painless and do not present as blisters.

Option B - Raised, scaly, and erythematous patches:

  • This description is not typical of seborrheic keratosis. SKs have a rough or warty surface, but they are not usually erythematous (red) or scaly.

Option D - Target-shaped lesions with central clearing:

  • This description is not consistent with seborrheic keratosis. Target-shaped lesions with central clearing are often seen in conditions like erythema multiforme, but they are not a typical feature of SK.

questions.text: What is the name of the anatomical structure between the tragus and the crus of the helix which is devoid of cartilage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Incisura terminalis

  • The incisura terminalis is an area devoid of cartilage between the tragus and the beginning of the helix on the pinna. It is chosen as a site of incision in endaural surgeries (Lempert endaural incision).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cavum concha: Cavum concha refers to the largest depression on the pinna, which is surrounded by the antitragus, tragus, and anti-helix.

Option B - Triangular fossa: The triangular fossa is a triangular depression located above the cavum concha on the pinna.

Option D - Lobule of the ear: The lobule of the ear is the lower part of the pinna that lacks cartilage. It contains a higher amount of fat and is sometimes used as a site for fat graft harvest.

questions.text: A 2-week-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his parents. He was born to a 21-year-old gravida 1 para 1 mother who admits she did not make any prenatal appointments. The infant was delivered in a home with the help of a midwife. According to the mother, it was a difficult delivery. She states that "he may have suffered some injury during birth ."Upon examination, everything is unremarkable except the nose has a deformity. Which of the following statements is false regarding the nasal deformity shown in the image?

choices.text: Can also be due to birth injuries

questions.solution:
Option C: Known as saddle nose

The picture shows a crooked nose deformity.

  • In the crooked nose, the midline of the dorsum from the frontonasal angle to the tip is curved in a C- or S-shaped manner.
  • In a deviated nose, the midline is straight but deviated to one side
  • Usually, these deformities are traumatic in origin.
  • Injuries sustained during birth, neonatal period, or childhood but not immediately recognized will also develop into these deformities with the growth of the nose.
  • Deviated or crooked nose can be corrected by rhinoplasty or septorhinoplasty.
  • The aim of these operations is to correct not only the outer appearance of the nose but also its function.

Option A: Mostly of traumatic origin

  • The crooked nose deformity is mostly of traumatic origin.
  • Hence it pertains to the criteria of crooked nose deformity, making it an incorrect answer.

Option B: Can also be due to birth injuries

  • The crooked nose deformity shown in the image is due to birth injuries.
  • Hence, this is a true statement regarding crooked nose deformity, making it an incorrect choice for this question.

Option D: Requires septorhinoplasty

  • Crooked nose deformity requires septorhinoplasty for correction.
  • Hence this statement is true regarding crooked nose deformity making it the wrong choice for this question.

questions.text: The opening of the eustachian tube is located in which part of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Protympanum

  • The protympanum refers to the part of the middle ear anteriorly which has the opening of the eustachian tube. It is in this region that the eustachian tube connects the middle ear to the nasopharynx, allowing for the equalization of pressure and ventilation of the middle ear.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Epitympanum: The epitympanum refers to the part of the middle ear that is lying against the pars flaccida or the attic.

Option B - Mesotympanum: The mesotympanum refers to the part of the middle ear that lies against the pars tensa.

Option C - Hypotympanum: The hypotympanum refers to the part of the middle ear that lies below the level of the annulus.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman presents to the physician because of a 5-month history of weakness on the left side of her face, loss of taste, and dryness and redness of her left eye. She has no history of serious illness. Physical examination shows an inability to puff the left cheek and close her left eye. An MRI of the brain shows a contrast-enhancing mass in the posterior fossa. Which of the following statement is correct regarding facial nerve landmarks if this patient underwent surgery for his condition?

1. Tympanomastoid suture -Nerve lies 6–8 mm deep to this suture

2. Styloid process-The nerve crosses medial to the styloid process

3. Cartilaginous pointer - Nerve lies 1 cm deep and slightly anterior and inferior to pointer

4. Posterior belly of digastric- Nerve is found to lie between it and the styloid process
questions.solution:
Option A: 1, 3, and 4 are correct

  • It is a case of parotid gland tumor, which require parotidectomy for its treatment. 
  • Facial Nerve Landmarks in parotid surgery:
  • Cartilaginous pointer: Nerve lies 1 cm deep and slightly anterior and inferior to a pointer. A cartilaginous pointer is a sharp triangular piece of the cartilage of pinna and "points" to the nerve
  • Tympanomastoid suture: Nerve lies 6–8 mm deep to this suture (most reliable marker)
  • Styloid process: The nerve crosses laterally to the styloid process.
  • Posterior belly of digastric: If the posterior belly of the digastric muscle is traced backward along its upper border to its attachment to the digastric groove, a nerve is found to lie between it and the styloid process.

Option B: 1, 2, and 3 are correct 

  • It is an incorrect option because statement 2 is a false statement.
  • In statement 2, it is mentioned that the facial nerve crosses the medial to styloid process, which is false.
  • The facial nerve crosses laterally to the styloid process.

Option C: 1, 2, 3, and 4 are correct

  •  It is an incorrect option because statement 2 is a false statement.
  • In statement 2, it is mentioned that the facial nerve crosses the medial to styloid process, which is false.
  • The facial nerve crosses laterally to the styloid process.

Option D: Only 1 and 2 are correct

  • It is an incorrect option because statement 2 is a false statement.
  • In statement 2, it is mentioned that the facial nerve crosses the medial to styloid process, which is false.
  • The facial nerve crosses laterally to the styloid process.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with severe ear pain. On examination, the external auditory canal appears normal. The patient complains of dental pain on the lower left molar. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the referred otalgia in this patient?

choices.text: Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.solution:
The correct answer is: B) Auriculotemporal nerve

Explanation for all the given options:

A) Lesser occipital nerve: The lesser occipital nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus and is not directly involved in referred otalgia.

B) Auriculotemporal nerve: This is the correct answer. The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). It provides sensory innervation to the external ear and the temporal region. Referred otalgia occurs when pain originating from the lower molar travels along the auriculotemporal nerve to reach the external ear, leading to the perception of ear pain.

C) Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve: The tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) is not primarily responsible for referred otalgia in this context.

D) Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) provides sensory innervation to the pharyngeal region and posterior third of the tongue. It is not directly responsible for referred otalgia in this scenario.

In summary, the referred otalgia in this patient is likely due to the involvement of the auriculotemporal nerve, which transmits pain from the lower molar to the external ear.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with cervical spondylosis complains of chronic ear pain. The pain is located in the area of the external ear. Which nerves are responsible for the referred otalgia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Lesser occipital and auriculotemporal nerves

  • In this case, the patient has cervical spondylosis, which can lead to referred otalgia. Cervical spondylosis at the level of C2 and C3 can affect the lesser occipital and greater auricular nerves, resulting in ear pain. Therefore, option A (Lesser occipital and auriculotemporal nerves) is the correct answer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old came to ENT OPD with complaints of mild change in voice with no airway obstruction or aspiration. The physician comes to a conclusion that it is due to the paralysis of the nerve which supplies all muscle except cricothyroid and paralysis of this nerve leads to impaired abduction of the cord. Which nerve is the sensory innervation to the larynx below the level of the vocal cords?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Recurrent laryngeal nerve

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve gives sensory nerve supply to the larynx below the vocal cords and supplies all the larynx muscles except the cricothyroid muscle.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Internal laryngeal nerve: Is incorrect as it supplies sensory innervation above the level of the vocal cords.

Option B- External laryngeal nerve: Is incorrect as it supplies motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle.

Option C- Superior laryngeal nerve: Is incorrect as it supplies sensory innervation above the level of the vocal cords.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with hoarseness of voice following a recent thyroid surgery. On examination, her vocal cords are found to be immobile. What is the most likely cause of her vocal cord paralysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Surgical trauma

  • In this clinical scenario, the most likely cause of the patient's vocal cord paralysis is surgical trauma. During thyroid surgery, the right recurrent laryngeal nerve has a higher possibility of getting injured than the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. The recurrent laryngeal nerves innervate the muscles that control vocal cord movement, and injury to these nerves can lead to vocal cord paralysis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Idiopathic: Idiopathic vocal cord paralysis refers to cases where the cause of the paralysis is unknown. However, in this case, the patient has a clear history of thyroid surgery, making surgical trauma a more probable cause.

Option B- Malignancy: Malignant tumors can compress or invade the recurrent laryngeal nerves, causing vocal cord paralysis. While malignancy is a possible cause, the surgical trauma in this patient is a more likely reason for the vocal cord paralysis based on the clinical history provided.

Option D- Infections: Viral or bacterial infections can rarely lead to vocal cord paralysis, but in this case, there is no mention of any infection in the provided history. Therefore, surgical trauma remains the most likely cause.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about eyelids is incorrect?

choices.text: The horizontal length of the lid is around 28-30mm
Blepharophimosis refers to a decrease in the vertical gap between open eyelids
The lateral canthus is normally 2mm above the medial canthus
Mongoloid slant refers to a lateral canthus that is more than 2mm above the medial canthus

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Blepharophimosis refers to a decrease in the vertical gap between open eyelids:

  • Blepharophimosis refers to a decrease in the vertical gap between open eyelids. This statement is incorrect. Blepharophimosis actually refers to a decrease in the horizontal length of the lid, not the vertical gap.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The horizontal length of the lid is around 28-30mm: This statement is correct, as mentioned in the information provided.

Option C -The lateral canthus is normally 2mm above the medial canthus: This statement is correct, as stated in the information.

Option D - Mongoloid slant refers to a lateral canthus that is more than 2mm above the medial canthus: This statement is correct, as mentioned in the information.

Therefore, the correct answer is B) Blepharophimosis refers to a decrease in the vertical gap between open eyelids.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with excessive skin in the upper eyelid area, which is mimicking ptosis. This condition is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Dermatochalasia:

  • Dermatochalasia is the correct answer. It refers to the excessive skin condition above the subcutaneous tissue, which can mimic ptosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Blepharospasm: Blepharospasm refers to involuntary eyelid closure or blinking due to spasms of the orbicularis oculi muscle. It is not related to excessive skin in the upper eyelid.

Option C - Lagophthalmos: Lagophthalmos is the inability to fully close the eye. It is not related to excessive skin in the upper eyelid.

Option D - Orbital septum: The orbital septum is a thin connective tissue that fills the space between the supraorbital or infraorbital margins and posterior border of tarsus. It is not related to excessive skin in the upper eyelid.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient complains of progressive peripheral vision loss. Upon examination, optic disc pallor and attenuation of blood vessels are observed. Which layer of the retina is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Ganglion cell layer

  • Ganglion cell layer: The ganglion cell layer is responsible for transmitting visual information from the photoreceptors to the optic nerve. Damage to this layer can result in visual field defects and optic disc abnormalities, which are consistent with the patient's symptoms of peripheral vision loss and optic disc pallor.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Inner plexiform layer: The inner plexiform layer is involved in the processing and transmission of signals between the bipolar cells and ganglion cells. While damage to this layer can affect visual function, it is less likely to be the primary cause of progressive peripheral vision loss and optic disc changes observed in the patient.

Option C - Inner nuclear layer: The inner nuclear layer contains the cell bodies of bipolar cells, horizontal cells, and amacrine cells. Dysfunction or damage to this layer may result in visual impairments, but it is not typically associated with progressive peripheral vision loss and optic disc pallor.

Option D - Outer plexiform layer: The outer plexiform layer is involved in the transmission of signals between the photoreceptor cells and bipolar cells. Although abnormalities in this layer can impact visual function, they are unlikely to be the primary cause of the specific symptoms described in the patient.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with moderate myopia is seeking refractive surgery. Which laser procedure is the most appropriate for correcting the patient's myopia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Femto-laser:

  • The most appropriate laser procedure for correcting the patient's myopia is the Femto-laser. The Femto-laser, also known as femtosecond laser, is commonly used in refractive surgeries to reshape the cornea and correct refractive errors. It allows for precise and controlled corneal tissue removal, resulting in accurate corneal reshaping to achieve the desired refractive correction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nd: YAG laser: The Nd: YAG laser is not commonly used for corneal refractive surgeries or the correction of myopia. It is primarily used for posterior capsulotomy and peripheral iridotomy in specific eye conditions. Therefore, it is not the most appropriate option for correcting myopia in this scenario.

Option B - Excimer laser: The excimer laser is a widely used laser in refractive surgeries and is specifically designed for corneal reshaping to correct refractive errors, including myopia. It is capable of precise tissue removal and reshaping of the cornea. However, in this scenario, the Femto-laser is a more appropriate choice as it provides additional advantagesof flapless surgery and performing specific procedures like SMILE (Small Incision Lenticule Extraction). 

Option C - Argon laser: The argon laser is a photocoagulative laser primarily used for retinal photocoagulation used in treating various retinal conditions, such as diabetic retinopathy and retinal vascular disorders.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient complains of floaters and blurred vision in both eyes. On examination, you observe a retrolental flare and inflammatory exudates over the pars plana. Which term best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Intermediate uveitis

  • In the given scenario, the patient's symptoms of floaters and blurred vision, along with the findings of  retrolental flare and inflammatory exudates over the pars plana which, are indicative of intermediate uveitis. Intermediate uveitis is also known as pars planitis, as it primarily involves the inflammation of the pars plana region of the eye. It is characterized by inflammation in the vitreous, peripheral retina, and the adjacent structures.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Anterior uveitis: Anterior uveitis, also known as iridocyclitis, primarily involves inflammation of the iris and the ciliary body. It typically presents with symptoms such as eye redness, pain, and photophobia. In the given scenario, the involvement of the pars plana  suggests a more posterior location of inflammation, ruling out anterior uveitis as the correct answer.

Option C - Posterior uveitis: Posterior uveitis involves inflammation of the choroid and retina. It typically presents with symptoms such as decreased vision, central scotoma and patches of choroiditis.

Option D - Pan uveitis: Pan uveitis refers to inflammation involving all three anatomical regions of the uvea, namely the anterior segment (iris and ciliary body), the intermediate segment (pars plana), and the posterior segment (choroid and retina).

questions.text: A 30-day-old baby presents with excessive lacrimation, corneal edema, photophobia, enlargement of the eye with buphthalmos, and Haab striae. The child is agitated and restless. He has a large hazy cornea in both eyes. His lacrimal system is normal. On gonioscopy, the iris has a scalloped appearance. The trabecular meshwork appears unusually thick and seems to be covered by a membrane. What is the treatment of choice for this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Trabeculectomy + Trabeculotomy

  • Trabeculectomy is a type of glaucoma surgery performed on the eye that creates a new pathway for fluid inside the eye to be drained.
  • Trabeculotomy removes barriers to aqueous outflow from a congenital angle deformity. 

Option A: Trabeculectomy + MMC

  • Mitomycin C (MMC) is an antimetabolite applied between the sclera and conjunctiva during the initial stages of a trabeculectomy to prevent excessive post-operative scarring and thus reduce the risk of failure. It is not used to treat congenital glaucoma.

Option C: Goniotomy

  • It is not the treatment of choice in the current situation, as the cornea is hazy, that the angle cannot be seen well enough for goniotomy under direct visualization.

Option D: Iridotomy

  • Iridotomy is not used to treat congenital glaucoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with dry eyes and discomfort. Upon examination, you notice an insufficient tear film on the ocular surface. Which of the following is most likely disrupted in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Blinking mechanism:

  • In this scenario, the patient is experiencing dry eyes and discomfort, indicating an insufficient tear film on the ocular surface. The blinking mechanism plays a crucial role in tear distribution, removal of debris, and protection of the cornea. During blinking, tears are evenly spread across the ocular surface, forming a tear film that provides lubrication. If there is a disruption in the blinking mechanism, such as inadequate or incomplete blinking, it can lead to insufficient tear distribution and accumulation of debris on the ocular surface, resulting in dry eyes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tear drainage: Tear drainage refers to the removal of excess tears from the ocular surface. While tear drainage is important for maintaining the proper tear film thickness, it is not the primary cause of insufficient tear film in this case.

Option B - Tear production: Tear production refers to the process of producing an adequate quantity of tears. Although decreased tear production can contribute to dry eyes, the specific scenario mentioned does not provide information suggesting a disruption in tear production.

Option D - Tear composition: Tear composition refers to the components and quality of tears. While tear composition can influence tear film stability and ocular surface health, it is not the most likely cause of insufficient tear film in this patient.

questions.text: Herpes zoster along the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve is a rare condition caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus that resides within the trigeminal ganglion after the primary infection of chickenpox. Mark the incorrect statement about the condition.

choices.text: The most specific nerve involved is the lacrimal nerve
The most common nerve involved is the Frontal nerve
The painful rash typically involves specific dermatome supplied by branches of the trigeminal nerve

questions.solution:
Option A: The most specific nerve involved is the lacrimal nerve

  • The nasociliary nerve is the most important nerve involved in herpes zoster infection.
  • HERPES ZOSTER OPHTHALMICUS
    • Most specific nerve involved: Nasociliary branch of the Frontal division of the Trigeminal Nerve.
    • H/o immunosuppression to be ruled out.

Option B:The most common nerve involved is the Frontal nerve

  • Causative agent: Varicella zoster infection
  • Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus) occurs when a shingles outbreak affects the facial nerve near one of the ears.
  •  In addition to the painful shingles rash, Ramsay Hunt syndrome can cause facial paralysis and hearing loss in the affected ear.
  • Most commonly, the rash occurs in a single dermatome around the body's left or right side. In other cases, the rash occurs on one side of the face.
  •  Shingles on the face can affect the eye and cause vision loss.

Option C: The painful rash typically involving specific dermatome supplied by branches of the trigeminal nerve

  • The painful dermatomal rash typically involves the dermatome supplied by the trigeminal nerve.
  • Trigeminal herpes zoster with Ramsay Hunt syndrome may produce cutaneous, intraoral, and otic vesicles, hearing loss, and mild facial palsy.
  • Herpes zoster of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve may begin with a toothache during its prodromal stage, followed by its vesicular eruption.

Option D: Hutchinson's Sign suggests corneal involvement

  • Hutchinson Sign: Involvement of nasociliary nerve, which produces lesions on the tip of the nose and suggests corneal involvement.
  • It reflects zoster involvement of the first branch of the trigeminal nerve and is concerning for herpes zoster ophthalmicus.
  • Herpes zoster vesicles may present as papular lesions or macular vesicles on an erythematous base.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents with localized bone pain in the long bone of the lower limb. Radiographic imaging reveals a lytic lesion with aggressive periosteal reaction. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Ewing's sarcoma. Based on the provided information, which part of the bone is typically involved in Ewing's sarcoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Diaphysis

  • The diaphysis is the central shaft of a long bone, between the metaphysis and the epiphysis. Both Ewing's sarcoma and osteosarcoma can involve the diaphysis. In the case of Ewing's sarcoma, the diaphysis is the most common site of involvement.

Incorrect Options:

Option - A Epiphysis: The epiphysis refers to the ends of long bones, where they articulate with other bones. Ewing's sarcoma and osteosarcoma typically do not involve the epiphysis. These tumors are more commonly found in the diaphysis or metaphysis of long bones.

Option - B Metaphysis: The metaphysis is the region of a long bone located between the diaphysis (shaft) and the epiphysis (end). Ewing's sarcoma can occasionally involve the metaphysis, although it more commonly affects the diaphysis. Osteosarcoma also primarily affects the metaphysis, especially in the long bones of the extremities.

Option - D Cortex: The cortex refers to the outer layer of a bone. Ewing's sarcoma and osteosarcoma can extend into the cortex as they progress, but they primarily arise from the medullary cavity within the bone and involve the internal structures rather than the outer cortex.

It's important to note that the exact location of these tumors can vary, and in some cases, they may involve multiple parts of the bone. However, based on typical presentations, Ewing's sarcoma commonly involves the diaphysis, while osteosarcoma primarily affects the metaphysis of long bones.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female twisted her ankle while playing sports. She experienced immediate pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight on the affected foot. Physical examination reveals tenderness and swelling on inversion of a plantar-flexed foot. Ankle range of motion is limited and painful. X-ray shows no fracture. Which ligament is most commonly injured in an ankle sprain?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Anterior talofibular ligament 

  • This ligament is the most commonly injured in ankle sprains. It connects the talus bone to the fibula on the lateral (outer) aspect of the ankle. It plays a crucial role in stabilizing the ankle joint during inversion movements.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Posterior talofibular ligament: This ligament is located on the back of the ankle and connects the talus bone to the fibula. It is less commonly injured in ankle sprains compared to the anterior talofibular ligament.

Option C - Calcaneofibular ligament: This ligament connects the calcaneus bone (heel bone) to the fibula on the lateral aspect of the ankle. It is also commonly involved in ankle sprains, especially when the injury involves a greater degree of inversion.

Option D - Deltoid ligament: The deltoid ligament is located on the medial (inner) aspect of the ankle and connects the tibia bone to the talus and calcaneus bones. It is less commonly injured in ankle sprains and is more commonly involved in ankle instability or fractures.

In summary, while all of these ligaments can be injured in an ankle sprain, the anterior talofibular ligament is the most commonly affected ligament. It is important to note that the specific ligaments involved may vary depending on the mechanism and severity of the injury.

questions.text: Bone resorption is a process by which osteoclasts break down the tissue in bones and release the minerals, resulting in a transfer of calcium from bone tissue to the blood. Which marker is associated with bone resorption?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Hydroxyproline 

  • Hydroxyproline is a marker associated with bone resorption. It is a component of collagen, the main protein in bone. Increased levels of hydroxyproline in the urine or blood can indicate increased breakdown of collagen and bone resorption.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteocalcin: Osteocalcin is a marker associated with bone formation rather than bone resorption. It is a protein produced by osteoblasts, the cells responsible for bone formation.

Option B - ALP (alkaline phosphatase): ALP is an enzyme found in various tissues, including bone. While elevated ALP levels can indicate increased bone activity, it is not a specific marker for bone resorption.

Option D - Pyridinoline: Pyridinoline is another marker associated with bone resorption. It is a cross-linking compound found in the collagen of bone. Elevated levels of pyridinoline in the urine or blood indicate increased bone breakdown and resorption.

In summary, among the given choices, hydroxyproline and pyridinoline are markers specifically associated with bone resorption. Osteocalcin is associated with bone formation, while ALP is a more general marker of bone activity.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is NOT a known cause of exaggerated lumbar lordosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Scoliosis

  • Scoliosis is a condition characterized by an abnormal sideways curvature of the spine. It typically affects the thoracic or thoracolumbar region rather than the lumbar spine. While scoliosis can cause abnormal spinal curvatures, it is not directly associated with exaggerated lumbar lordosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Spondylolisthesis: Spondylolisthesis is a condition where one vertebra slips forward over the vertebra below it. It can disrupt the normal curvature of the lumbar spine and contribute to exaggerated lumbar lordosis.

Option B - Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by decreased bone density and strength, making the bones more susceptible to fractures. While it may not directly cause exaggerated lumbar lordosis, it can weaken the vertebrae and contribute to postural changes that can lead to an exaggerated curvature.

Option C - Achondroplasia: Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder that affects bone growth and leads to dwarfism. Individuals with achondroplasia often have an exaggerated lumbar lordosis as part of their skeletal abnormalities.

In summary, while spondylolisthesis, osteoporosis, and achondroplasia are known causes of exaggerated lumbar lordosis, scoliosis is not typically associated with an exaggerated inward curvature of the lumbar spine.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the growth pattern of a particular bacterial strain that caused a respiratory disease outbreak in children in rural Venezuela. The bacteria are found to be able to grow in a specialized culture that contains sheep blood, cystine, and potassium tellurite; the colonies are black and have a shining surface. The investigator wants to examine the biophysical properties of living bacterial cells. Which is the specialized type of microscope which enables quantitative measurement of the chemical constituents of cells?
questions.solution:
Option B: Interference microscope

  • Interference microscope enables
    • Examine a living cell's biophysical properties.
    • Stiffness.
    • Time-dependent deformability.
    • Mass.
  • Does not require labeling with fluorescent proteins or optically active dyes.
  • Both cultured cell lines and material derived from whole organisms can be used.

Option A: Darkfield microscope

  • The background is dark with darkfield condensers.
  • The reflected light is used.
  • Visualize spirochetes.

Option C: Phase Contrast Microscope

  • It is used to visualize the living cells by creating a difference in contrast between the cells and water.
  • Converts slight differences in refractive index and cell density into easily detectable variations in light intensity.
  • It is useful for studying.

Option D: Fluorescence microscopy

  • When UV rays are absorbed into fluorescent substances and reflected, the wavelength of invisible light increases & becomes luminous.

Stains:

  • Auramine / Rhodamine for → MTB.
  • Calcofluor White for → Fungus.
  • Acridine orange for → Malarial parasite

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks gestation, is admitted to the hospital in active labour. Her current pregnancy has been complicated by iron deficiency anaemia treated with iron tablets. She has received routine prenatal care but has not been tested for group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization. An infection complicated the pregnancy and delivery of her first child with GBS, which resulted in sepsis in the newborn. Concerning immunoglobulin, Which is the earliest immunoglobulin to be synthesized by the fetus?
questions.solution:
Option D: IgM

The earliest immunoglobulin to be synthesized by the fetus is IgM.

  • IgM is the first immunoglobulin synthesized by a fetus at about 20 weeks.

  • Maximum molecular weight is also known as MILLIONAIRE MOLECULE.

  • IgM is not transported across the placenta; hence, IgM in the fetus or newborn indicates intrauterine infection.

  • It has a maximum sedimentation coefficient.

  • The first immunoglobulin to be produced in any immune response.

  • It is the most efficient. Because its interaction with antigens can involve all ten binding sites, it has the highest binding capacity and cross-linking of all the immunoglobulins.

Option A: IgA

  • Most abundant immunoglobulin in the body but has a low serum concentration

  • Monomer in circulation and dimer when secreted (then containing J chain).

  • Uses transcytosis to cross epithelial borders.

  • Found especially on mucosal surfaces and in bodily fluids like saliva, mucus, tears, and breast milk.

  • Prevents the binding of pathogens to mucous membranes of host cells.

  • A secretory component acquired from epithelial cells protects IgA from luminal proteases (e.g., in the gastrointestinal tract)

  • No complement fixation.

Option B: IgG

  • Maximum in concentration.

  • Maximum t1/2 → 23 Days.

  • The Fc portion of IgG involves in opsonization (enhancement of phagocytosis).

  • Only Ig which pass through the placenta.

Option C: IgE

  • Binds to mast cells → cross-linking upon allergen exposure → release of histamine (involved in allergic diseases).

  • Binds to basophils.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with an exacerbation of COPD was admitted to the ICU and intubated. He was treated as a case of central venous catheter-related MRSA bacteremia and discharged. He was again admitted to the ER for a dissecting aneurysm of the abdominal aorta, which was promptly treated by surgery. The physician suspected a chronic bacterial infection and sent him for a culture examination on nutrient agar. What is the concentration of agar in nutrient agar?
questions.solution:
Option B: 2%

  • The concentration of agar in nutrient agar is 2%.

Nutrient agar:

  • Type of Simple/Basal Media.
  • Made-up of peptone water + meat extract (1%) + 2% agar.

Properties of agar that makes it an ideal solidifying agent :

  • It can’t be utilized/degraded by bacteria.
  • Melting point → 98oC [autoclavable].
  • Solidifying point → 42oC.

Option A: 1%·

  • For solid agar: 1–2% (Japanese agar 2% or New Zealand agar 1.2%).

Option C: 0.5%

  • For semisolid agar: 0.5%.

Option D: 6%

  • For solid agar to inhibit Proteus swarming: 6%.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the OPD with watery stools, stomach pain, and fatigue from the last 2 days. He has just returned from Africa, where he worked for two months in a refugee camp on the border of Rwanda and Zaire. On the plane, he developed abdominal bloating, intestinal gurgling and nausea followed by two loose bowel movements. Soon he was having profuse watery diarrhoea occurring hourly. The stools were clear and without odour. Suspecting infectious stool sample is sent for culture. The microbiologist performing the following test is shown in the image below. Identify the test.
questions.solution:
Option A: String test

  • The above given is a case of vibrio cholera.
  • Odourless and plain stools are a clue to diagnosing rice water stools.
  • The test shown in the Question is the String test.

String test:

This test is done for the diagnosis of V. cholerae.

Method:

Stool + Na deoxycholate

↓

Try to lift up

↓

String is formed

  • If the result is positive, the bacterial cells will be lysed by the sodium deoxycholate or sodium taurocholate, the suspension will lose turbidity, and DNA will be released from the lysed cells causing the mixture to become viscous.

Option B: Slide coagulase test

  • Slide coagulase test: to differentiate staphylococcus from other species of staphylococci known as CONS (Coagulase-negative staphylococci).

Option C: Slide catalase test

Slide Catalase test:

  • To detect the presence of enzyme catalase in a bacterium.
  • Not found in anaerobes.
  • To differentiate staphylococci from streptococci.
  • Catalase positive = 3% H2O2 + staphylococcus colonies: bubbles formation. (Refer to the image below)
  • Catalase negative = Streptococcus species

Option D: Slide Oxidase test

Slide Oxidase test:

  • Oxidase reagent - Tetra methyl para phenylene diamine dihydrochloride.
  • Change of colour From white to blue within 10 sec → Positive

Oxidase-positive organisms:

  • Pseudomonas
  • Vibrio
  • Neisseria
  • Brucella

questions.text: A young female brought her 5-year-old boy to the emergency department complaining of stomach pain, watery diarrhoea, loss of appetite, and vomiting. The sample was sent to the laboratory for diagnosis. The causative organism showed effacement and attachment of intestinal cells, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Option A: EPEC

  • The above is infectious diarrhoea by EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli).
  • The organism which shows effacement and attachment of intestinal cells is EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli).
  • Enteropathogenic E.coli (EPEC) causes attaching and effacing lesions.
  • Paediatric age group diarrhoea (infantile) by attaching to enterocytes and causing their effacement.
  • Factors which promote attachment and effacement (loss of microvilli) are:
    • Bundle-forming pilus encoded by a plasmid EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
    • Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE).

Option B: ETEC

  • ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E.coli) causes attachment through CFA (colonization factor antigen).

Option C: EHEC

  • EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E.coli) causes VT (verotoxin) mediated capillary microangiopathy.

Option D: V. Cholerae.

  • Vibrio cholerae lives in contaminated water.

  • It enters the human body by the consumption of uncooked seafood (e.g., raw shellfish).

  • Vibrio cholerae is a Facultative anaerobe, Oxidase positive, and Straight or curved (comma) shaped bacteria.

  • It has a Polar flagellum.

  • Grows in alkaline media → acid-labile →requires a large infectious dose.

  • Cholera toxin (enterotoxin) is a protein that causes “rice-water” diarrhoea.

  • It causes bacterial gastroenteritis.

  • Fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient who underwent prosthetic heart valve replacement 6 years ago came to the dentistry clinic for a follow-up procedure. The dentist advised her on antibiotic prophylaxis before going for the treatment. Antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis had been advocated before dental procedures in some patients based on theoretical arguments, observational reports and animal studies. This is most probably due to the risk of infection by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A : Streptococcus viridans

  • Viridans streptococci are normally resident in the mouth and upper respiratory tract. They cause transient bacteremia following tooth extraction or other dental procedures; they get implanted on damaged or prosthetic valves or in a congenitally diseased heart and grow to form vegetation.
  • They are ordinarily nonpathogenic but can, on occasion, cause disease. People with pre-existing cardiac lesions may cause bacterial endocarditis, Streptococcus sanguinis being most often responsible.
  • Streptococcus mutans are important in the causation of dental caries.
  • The transient viridans streptococcal bacteremia induced by eating, tooth-brushing, flossing, and other sources of minor trauma, together with adherence to biological surfaces, is thought to account for the predilection of these organisms to cause endocarditis.
  • Viridans streptococci are also isolated, often as a part of mixed flora, from sinusitis, brain abscess, and liver abscess sites.
  • Viridans streptococcal bacteremia occurs relatively frequently in neutropenic patients, particularly after bone marrow transplantation or high-dose chemotherapy for cancer.
  • Treatment of viridans streptococcal infections includes:-
    1. Bacteremia in neutropenic patients → Vancomycin.
    2. Other infections → Penicillin.

Option B: Streptococcus pneumonia

  • Streptococcus pneumonia infection is sometimes found to cause infective endocarditis but is very infrequent.
  • It is known as one of the main causes of community-acquired pneumonia and meningitis.

Option C: Streptococcus pyogenes

  • They cause various infections in children and adults but are rarely seen as a cause of infective endocarditis.
  • The infections range from superficial non-invasive skin infections to invasive infections and diseases like rheumatic fever and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Option D: Staphylococcus aureus

  • Staph. Aureus infective endocarditis (SAIE) is a serious manifestation with considerable morbidity and mortality.
  • It is found in IV drug users and hospitalized patients with nosocomial infections.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presents signs and symptoms suggestive of meningitis which has been resistant to antibiotics for his current illness for the last 02 weeks. His MRI brain is revealing ventriculomegaly and a brain abscess. Importantly, he has a pathognomic feature of fungal infection. Later he is suspected of having a fungal disease. His sample was sent for staining and further processing to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is a correctly matched stain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: India Ink-Cryptococcus

  • Based on signs and symptoms patient is suffering from cryptococcus neoformans, which stains India Ink.
  • Entry to the CNS is a vital step in cryptococcal pathogenesis. Various reports revealed that internalised and free cryptococci enter the blood-brain barrier to reach the brain, either by transcytosis through barrier epithelial cells or between them via the break of the tight junctions.
  • The best-studied virulence factor of C. neoformans is its polysaccharide capsule.

C. Neoformans capsule images:

  1. Top row: Negative stain with India ink; quick-freeze deep-etch electron micrograph of a portion of the cell wall with capsule fibres extending to the left); thin section electron micrograph of three cells.
  2. Bottom row: Immunoelectron micrograph of a portion of a cell (capsule fibres extending upwards) stained with gold-conjugated anti-capsule antibody; differential interference contrast micrograph of a budding cell; confocal immunofluorescence micrograph with the capsule stained blue and the cell wall stained green.

 

  • A modified technique employs 2% chromium mercury and India ink. This technique identifies some external and internal structures of the organism.

 

 

Option B: Lactophenol cotton blue– Candida

  • Candida is a commensal of the human body and an opportunistic pathogen frequently responsible for hospital-acquired bloodstream infections.
  • Candida cells can merge with bacteria within biofilms, especially through chemical or metabolic indirect interactions and direct physical contact involving the yeast or hyphal form of the fungal cells.
  • Lactophenol cotton blue is a mixture of methyl blue and lactophenol (a solution of phenol, lactic acid, and glycerol in water).

 

Option C: Methanamine silver – Aspergillus

  • The major species known to cause disease in humans are found in five Aspergillus species: 
    • Fumigation
    • Flavi
    • Nigri
    • Terrie
    • Nidulante
  • In humans, Aspergillus fumigatus is the mainstream and life-threatening airborne opportunistic fungal pathogen, which is particularly important among immunocompromised patients.
  • Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) with methenamine silver stain is commonly used to detect pneumocystis carinii and fungal organisms as causes of infectious pulmonic disease in immunosuppressed patients.

 

 

Option D: Gram’s stain– Pneumocystis carinii

  • Whether P carinii is a fungus or a protozoan is not yet established. Antigenic differences have been found in strains derived from the various mammalian hosts.
  • Tachypnea, dyspnea and cough, and fever—are the usual symptoms of Pneumocystis pneumonia.
  • In normal individuals, asymptomatic infection of the lungs occurs in early life. The organism remains inactive or latent unless the host becomes immunocompromised. Organisms add to the alveolar septal wall resulting in diffuse alveolitis and impaired oxygenation.
  • A Gram stain is a test that denotes bacteria at the site of a suspected infection, such as the throat, lungs, genitals, or in skin wounds. Gram stains may also identify bacteria in certain body fluids, such as blood or urine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was returning to India from South America. At the airport, he was stopped as he showed some symptoms like fever, headache, and muscle aches, particularly in his back and knees. He is sensitive to light, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite and dizziness. On examination, his face, tongue, skin and eyes show yellow colour. The physician diagnosed this condition as yellow fever. This condition is caused by which viral family?
questions.solution:
Option B: Flavivirus

  • The yellow fever virus is an arbovirus of the flavivirus genus and is transmitted by mosquitoes belonging to the Aedes and Haemogogus species.
  • The yellow fever virus is found in tropical and subtropical areas of Africa and South America. Yellow fever is a very rare cause of illness in US travelers.
  • After transmission from a mosquito, the viruses replicate in the lymph nodes and infect dendritic cells in particular. From there, they reach the liver and infect hepatocytes (probably indirectly via Kupffer cells), which leads to the eosinophilic degradation of these cells and the release of cytokines. Apoptotic masses known as Councilman bodies appear in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes.
  • Fatality may occur when there is a cytokine storm, shock, and multiple organ failure.
  • Laboratory diagnosis of yellow fever is generally accomplished by testing serum to detect virus-specific IgM and neutralizing antibodies. Sometimes the virus can be found in blood samples taken early in the illness.

Option A: Alphavirus

  • Alphaviruses are small, enveloped viruses, ~70 nm in diameter, containing a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome.
  • Viruses of this genus are predominantly arthropod-borne viruses known to cause human disease.
  • Alphavirus usually causes fever, rash, and rheumatic diseases

Option C: Bunyavirus

  • Bunyavirales is an order of single-strand, spherical, enveloped RNA viruses (formerly the Bunyaviridae family)
  • Bunyaviruses cause several diseases in humans and domestic animals, including fever, hemorrhagic fever, renal failure, encephalitis, meningitis, blindness, and, in domestic animals, congenital defects.

Option D: Orbivirus

  • Orbiviruses are vector-borne pathogens transmitted by ticks, mosquitoes, and midges.
  • That causes bluetongue disease in sheep, cattle, goats, and wild ungulates; African horse sickness in horses, donkeys, and dogs; and epizootic hemorrhagic deer fever.
  • The three economically most important orbiviruses are :
    • Bluetongue virus
    • African horse sickness virus
    • Epizootic hemorrhagic disease virus
  • All of these are transmitted by Culicoides species. The genus contains 22 species and at least 130 different serotypes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to OPD with a complaint of abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting for the last two days. She also reports headaches, insomnia and generalised weakness. His examination reveals a high blood pressure of 160/110mmHg with a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute. On examination, hepatomegaly is noticed. Additionally, her vitamin B-12 levels are low. The clinical diagnosis of malignant hydatid disease is made. Which of the following is true about malignant hydatid disease in the patient?

choices.text: Hydatid disease in the immunocompromised host

questions.solution:
Option B: Infection with E. multilocularis

  • The scenario is hydatid disease, in which there is abdominal pain and hepatomegaly. Hydatid disease is an infection with Echinococcus multilocularis.
  • The liver is the most common organ affected (98% of cases).
  • The disease may resemble a slowly growing carcinoma and cause intrahepatic portal hypertension symptoms.
  • Hepatomegaly and hypertension are seen.
  • The cyst appears as a solid, firm mass with an irregular outer layer and can migrate rapidly to other organs to mimic a malignant tumour.
  • Man is an accidental intermediate host.
  • Definitive agent- Foxes and wolves (and also dogs and cats).
  • Intermediate hosts- Small wild rodents like squirrels, voles, mice, etc.
  • This disease is found in Russia, Kazakhstan, China, etc.

Option A: Malignant changes into hydatid cyst

  • There are no malignant changes in hydatid disease.
  • Humans are not included in the parasitic life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus.

Option C: Hydatid disease in the immunocompromised host

  • The scenario mentioned above is hydatid disease.
  • Cystic and alveolar echinococcosis occurs in the immunocompromised host.

Option D: Caused by Echinococcus granulosus

  • Hydatid disease is an infection with Echinococcus multilocularis.
  • Cystic Echinococcosis (C.E.), also known as hydatid disease, is caused by infection with the larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe gastritis. Her endoscopy is performed on the doctor's recommendation. During the procedure, the patient suddenly develops severe pain and swelling in the neck, with crepitus suggestive of iatrogenic esophageal perforation. Which part of the esophagus is most susceptible to this type of injury?

choices.text: Above the arch of the aorta
Below the arch of the aorta

questions.solution:
Option B: Cervical portion

  • The cervical portion of the esophagus is most susceptible to iatrogenic esophageal perforation

Common sites of esophageal perforation

Anatomic landmark Description
Piriform sinus Trumpet players, manual labourers, and singers are prone to develop piriform sinus perforations.
Killian triangle Pharyngoesophageal diverticula occur here, and inadvertent cannulation of the diverticulum results in perforation.
Cricopharyngeous muscle Most common site of iatrogenic perforation.
Aortic arch/bronchus Esophagus is in direct contact with the aortic arch and bronchus, which both create a small indentation on the esophagram.
Gastroesophageal junction Most common site of perforation in Boerhaave’s syndrome.

Etiology:

Esophageal perforation
Iatrogenic Spontaneous
  • Most common type(60%)
  • Caused by endoscopy
  • The most common site is the cervical esophagus (cricopharyngeal area)
  • Esophageal rupture after vomiting
  • Most common site: the left posterolateral side of the distal esophagus

 

 

Option A: Abdominal portion

  • It is the most common site of perforation in Boerhaave’s syndrome.

Option C: Above the arch of the aorta

  • Iatrogenic perforation rarely develops above the arch of the aorta.

Option D: Below the arch of the aorta

  • Iatrogenic perforation rarely develops below the arch of the aorta.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female presents in the surgical outpatient department due to the progressively increasing size of her left breast for the last 2 months. She also complains of itching, heaviness, and an increased temperature in her left breast. Physical examination reveals widespread erythema, intense edema, and areolar erosion of the breast, with several enlarged axillary lymph nodes on the left side. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and radiotherapy

questions.solution:
Option A: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy and radiotherapy

  • This elderly female with skin thickening, erythema, the warmth of her breast, and palpable axillary lymph nodes most likely has locally invasive inflammatory breast cancer.
  • Inflammatory breast carcinoma accounts for <3% of breast cancers.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer is a subtype of invasive ductal carcinoma which does not commonly present with a palpable lump.
  • It usually presents with an inflamed, swollen breast with thickening of the overlying skin (peau d’orange appearance) due to blockage of dermal lymphatics.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer can sometimes be misdiagnosed as mastitis due to its presentation.
  • At least 33% of skin over the breast is involved with a history of rapid onset and progression.
  • More than 75% of women have palpable axillary lymphadenopathy and distant metastasis.
  • This patient most likely has stage IIIB breast cancer (tumor spread to the chest wall and axillary lymph nodes with no involvement of other organs).
  • The treatment of inflammatory breast cancer includes neoadjuvant chemotherapy (given before the surgery) to reduce tumor size.
  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is followed by modified radical mastectomy (removal of the entire breast including skin, nipple, areola, and axillary lymph nodes with sparing of the pectoralis major and minor muscles).
  • Modified radical mastectomy is followed by radiotherapy to remove any residual tumor cells.

Option B: Radical mastectomy followed by chemotherapy

  • Radical mastectomy involves the removal of the entire breast, nipple, areola, overlying skin, axillary lymph nodes, and pectoralis major and minor muscles.
  • Patients with inflammatory breast cancer are treated with modified radical mastectomy as it has better outcomes than radical mastectomy.

Option C: Radical mastectomy followed by radiotherapy

  • The treatment of inflammatory breast cancer is initiated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
  • In addition, modified radical mastectomy is preferred over radical mastectomy for treating inflammatory breast cancer.

Option D: Chemotherapy followed by hormone therapy

  • Chemotherapy and hormonal therapy are the mainstays of treatment for metastatic breast cancer (that has spread to other body organs).
  • This patient has locally invasive inflammatory breast cancer that can be treated with chemotherapy, surgery, and radiotherapy.
  • Surgical treatment is the definitive treatment for stage III breast cancer to remove residual cancer from the chest wall and axilla.

questions.text: A newborn exhibits respiratory distress and cyanosis, accompanied by X-ray evidence of multiple bowel loops within the thoracic cavity and a mediastinal shift, what is the most frequently encountered type of defect associated with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A: Bochdalek 

  • Bochdalek hernia is the most common congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • Congenital Diaphragmatic hernia: 
    • The overall incidence of Bochdalek hernia is 1:2000 to 1:5000.  
    • It occurs due to the failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus.  
    • Abdominal contents herniate into the thoracic cavity compressing the ipsilateral developing lung.  
    • Patients have respiratory distress and cyanosis at birth.  
    • Clinical features:
      • Includes grunting respiration, chest retractions, dyspnea, and cyanosis with the scaphoid abdomen.  
      • Decreased breath sounds, along with bowel sounds, are heard on auscultating the chest.  
      • Shifting of heart sounds to the right. 
    • Diagnosis:
      • Diagnosis made prenatal at 15 weeks of gestation with ultrasound. 
      • Ultrasound findings include herniated abdominal viscera in the chest, changes in liver position, and a mediastinal shift away from the herniated viscera.  
      • Chest radiograph demonstrates multiple bowel loops in the thoracic cavity along with mediastinal shift. 
    • Management: 
      • Immediate securing of the airway with endotracheal intubation is critical. 
      • To minimize the degree of pulmonary hypertension, inhaled nitric oxide may be administered. 
      • After achieving hemodynamic stability, the diaphragmatic repair is done. 
      • Fetal tracheal occlusion is an experimental prenatal therapy for the treatment of severe congenital diaphragmatic hernia that reverses lung hypoplasia. 

Option B: Morgagni 

  • It is not the most commonly occurring diaphragmatic hernia in newborns. 

Option C: Paraesophageal type I 

  • Paraesophageal type I is also called a Sliding hernia.
  • It is not the most commonly occurring diaphragmatic hernia in newborns. 

Option D: Paraesophageal type III 

  • Paraesophageal type III is also called a Mixed paraesophageal hernia
  • Herniation of both GE junction of fundus of stomach.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented to the surgery OPD with complaints of swelling in front of her neck. She gives a history of irradiation to her neck during her childhood for Hodgkin lymphoma, which was cured. Her neck examination reveals a hard mass in front of her neck. A FNAC of the thyroid lump is done, which confirms a thyroid carcinoma with no lymph node involvement. Her biopsy picture is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Papillary carcinoma

  • In the case mentioned above, the patient's clinical features of swelling in the front of the neck associated with hoarseness of voice and biopsy findings suggest Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC).
  • Pathology of papillary thyroid carcinoma:
    • Papillary projections
    • Optically clear nuclei aka Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusion bodies
    • Dystrophic calcification- Psammoma bodies

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy and usually is associated with an excellent prognosis, particularly in young patients.
  • Occasionally, a metastatic PTC manifests as a painless lateral neck mass that is clinically detected before detecting the primary thyroid lesion called lateral aberrant thyroid
  • Prognostic risk classification for PTC includes the AGES and AMES scoring systems.
  • The absence of distant metastasis at initial treatment and size less than 4cm are other important positive predictors.
  • Total Thyroidectomy is recommended for all PTCs 1cm or larger
  • PTCs less than 1 cm in diameter are defined as microcarcinomas.

Option B: Follicular carcinoma

  • Follicular thyroid cancer is the second most common type, making up about 10 to 15% of all thyroid cancers.

Option C: Medullary carcinoma

  • Medullary carcinoma is a rare type of thyroid cancer.
  • Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) cells can be secreted by various tumor markers, including calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA).

Option D: None of the above

  • The clinical case and biopsy picture above suggest Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of heartburn and regurgitation. She also complains of mild dysphagia. The patient is diagnosed with a hiatus hernia. Which of the following statements represents a hiatus hernia?

choices.text: It is prevalent in young people
Decreased intraabdominal pressure leads to a hiatus hernia

questions.solution:
Option B: Esophageal strictures are present 

  • Hiatal hernias can either be present at birth or develop later in life. There is a correlation between age and an increased prevalence. It is hypothesized that muscle weakness, together with a lack of flexibility and elasticity brought on by ageing, predisposes a person to develop a hiatal hernia.  
  • As a result, the top portion of the stomach may not return to its natural place below the diaphragm when swallowing. This may cause discomfort.  
  • Other risk factors, such as having high intraabdominal pressure, have also been identified as contributing causes. The most common causes of this condition are being overweight, being pregnant, having chronic constipation, and having a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).  
  • The formation of a hiatal hernia may also be influenced by factors like trauma, age, prior surgical procedures, and even heredity. 

Option A: It is prevalent in young people

  • It is prevalent in old people. 

Option C: It presents with esophageal varices

  • It does not present with esophageal varices. 

Option D: Decreased intraabdominal pressure leads to a hiatus hernia

  • Increased intraabdominal pressure leads to a hiatus hernia.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the disease that presents with chronic diarrhea, recurrent aphthous ulcers, and multiple superficial ulcers involving the entire colon?

choices.text: Infliximab was not the first anti-TNF α antibody used in the treatment of ulcerative colitis
Surgery is palliative in ulcerative colitis

questions.solution:
Option A: First-line therapy is Aminosalicylates

  • Based on the symptoms of chronic diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and recurrent aphthous ulcers, and colonoscopic findings of multiple superficial ulcers in the rectum, the most likely diagnosis is ulcerative colitis.
  • The first line therapy for ulcerative colitis is Aminosalicylates which involve sulfasalazine, 5-acetyl salicylic acid (5-ASA), and related compounds. These are the first-line medication used to induce and maintain remission in patients with mild to moderately active ulcerative colitis.
  • They act by inhibiting cyclooxygenase and 5-lipoxygenase in the gut mucosa and have a minor role in inhibiting cytokines. At the same time, PAF, TNF α, and nuclear activation factor play a major role.
  • These drugs require direct contact with affected mucosa for efficacy.
  • In cases of acute exacerbation, immunomodulators and Thiopurine are the most commonly used immunomodulator in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis requiring long-term treatment. They interfere with nucleic acid synthesis and thus decrease the proliferation of inflammatory cells. They are usually used in patients who have failed to respond to salicylate therapy or are dependent on or have a refractory response to the corticosteroids.
  • Tacrolimus and Cyclosporine induce clinical remission in patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis who are unresponsive to steroids and hence used as second-line therapy.

Option B: Infliximab was not the first anti-TNF α antibody used in the treatment of ulcerative colitis

  • The first anti-TNFα antibody used to treat ulcerative colitis was infliximab.
  • The first anti-TNF-α antibody was approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for treating moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
  • Adalimumab is used in patients that are intolerant to infliximab.

Option C: Steroid-dependent cases need surgery

  • The steroid-dependent cases of ulcerative colitis do not need surgery.
  • Corticosteroids are considered the most effective therapy in inducing remission in patients who do not respond to 5 amino-salicylic acids.

Option D: Surgery is palliative in ulcerative colitis

  • The surgical treatment is not entirely palliative.
  • A combination of strictureplasty and operative excision results in effective symptom relief.
  • Chronic ulcerative colitis is a diffuse inflammatory disease of the colon and rectal mucosa. Complete removal of the colon and rectum ensure complete healing.
  • New surgical alternatives developed in the past 20 years have eliminated the need for a permanent ileostomy after resectioning the involved colon and rectum.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male chronic smoker presented with a swelling on the right side of the face for the past one and a half years. The onset was insidious, and the swelling gradually increased in size. The skin over the swelling is normal.  Examination showed a firm right preauricular mass. A mass biopsy showed numerous papillations covered by monomorphic oncotic cells and germinal centers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Warthin's tumour

  • Warthin's tumour, also called papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, is the second most common benign salivary gland tumour (after pleomorphic adenoma). It represents 10-15% of the total salivary gland neoplasms.
  • They are commonly seen between the fifth and seventh decade of life, and it has an apparent male predilection for their occurrence. They are typically found in smokers.
  • They almost exclusively occur in the parotid glands and can be bilateral in 10% of cases.
  • Histologically, it is composed of an oncotic epithelium and a lymphoid stroma.
  • It consists of an encapsulated mass containing numerous irregular cystic spaces lined by bilayered oncotic epithelium growing in the cystic spaces as papillary projections.
  • The underlying stroma separating the oncotic epithelium is typically a large lymphoid matrix with germinal centres.
  • Treatment is superficial parotidectomy, although they can be enucleated without danger of recurrence.

Option A: Pleomorphic adenoma

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common parotid gland neoplasm. It is composed of a chondromyxoid stroma and epithelium. There are no germinal centres, and the tumour is pleomorphic rather than monomorphic, as in this patient.

Option B: Adenoid cystic carcinoma

  • It is the most common tumour of the minor salivary glands. It occurs most commonly in the palate, retromolar area and sinonasal tract.
  • It does not occur in the parotid gland. It commonly involves the facial nerve.

Option D: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

  • It is the second most common salivary gland tumour. It has mucinous and squamous components. Germinal centres are absent.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the medical outpatient department with complaints of abdominal pain associated with diarrhoea for the last two months. He is afebrile and vitally stable. He looks pale and has oral ulcers. His abdominal examination is unremarkable. On further evaluation, in barium contrast studies, the hose pipe appearance of the intestine is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Crohn’s disease

  • Hose-pipe appearance is a feature of Crohn’s disease.
  • Crohn’s disease:
    • Chronic transmural inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract.
    • Radiologic findings:
      • Deep ulcers
      • Hose-pipe appearance (long stricture extending into I/C valve with thickened wall)
      • Fat halo sign
      • Cobblestone appearance
      • Creeping fat sign

Option B: Malabsorption Syndrome

  • Malabsorption syndrome is a digestive disorder that prevents the body from effectively absorbing nutrients from food.
  • It has many causes, but most commonly involves damage to the small intestine's mucous lining.

Option C: Ulcerative Colitis

  • Ulcerative colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease which involves the colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhoea and abdominal pain along with iron deficiency anaemia.
  • There is a collar button appearance and loss of haustrations.
  • Signs seen:
    • Target sign / Halo sign
    • Comb sign
    • Rose thorning sign
    • Creeping fat sign
    • String sign of Kantor

Option D: Hirschsprung’s disease

  • Hirschsprung's disease is characterised by the absence of ganglionic cells in the distal colon and rectum.
  • It occurs due to the failure of migration of neural crest cells to distal bowel segments and affects cells in both myenteric and submucosal plexuses.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female comes to the physician complaining of a lump in her right breast that she noticed 4 months ago. After a complete workup, the diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma is established. Before starting treatment, the physician suggests HER-2/neu immunohistochemistry staining. Which of the following scores on this patient’s test results will most likely need further confirmatory testing?
questions.solution:
Option C: 2+

  • This patient, who has been diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma, should have additional testing for molecular markers.
  • Various molecular markers, including those involved in the steroid hormone receptor pathways (estrogen and progesterone receptors), and molecules involved in the human epidermal growth factor receptor pathway (HER-2), are routinely tested for targeted treatment.
  • HER-2 protein is the product of the ERB-B2 gene.
  • This protein is amplified in almost 20% of breast cancer cases, and its testing is therefore included in the routine pathologic reporting of breast cancer.
  • The HER-2 receptor has an extracellular domain and intracellular tyrosine kinase.
  • Overexpression of the HER-2 gene product results in the proliferation of tumor cells.
  • HER-2 overexpression is measured by immunohistochemistry.
  • The results are reported on a scale of 0 to 3+.
  • A score of 0 or 1+ indicates a negative, whereas a score of 3+ indicates a positive HER-2/neu amplification status.
