  • If the test yields a score of 2+, it is considered equivocal, and further testing with fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) is done to confirm a positive or negative status.
  • HER-2-positive breast cancer can be treated with trastuzumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody targeted against the HER-2 receptor.

 

 

Option A: 0

  • If the immunohistochemical staining reveals a score of 0, it is considered negative for HER-2 gene amplification.
  • No further testing is indicated in this scenario.

Option B: 1+

  • Obtaining a score of 1+ on immunohistochemistry labels the tumor as HER-2 receptor-negative, and no further testing is required.

Option D: 3+

  • If the immunohistochemistry for the HER-2 gene reveals a score of 3+, it marks the overexpression of the gene and its product protein.
  • The patients with a positive HER-2/neu status are treated with trastuzumab-based targeted therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of Van Nuys prognostic index (NPI)?
questions.solution:
Option A: Age of patient

  • Ductal carcinoma-in-situ is the presence of cancer cells inside the milk duct of breast tissue.
  • DCIS is considered the earliest form of breast cancer.
  • DCIS is a non-invasive (benign) tumor.

  • Van Nuy's prognostic index (VNPI) classifies patients with DCIS to guide decisions on the best treatment option.
    • Size of tumor
    • Resection margin width; the amount of healthy tissue surrounding the tumor after removal
    • Age of patient
    • Grade

Option B: Smoking status

  • Smoking is a risk factor for breast cancer in women.
  • It, however, has no role in deciding whether the patient will benefit from radiotherapy or whether it will be a futile effort.

Option C: Gender

  • Breast cancer is rare in men. However, when present, they are associated with a worse prognosis.

Option D: Her-2-neu receptor status

  • Her-2-neu is associated with worse prognosis in breast cancer patients

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the emergency department complaining of excessive drowsiness and decreased oral intake for the past 3 days, along with difficulty getting up from the squatting position, combing her hair, and dressing. She complained of weight gain in the last few months, increased sensitivity to cold, skin dryness, hair loss, hoarseness of voice, and easy fatigability. She also had no family history or any major illnesses. On physical examination, periorbital puffiness and dry, coarse skin were noted. No tremors or fasciculations were elicited. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hypothyroidism

  • These symptoms are suggestive of hypothyroidism. A deficiency in circulating levels of thyroid hormone leads to hypothyroidism.
  • Hypothyroidism signs and symptoms may include:
    • Easy fatigability
    • Increased sensitivity to cold (cold intolerance)
    • Constipation
    • Dry skin ( due to reduced conversion of carotene to vitamin A)
    • Weight gain
    • Patients with severe hypothyroidism or myxedema develop characteristic facial features due to the deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the subcutaneous tissues, leading to facial and periorbital puffiness.
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Muscle weakness (thyroid myopathy), Muscle aches, tenderness, and stiffness
    • Elevated blood cholesterol level
    • Heavier than normal or irregular menstrual periods
    • Infertility
    • Thinning hair and loss of outer two-thirds of eyebrow
    • Enlarged thyroid gland (goiter)
    • Cardiovascular changes include bradycardia, cardiomegaly, pericardial effusion, reduced cardiac output and pulmonary effusion.
    • Hypothyroidism in children leads to cretinism and characteristic facies

Option B: Hyperthyroidism

  • Hyperthyroidism presents with weight loss despite increased appetite, heat intolerance, tremors, gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea), and warm moist palms. Such findings are not seen in this patient.

Option C: Anemia of unknown cause

  • A patient with anemia presents easy fatigability, excessive drowsiness, dry skin, and dry/damaged hair; however, patients with anemia do not show periorbital puffiness, cold intolerance, and hoarseness of voice. Such symptoms are suggestive of hypothyroidism.

Option D: Underlying malignancy

  • A patient with malignancy will present with weight loss, decreased appetite, and easy fatigability gradually progressively. However, periorbital puffiness, dry, coarse skin, weight gain, and cold intolerance are signs of hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presented to the outpatient clinic complaining of fever for 1 month and  generalized weakness. She also presents with an anterior neck swelling for 4 years which rapidly progressed in the past 3-4 months, accompanied by pain over the swelling, and hoarseness of voice. The patient further reported a history of recent weight loss and decreased appetite. She denied dysphagia, dyspnea, and any history of cancer in the family. Prior medical history was described as non-significant. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Anaplastic

  • This patient has had neck swelling for the past 4 years with a rapid progression in size since the last 3-4 months associated with hoarseness of voice and pain over the swelling likely has anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.
  • Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is most commonly seen in life's 7th to 8th decade.
  • It presents more commonly in women.
  • The patients present with a history of neck swelling and a sudden increase in the size of the swelling associated with severe pain over the swelling
  • The most common route of spread is by direct invasion causing compression of the surrounding structures:
    • Dyspnea due to tracheal compression
    • Dysphagia due to esophageal compression
    • Hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement
  • The most common site of metastasis is Lungs
  • On FNAC, it shows giant and multinucleated cells
  • Has a poor prognosis due to the aggressive nature of the tumor

Option A: Papillary

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma presents in young patients with a history of radiation exposure.
  • It presents a painless thyroid mass, hard and fixed with irregular borders and regional lymphadenopathy.

Option B: Follicular

  • Most commonly present in the fifth decade of life.
  • Present with an enlargement of the thyroid gland, most commonly asymptomatic, and occasionally show hypo or hyperthyroid symptoms.

Option C: Medullary

  • It is a rare calcitonin-producing tumor originating from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland.
  • Present with symptoms of compression of surrounding organs i.e. dyspnea, dysphagia, and hoarseness
  • It has a history of similar presentation in the family due to RET mutation (the RET proto-oncogene codes the RET receptor tyrosine kinase)

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented to the clinic with painful blue-colored fingers and nails on both hands that became blanched then changed color to blue after a month's trip to mountain areas. She had weak but noticeable upper-limb pulses on examination, and no other significant findings were present. She had no other co-morbidities and was taking no medications. No tobacco history is present. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A: Raynaud’s disease

  • The patient presents with pain and color changes in her fingers and nails after exposure to cold (Northern areas of Pakistan), indicating Raynaud’s disease.
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon is manifested by the sequential development of digital blanching, cyanosis, and redness of fingers and toes due to cold exposure or emotional stress.
  • Pulses are usually normal but can be weak due to arterial spasms of the region.
  • Blanching is due to a spasm of digital arterioles causing white digits that proceed to 2nd stage of cyanosis. The patient presents with cyanosis due to dilatation of capillaries and venule, which leads to a collection of deoxygenated blood and causes blue skin color.
  • The management is to stop cold exposure, calcium channel blockers (nifedipine, diltiazem), and angiotensin receptors blockers. These medications are used to relieve spasms.

Option B: Raynaud’s syndrome

  • It is associated with other disorders –most commonly SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus).

Option C: Buerger’s disease

  • Patient with Buerger's disease usually presents with a strong history of smoking.

Option D: Acrocyanosis

  • The cyanosis in this disease occurs with no pain, but paresthesia is present.

questions.text: You are a third-year resident in the surgery department. During a sphincterotomy procedure for sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, the chief surgeon passes on the surgical blade to you and tells you to continue the procedure. To minimize the chance of pancreatic duct injury during surgery, you should make the incision at which of the following positions in the ampulla?
questions.solution:
Option D: 11 o’clock position

  • Sphincterotomy is performed from 10 to 11 o’clock position. 
  • Placing the incision at this location in the ampulla minimizes the chance of pancreatic duct injury, which is generally located opposite the planned sphincterotomy site.

Option A: 3 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 3 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

Option B: 6 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 6 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

Option C: 9 o’clock position

  • Incision at the 9 o’clock position increases the risk of pancreatic duct injury.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female comes to the clinic with the complaint of generalized pain and swelling in both legs for two months. Her job requires her to stand for long periods of time, which worsens her pain and is usually relieved by walking and raising her legs. She has a known case of varicose veins. Her Vitals show that her blood pressure is 130/90, her heart rate is 72 beats per minute, and her temperature is 37.7 degree Celsius. On examination, visibly distended veins, along with yellow-brown skin pigmentation, eczema, and painful, indurated, and hardened skin, are seen on both of her lower legs. Additionally, lipodermatosclerosis is found. According to the CEAP classification system, these examination findings can be categorized as?
questions.solution:
Option D: C4

  • This is the case of chronic venous insufficiency.
  • The CEAP classification can classify CVI based on clinical features. According to this classification, hyperpigmentation, eczema, and lipodermatosclerosis are seen in the CEAP C4 class.
  • Hyperpigmentation is a sign of chronic venous stasis, particularly if it is found along the medial aspect of the lower leg or ankle.

      Option A: C1

  • The C1 category of the CEAP classification shows telangiectasias (diameter of the vein is less than 1mm) and/or reticular veins (diameter between 1 to 3mm).
  •  Telangiectasias, commonly called spider veins, are small, dilated blood vessels within the dermis, while reticular veins are found subdermally.

Option B: C2

  • The C2 class of CEAP shows recurrent varicose veins in the lower extremities without eczema or lipodermatosclerosis.
  • Varicose veins are dilated, often tortuous, visible veins in the subcutaneous tissue with a diameter of >3mm.

Option C: C3

  • Edema is seen as the predominant clinical feature in CEAP class C3.
  • It usually presents as swelling and pitting edema in the lower extremities.

questions.text:
According to Bismuth classification, the given two images of Klatskin tumours come under which type?

1                                                                                                    2
questions.solution:
Option D: Type IIIb; Type IV

  • Perihilar cholangiocarcinoma also referred to as Klatskin tumours, are further classified based on anatomic location by the Bismuth-Corlette classification.
    • Type IIIb tumours extend into the left secondary intrahepatic ducts.
    • Type IV tumours involve both the right and left secondary intrahepatic ducts.

Option A: Type IIIa; Type IIIb

  • Type IIIa tumours extend into the right secondary intrahepatic ducts
  • Type III b tumours extend into the left secondary intrahepatic ducts

Option B: Type IIIb; Type V

  • Type III b tumours extend into the left secondary intrahepatic ducts
  • Type V tumours involve the junction of the cystic duct and bile duct

Option C: Type II; Type IIIa

  • Type II tumours involve the bifurcation without the involvement of the secondary intrahepatic ducts
  • Type IIIa tumours extend into the right secondary intrahepatic ducts

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with chronic NSAID abuse presents with massive hematemesis, hypotension, and tachycardia. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness. IV proton pump inhibitors are administered, and endoscopy reveals a bleeding peptic ulcer in the proximal duodenum. Which of the following vessels needs to be ligated in this patient to stop the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Gastroduodenal artery

  • Peptic ulcers are open sores in the stomach (gastric ulcer) and the upper part of the duodenum (duodenal ulcer).
  • It usually presents with hematemesis and melena.
  • A peptic ulcer is the most common cause of upper GI bleeding, present in one-half to two-thirds of patients with upper GI bleeding.
  • It has the following two types:

 

 

Gastric ulcer

Duodenal ulcers

Abdominal pain

Pain increases with the meal.

Pain decreases with the meal.

H. Pylori infection

Chronic infection

Acute infection

Mechanism

Decreased mucosal protection against gastric ulcer

Decreased mucosal protection or increased gastric secretion

Causes

NSAIDS

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

Risk of carcinoma

Increase risk

Benign

 

  • Ulcers (duodenal ulcers) is the most common cause of upper GI bleeding
  • Duodenal ulcer bleeds from the gastroduodenal artery.
  • Gastric ulcers mostly bleed from the left gastric artery.

 

 

Option B: Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery

  • It arises from the gastroduodenal artery.
  • It divides into anterior and posterior branches.
  • Both branches combine with the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery branches to form the superior mesenteric artery.
  • It mostly supplies the pancreas and duodenum.

Option C: Left gastric artery

  • The left gastric artery is a branch of the celiac artery.
  • The lesser curve is supplied by the right and left gastric vessels, and the greater curve is by the right and left gastroepiploic vessels.
  • Gastric ulcers mostly bleed from the left gastric artery.

Option D: Left gastroepiploic artery

  • The left gastroepiploic artery arises from the splenic artery and runs within the gastrosplenic ligament.
  • The greater curve is supplied by the right and left gastroepiploic vessels.

questions.text: A 52-year old lady presented with a 5-day history of jaundice and abdominal pain nausea and dark urine. She was nauseated and had dark urine. On initial assessment, she was deeply icteric, and her temperature was 38.2°C, but she was hemodynamically stable. Systemic examination did not reveal any other abnormalities. No organs or lymph nodes were palpable, and the abdomen was soft and non-tender. Biochemical analyses demonstrated leukocytosis. Intrahepatic duct dilatation was also noted. What is the best next step in treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Conservative management with stone removal via ERCP
Adequate hydration and IV antibiotics and then elective cholecystectomy

questions.solution:
Option B: Adequate hydration and IV antibiotics and then elective cholecystectomy

  • The diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is Acute cholangitis.
  • Acute cholangitis is a severe medical condition that can progress quickly to septic shock and death.
  • Adequate hydration and IV antibiotics should be started immediately.
  • Patients who have suffered an episode of acute cholangitis related to gallstone disease should be recommended to undergo elective cholecystectomy approximately 6 weeks after the resolution of cholangitis.

Option A: Conservative management with stone removal via ERCP

  • If the patient does not respond to medical therapy and progresses to shock, the patient requires urgent stone removal by ERCP

Option C: Emergency cholecystectomy

  • Emergency cholecystectomy is indicated for gall bladder necrosis and emphysematous gall bladder.

Option D: ERCP with sphincterotomy

  • Emergent decompression of the biliary tree is usually accomplished by ERCP and sphincterotomy.
  • Indications for emergent sphincterotomy are:
    • The common bile duct is dilated and contains multiple stones and biliary sludge.
    • When papilla is fibrosed and stenosed secondary to the passage of stones through it.

questions.text:
A 1-year-old male baby is brought by his parents with a complaint of abdominal distention. The parents also complain of blood in the stool. A barium enema X-ray is ordered after the physical examination, which shows the following findings:



Which of the following findings are indicated in the Abdominal X-ray?
questions.solution:
Option C: Coiled spring sign

  • The above-shown picture depicts a coiled spring sign, and the most likely cause is intussusception.
  • Children with classic findings of intussusception need to be investigated with an enema, which is both diagnostic (the gold standard in the diagnosis of intussusception) and therapeutic.
  • On Barium enema:
    • Claw sign
    • Coiled spring sign

Option A: Meniscus sign

  • A highly specific radiographic roentgen finding for intussusception is called the meniscus sign (or crescent sign).
  • This is crescent shaped-gas in the bowel lumen (intussuscipiens) that surrounds the apex of the intussusceptum (invaginated segment), creating a well-demarcated soft tissue/gas interface

 

Option B: Pseudo kidney sign

  • The pseudo kidney sign is a characteristic ultrasound appearance in some cases of intestinal intussusception.
  • It refers to the longitudinal ultrasound appearance of the intussuscepted bowel segment, mimicking a kidney.

Option D: Target sign

  • A target sign is classically defined as a CT image associated with the thickening of the intestinal wall. A lower attenuated middle layer is surrounded on each side by layers of higher attenuation.
  • The diagnosis of a small bowel target sign most commonly correlates with intussusception.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male comes to the hospital with a congenital condition of a curved penis. Clinical examination shows he has incomplete prepuce and distal meatus. He has a poor urinary stream and has to sit to urinate. Medical history includes correction surgery at the age of 21 months. Again, the surgery is considered to improve fertility and allow voiding while standing. Which of the following is considered true regarding the condition shown in the image?.

choices.text: It is attributed to the failure of complete urethral tabularization in the fetus.
The urethral opening is most commonlyseen in the perineum
The urethra opens proximally and dorsally
It is seen in 1 in 1500 boys

questions.solution:
Option A: It is attributed to a failure of complete urethral tabularization in the fetus.

  • In this case, as the patient has distal meatus, hypospadias is diagnosed.
  • Hypospadias is a congenital condition in which the urethra folds are incomplete, and the urethral meatus opens on the underside of the penis or perineum (ventral surface of the penis).
  • This defect occurs during embryologic development between the gestation period of 8 to 20 weeks.
  • Based on the location of meatus hypospadias is classified into the followings:
    • Anterior: glanular and subcoronal
    • Middle: distal penile, midshaft, and proximal penile.
    • Posterior: penoscrotal, scrotal, and perineal.

Management

  • Treatment incurred surgery to reposition the urethral opening and straighten the penile shaft if required.
  • Treatment is not required in the anterior variety, and repair is done for cosmetic types.
  • Most Optimal time of repair is 6-12 months.
  • The surgical procedure includes meatal advancement or local skin flap advancement along with the removal of the chordee.
  • There is research which concludes that if the hypospadias repair is delayed and done at the adolescent, there is a 95% success rate with no difference between primary and secondary repair

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option B: Urethral opening is most commonly in the perineum

  • The perineal urethral opening is the posterior hypospadias.
  • However, the most common urethral opening in the case of hypospadias is the anterior type, most commonly glanular.

Option C: The urethra opens proximally and dorsally

  • It is a congenital abnormality of anterior urethral and penile development.
  • Hypospadias is characterized by a urethral meatus present ventrally on the penis or scrotum, dorsal winged prepuce (foreskin), and also the chordee, which is the ventral curvature of the penis.
  • All the features can be present at different levels of severity in patients.

​​​​​​​Option D: It is seen in 1 in 1500 boys

  • Hypospadias is the most common urethral malformation.
  • It occurs in 1 in 250 male births.
  • It is multifactorial in inheritance.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child is referred to the pediatric department in the with complaints of an distended abdomen, dribbling of urine with overflow incontinence. On physical examination, there is only a palpable and distended bladder up to the umbilicus with no other abnormalities. A urinary catheterization was performed, which drained 350 mL of clear urine, with immediate relief of the symptoms. This condition in a male child may be due to the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : Option D: Meatal ulcer with scabbing

  • In the above-given case, the presence of an enlarged bladder, dribbling urine, and distended bladder up to the umbilicus is suggestive of the diagnosis of acute urinary retention.
  • Acute urinary retention in a male child may be due to local inflammatory causes like a meatal ulcer with scabbing.

 

Aetiology of urinary retention in children
  • Neurological processes (17%)
  • Severe voiding dysfunction (15%)
  • UTI (13%)
  • Constipation (13%)
  • Adverse drug effect (13%)
  • Local inflammatory causes (7%)
  • Locally invading neoplasms (6%)
  • Benign obstructing lesions (6%)
  • Idiopathic (6%)
  • Combined UTI and constipation (2%)
  • Incarcerated inguinal hernia (2%)

 

Option A: Prostatic radiotherapy

  • Prostatic brachytherapy can lead to swelling of the urethra.
  • The swelling may cause blockage of the urethra, which can lead to urinary retention.
  • Prostatic radiotherapy may not lead to urinary retention in children.

Option B: Urethral stricture

  • Urinary strictures are rare in children.
  • Urinary strictures are associated with sudden urinary retention in adults.

Option C: Hysteria

  • Hysteria is not the common cause of urinary retention in children.
  • Urinary retention can be caused by mechanical obstruction in children.

questions.text: A 19-year-old football player suddenly collapses during the game. He endured no preceding trauma. Immediate resuscitation is initiated, but he passes away before the ambulance arrives. The patient has no chronic medical conditions but complained of occasional exertion-related chest discomfort and dyspnea. A review of family history showed an uncle who died at 40 due to sudden cardiac death. Which of the following gives the pathophysiological mechanism for the patient’s sudden cardiac death?
questions.solution:
Option A: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia

  • The patient presents with arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia (ARVD) clinical features.
  • It is a rare familial disorder that results in ventricular tachycardia and sudden cardiac death in young and healthy individuals.
  • It is autosomal dominant in nature.
  • The pathological hallmark is the fibrofatty replacement of the right ventricular myocardium.
  • ARVD is caused by mutations in genes which encode desmosomal proteins.
  • Patients present with arrhythmias, premature ventricular contractions, ventricular tachycardia, syncope, heart failure and sudden cardiac death.
  • ECG shows an epsilon wave (positive deflection in QRS wave).
  • Diagnosis is based on cardiac MRI.
  • Treatment involves an implantable cardiac defibrillator.

other options

Option B: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is the weakening of the left ventricle of the heart.
  •  It can occur in adults of any age, most commonly in elderly women.
  • It is triggered by severe physical or emotional stress.
  • It presents with signs and symptoms of a heart attack without any change in coronary arteries.

Option C: Atrial septal defect

  • Atrial septal defect presents with exercise intolerance due to secondary pulmonary artery hypertension.
  • It does not lead to sudden cardiac death.

Option D: Eisenmenger complex

  • An eisenmenger complex is a right to left shunt due to pulmonary hypertension.
  • The patient is usually bedridden and cannot participate in activities such as football.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the office with complaints of pain and swelling in her right big toe for 2 weeks. The symptoms are worse at the end of the day. Apart from this, she also reports mild headaches and constipation for two months. Her medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, swelling and tenderness were noted on 1st metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint. The rest of her relevant review is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lead 

  • Hyperuricemia and secondary (saturnine) gout are common findings associated with chronic lead toxicity and are thought to be due to proximal tubular defects resulting in increased tubular reabsorption and decreased secretion of uric acid.
  • Saturnine gout caused by lead poisoning is consistent with gout. The pain and swelling of 1st metatarsophalangeal joint mentioned in the scenario are constant with gout secondary to lead poisoning. 
  • The symptoms like headache and constipation in this patient are also due to lead toxicity. 
  • Lead Toxicity: Lead is a heavy metal and a fundamental earth substance. 
    • Causes: 
      • Paint (older homes, old toys, furniture, crafts) 
      • Occupational exposure 
      • Soil.
      • Drinking water.
      • Folk medicines, ayurvedic, and cosmetics.
      • Children's jewelry and toys etc 

Lead poisoning can have adverse effects on various organs. Signs and symptoms of lead poisoning are as follows: 

Option A: Arsenic 

  • Symptoms of acute arsenic poisoning are headache, confusion, diarrhoea, and drowsiness. Chronic arsenic toxicity can lead to vitamin A deficiency and night blindness.
  • Gout is not associated with arsenic poisoning. 

Option C: Mercury

  • Signs and symptoms of mercury toxicity includes loss of peripheral vision, paraesthesia, lack of coordination of movements, impairment of speech, hearing, ataxia, and muscle weakness.
  • Mercury poisoning does not cause gout. 

Option D: Antimony

  • Antimony is a silvery-white metal that is found in the earth's crust. Its poisoning does not cause secondary gout. 
  • Signs and symptoms of antimony poisoning include gastrointestinal disturbance, bitter taste in the mouth and a characteristic leucocyte count shift on complete blood count(CBC).

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department due to weakness, fatigue and chest discomfort. The patient suffered episodes of fainting and palpitations. There is a family history of sudden death in his sibling at 16 years. His vital signs are normal. Laboratory investigations reveal normal serum cardiac troponin T. Electrocardiogram shows an ST-segment elevation of 4 mm in V1 and V2, recognised as a spontaneous type 1 Brugada pattern. Besides ECG, what other studies are required to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Echocardiography

ECG findings in type 1 Brugada syndrome are as follows:

  • Coved ST-segment elevation >2mm in >1 of V1-V3 followed by a negative T wave.
  • It is also called the Brugada sign
  • Echocardiogram: Differential diagnosis for Brugada is arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia (ARVD), which is fibrofatty deposition in the Right Ventricular wall, making echocardiography a vital investigation to differentiate between the two conditions.

Option A: Stress Test

  • Stress test is not done if the patient has a risk of sudden cardiac death.

Option B: Holter monitor

  • Holter monitoring only use to identify tachyarrhythmias & types of tachyarrhythmias

Option C: Angiography

  • Imaging technique used for visualisation of the lumen of blood vessels and organs of the body
  • it is not used for the diagnosis of Brugada syndrome

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to recurrent syncopal attacks for 2 weeks. It is not associated with dizziness, sweating, chest pain or shortness of breath. He has no medical disorder and does not take any medications. His brother passed away 2 years ago with similar complaints. The ECG reveals a 'saddle back' pattern in leads V1-V2, confirming the diagnosis of Brugada syndrome. Which of the following is not associated with the Brugada syndrome?

choices.text: The treatment of choice is a pacemaker

questions.solution:
Option D: The treatment of choice is a pacemaker

  • Brugada syndrome is a genetic disorder.
  • It occurs due to abnormal channelopathy, which results in diminished inward sodium current in the right ventricular outflow tract epicardium region.
  • A loss of the action potential dome in the right ventricular epicardium due to unopposed transient potassium outward current results in dramatic shortening of the action potential.
  • The sizeable potential difference between the normal endocardium and rapidly depolarized right ventricular outflow epicardium gives rise to S-T segment elevation in V1-V3 in sinus rhythm and predisposes to local ventricular reentry.

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, the arrhythmia syndrome is most common in young male patients (-75%) and is thought to be responsible for the Sudden Unexpected Nocturnal Death Syndrome (SUDS)
  • For patients with syncopal attacks, ICD implantable cardioverter defibrillator is used as it can deliver a DC shock to terminate the arrhythmia developing in these patients and not a pacemaker.

Option A: SCN5A defect

  • SCN5A defect leads to defective Na+ influx
  • Due to a sodium channel defect, a voltage gradient is created between the right ventricular epicardium & normal heart.

Option B: Asymptomatic S-T segment elevation

  • In Brugada syndrome, the enormous potential difference between the normal endocardium and rapidly depolarized right ventricular outflow epicardium gives rise to S-T segment elevation in V1-V3 in sinus rhythm and predisposes to local ventricular reentry.

Option C: Sudden death

  • Brugada syndrome has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern; the arrhythmia syndrome is most common in young male patients (-75%) and is thought to be responsible for the Sudden Unexpected Nocturnal Death Syndrome (SUDS)
  • Sudden death in a sibling is seen.
  • It is the leading cause of sudden nocturnal death in Southeast Asian males.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with ASCVD complained of palpitations for the last 4 hours. On examination, her heart rate was 180 beats/min with Blood pressure 90/60 mmHg. Neck veins are fully distended. On auscultation, carotid artery bruit was present with loud S1 and narrow split S2. The chest had bilateral basal crepitations. Which of the following is not recommended for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Carotid sinus massage

Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia

The ECG in this patient shows narrow complex tachycardia with a heart rate of approximately 180 beats/min, likely paroxysmal supra-ventricular tachycardia.

  • The P waves are absent, and the RR interval is reduced and regular. ST segment depression is noted in most leads.
  • The first line of management is by carotid sinus massage; however, the carotid sinus massage is contraindicated in patients with carotid artery bruit (due to the presence of atherosclerotic plaque in the vessel wall)
  • Known cases of ASCVD (Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease)and atherosclerotic narrowing of the carotid artery (Carotid artery bruit).
  • If a carotid sinus massage is given to this patient, it can lead to the development of embolic stroke due to physical damage to atherosclerotic plaque in the carotid artery.
  • If it is unsuccessful, DC cardioversion is indicated.

Option B: Face ice pack

  • In children, supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is a dangerous dysrhythmia.
  • Traditional vagal techniques, certain pharmaceuticals, cardioversion, and the application of freezing water to the face are all part of the first course of therapy.​​​​​​​

Option C: Adenosine

  • Adenosine will restore normal sinus rhythm so it can be used

Option D: Verapamil

  • Verapamil is an antiarrhythmic drug
  • IV verapamil is used for PSVT for rate control.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of abdominal striae, weight gain and a hump in the posterior neck for the past 2 months. His B.P is 160/100 mmHg. Mark the incorrect statements regarding the condition shown below -
questions.solution:
Option C: Hyperkalemia

  • Presentation of Buffalo hump & Violet striae: Seen in CUSHING'S syndrome
  • In Cushing's syndrome, there is an increase in cortisol(three times) which have mineralocorticoid activity and activates the Epithelial Na+channels, leading to more salt and water coming in, but more K+ and H+ loss leads to Hypokalemic Alkalosis (Metabolic Alkalosis) but NO HYPERKALEMIA
  • Single midnight serum cortisol measurement helps in the diagnosis of the Cushings syndrome
  • Since cortisol is released in stressful situations in the body, so the midnight before sleep time, the body is at its lowest stress, and if the cortisol is increased in this situation, it means the patient is suffering from hypersecretion of cortisol irrespective of pressure and indicates Cushing's syndrome 

Option A: Hyperpigmentation

  • Hyperpigmentation in Cushing's syndrome is due to insulin resistance because of hypercortisolism

Option B: Purplish striae

  • Purplish striae are due to increased central obesity and skin thinning, and fragility

Option D: Metabolic alkalosis

  • Metabolic alkalosis is due to mineralocorticoid activity of the cortisol, which causes hypokalemic alkalosis

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency with complaints of palpitations and chest pain for the last hour. He has also experienced marked dyspnea since then. He has five pack-year smoking history; he does not use alcohol or any other illicit drug. His father died of cardiac disease at age 40, and his mother has psoriasis. The ECG is performed, which suggests broad complex tachycardia. The pulse of the patients is irregularly irregular. The patient is hemodynamically unstable. An anaesthetist is not available to assist with immediate DC cardioversion. What is the best initial treatment option?
questions.solution:
Option D: IV Flecainide

  • Broad complex tachycardia is defined as a heart rate greater than 100 beats per minute and a QRS complex duration greater than 120 milliseconds per minute.
  • The causes of broad complex tachycardia may include coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathies, etc.
  • If the QRS duration is prolonged, the arrhythmia is a wide-complex tachycardia.

  • Regular broad complex tachycardia can be ventricular tachycardia or supraventricular tachycardia with aberrancy.
  • The signs and symptoms of broad complex tachycardia may include chest pain, palpitations, syncope, dyspnea, etc.
  • Patients may have an accessory pathway with rapidly conducted AF.
  • The irregularly irregular rhythm is characteristic of atrial fibrillation.
  • It happens due to abnormal electrical impulses suddenly start firing in the atria.
  • The management of broad complex tachycardia starts with the ABC approach. First Airway, breathing, and circulation are secured.
  • Electrical cardioversion is the preferred treatment for tachyarrhythmias in unstable patients displaying potentially life-threatening adverse signs.
  • Intravenous class-I antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., procainamide, flecainide, propafenone) can be used as well as amiodarone. Still, DC cardioversion is the treatment of choice if there is hemodynamic compromise or rapidly conducted AF down an accessory pathway.

Option A: IV adenosine

  • Patients may have an accessory pathway with rapidly conducted AF.
  • Adenosine should be avoided as it prolongs the AV node refractory period and thus may increase conduction down an accessory pathway, increasing the risk of ventricular fibrillation.

Option B: IV verapamil

  • The patient may have an accessory pathway with rapidly conducted AF.
  • Verapamil should be avoided as it prolongs the AV node refractory period and thus may increase conduction down an accessory pathway.
  • This increases the risk of rapidly conducted AF becoming VF.

Option C: Oral beta-blocker

  • The patient may have an accessory pathway with rapidly conducted AF.
  • Beta-blockers should be avoided as it prolongs the AV node refractory period and thus may increase conduction down an accessory pathway.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient department for a routine health visit. He has no presenting complaints. He works as an accountant in a construction company. He does not smoke but drinks alcohol on social occasions. He has a family history of diabetes mellitus in two successive generations. He has no symptoms suggestive of diabetes. The physician recommends screening for diabetes based on his family history, and the results show fasting blood glucose levels of 250mg/dl. On further workup, the radio Immune Assay of Insulin is normal. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Maturity-onset diabetes of young

  • MODY presents impaired blood glucose levels induced by diminished insulin release due to an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.
  • The onset of MODY is 25 years or younger
  • The beta cell mass is normal, but decreased insulin secretion occurs.
  • It involves mutations in the nuclear transcription factor gene (most commonly Hepatic nuclear factor 1-alpha) that regulates islet gene expression
  • Patients are responsive to sulfonylurea, which causes increased insulin secretion.

Option B: Wolfram Syndrome

  • Wolfram syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition and neurodegenerative disorder leading to childhood-onset- insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.
  • It also causes:
    • Diabetes insipidus
    • Optic atrophy
    • Deafness.
  • It is a due mutation in a gene named WFSI, which encodes a 100.3 DKa transmembrane protein localized in the endoplasmic reticulum.

Option C: Type 1 diabetes mellitus

  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus has immune-mediated insulinopenia due to reduced beta cell mass.
  • In this condition immune system destroys the beta-pancreatic cell. This is also associated with a mutation in genes associated with T-cell tolerance.
  • Symptoms may include:
    • Extreme thirst
    • Vomiting, upset stomach
    • Dry mouth, blurry vision, and fatigue

Option D: Latent autoimmune Diabetes in adults

  • It is a slow-progressing form of immune-mediated type 1 diabetes mellitus.
  • It leads to a decrease in insulin release because of damage to insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas
  • The onset is over 30 years of age.
  • It often would not require insulin for several months up to years after diagnosis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male is being evaluated after the management of a femoral fracture due to a recent fall. The patient fell after losing his balance while walking on the street a few days ago and had a fracture of the femoral neck. His temperature is 98°F, his blood pressure is 126/80 mmHg, and his pulse is 90 beats per minute. He follows a healthy diet plan. His past medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease, and he is on dialysis. On laboratory evaluation, he is found to have high serum PTH, low serum Ca2+ and high serum PO4+. What is the most likely cause of his laboratory derangement?
questions.solution:
Option C: Reduced Kidney Function

  • This patient has a history of chronic kidney disease and is on dialysis.
  • His laboratory evaluation shows low serum calcium and high serum phosphate levels. He has had a fragility fracture of the femoral neck. This is due to decreased calcium levels.
  • His PTH is high due to hyperparathyroidism secondary to the high phosphorus and low calcium stimulating the parathyroid gland.
  • In secondary hyperparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated in response to chronic hypocalcaemia. While any disorder that results in hypocalcaemia can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism, chronic renal failure and vitamin D deficiency are the most common causes. Stimulation of the parathyroid glands by chronic hypocalcaemia results in hyperplasia of all glands.
  • Secondary hyperparathyroidism can also result from malabsorption (chronic pancreatitis, small bowel disease, malabsorption-dependent bariatric surgery).
  • In this patient, chronic kidney disease has caused the derangement of the calcium and phosphate levels, thus causing the release of PTH from the parathyroid gland.

Option A: Dietary Vitamin D Deficiency

  • Dietary vitamin D deficiency can also cause hyperparathyroidism secondary to decreased calcium levels in the body. But this patient follows a healthy lifestyle and diet. Therefore, his chronic kidney disease is the main cause of these laboratory abnormalities.

Option B: GI Malabsorption

  • GI malabsorption can result in Vitamin D deficiency, which causes decreased calcium absorption from the gut and decreased calcium reabsorption from the kidneys. It may occur due to pancreatitis or small-bowel disease. This patient’s history does not indicate malabsorption syndromes.

Option D: Pituitary Adenoma

  • 85% of the cases of primary hyperparathyroidism are due to solitary parathyroid adenomas. Parathyroid hyperplasia, multiple adenomas, and rare carcinoma cause the other 15% of cases. It causes excess PTH despite normal or increased Calcium levels in the body.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician with complaints of frequent urination, fatigue, and excessive thirst. His blood sugar level is checked, which is 121 mg/dl. The physician prescribes him an Oral glucose tolerance test. All of the following conditions show a False positive oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Exercise

It does not give false positive oral glucose tolerance test because:

  • During exercise, the muscles will consume more glucose; hence blood sugar levels can be normal in a diabetic patient.
  • Exercise also enhances insulin action and carbohydrate tolerance for between 24 to 72 hours.

Option A: Malnourished

  • In malnourished individuals, due to nutritional deficit and physical stress, there is a release of regulatory hormones such as
    • Catecholamines inhibit insulin release and stimulate gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, thus leading to carbohydrate intolerance.
    • Glucocorticoids are also released, which also increase blood glucose by activating various mechanisms.

Option B:  Infectious state

  • In case of infectious conditions, there is the release of regulatory hormones such as cortisol:
    • Increases blood glucose level by gluconeogenesis.
    • Acts as an insulin antagonist, decreasing the release of insulin, thus increasing blood sugar levels and making the body able to survive stress caused by an infectious agent.

Option C: Severe Emotional stress:

  • In emotional stress, there is the release of stress hormones such as:
    • ​​​​​​​Cortisol increase blood glucose level to cope with the increased demand for glucose in stressful situations, especially for the brain. It also causes carbohydrate intolerance by decreasing insulin secretion.
    • Catecholamines such as adrenaline increase blood glucose levels by activating:
  • Glycogenolysis in skeletal muscles and also in liver
  • Increases gluconeogenesis by the liver
  • Causes reduction in glucose uptake by different tissues such as skeletal muscles.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to dysuria and passing foamy urine for 2 weeks. He has had a history of type II diabetes mellitus for 20 years, for which he takes insulin irregularly. The recent laboratory investigations reveal:


	
		
			
			Glucose
			
			
			200mg/dl
			
		
		
			
			Urea
			
			
			52mg/dl
			
		
		
			
			Creatinine
			
			
			1.2mg/dl
			
		
		
			
			Uric acid
			
			
			5.3mg/dl
			
		
	



	
		
			Blood pressure
			160/92mmHg
		
		
			Urine Albumin
			35mg
		
	


The physician suspects a complication of long-standing diabetes mellitus. Which of the following is associated with this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Urine dipsticks can easily detect microalbuminuria
24 hr urine albumin is more sensitive than spot sample urine albumin: urine creatinine
Microalbuminuria correlates with nocturnal spike in Systolic blood pressure
It is the most common cause of death in type II diabetes mellitus.

questions.solution:
Option C: Microalbuminuria correlates with a nocturnal spike in systolic blood pressure

  • The patient presents with clinical features of diabetic nephropathy.
  • Diabetic nephropathy is a microvascular complication of diabetes mellitus.
  • Diabetic nephropathy is initially manifested as microalbuminuria.
  • Microalbuminuria is the urinary albumin excretion of 30-300mg/day.
  • Microalbuminuria correlates with a nocturnal spike in systolic blood pressure.
  • There is a positive link between high blood pressure and microalbuminuria.
  • High blood pressure may cause microalbuminuria by increasing glomerular filtration pressure and subsequently causing kidney damage.
  • Antihypertensive activity decreases microalbuminuria by decreasing intraglomerular pressure and lowering systemic hypertension.
  • Hence, normotensive diabetic patients with microalbuminuria have slightly elevated blood pressure during sleep, which is lowered by antihypertensive therapy.

Option A: Urine dipsticks can easily detect microalbuminuria

  • Sensitive radioimmunoassay methods measure small amounts of urinary albumin in contrast to less sensitive dipstick strips, whose minimal detection is 0.3-0.5%

Option B: 24 hr urine albumin is more sensitive than spot sample urine albumin: urine creatinine

  • 24-hour urine albumin values are affected by the following:
    • Exercise
    • Dietary protein
    • Sustained erect posture
  • ​​​​​​​This problem is circumvented with spot sample urine albumin to urine creatinine values.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

Option D: It is the most common cause of death in type II diabetes mellitus

  • Myocardial infarction is the most common cause of death in type II diabetes mellitus.
  • Heart disease in a patient with diabetes is due to coronary atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child is brought to the pediatric department with complaints of nausea and vomiting. The child is malnourished, along with mild to moderate dehydration. The child had a previous history of cerebral palsy at the 5th month of age. Serum electrolytes and ABGs are also abnormal. Barter syndrome has been diagnosed in the child. Which of the following are associated with bartter syndrome?

choices.text: Urinary calcium increased, and Mineralocorticoid antagonists can not be used
Metabolic acidosis is present, Mineralocorticoid antagonist cannot be used, and normal to low blood pressure
Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis and normal to low blood pressure
Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis, Mineralocorticoid antagonist can not be used and normal to low blood pressure

questions.solution:
Option C: Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis, and normal to low blood pressure

  • Bartter syndrome is a renal tubular salt-wasting disorder in which the kidneys cannot reabsorb sodium and chloride in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This results in extracellular fluid volume depletion with low/normal blood pressure.
  • The defect in Barter syndrome in the thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle - increase urinary loss of calcium & nephrocalcinosis
  • The salt wasting and polyuria lead to dehydration - stimulating the R.A.A.S. - secondary hyperaldosteronism. This explains hypokalemia.
  • R.O.M.K. receptors in T.A.L. are affected, leading to urinary loss of potassium.
  • Increased intra-renal prostaglandins and hence indomethacin is prescribed.
  • Secondary aldosteronism explains the development of metabolic alkalosis

Option A: Urinary calcium increased, and Mineralocorticoid antagonist can not be used

  • Mineralocorticoid antagonists are used for the treatment
  • Other agents which are used for the treatment are NSAIDs and A.C.E.I.s/A.R.B.s

Option B: Metabolic acidosis is present, Mineralocorticoid antagonist cannot be used, and normal to low blood pressure

  • Mineralocorticoid antagonists are used for the treatment
  • Moreover, there is metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis.

Option D: Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis, Mineralocorticoid antagonist can not be used and normal to low blood pressure

  • Mineralocorticoid antagonists such as spironolactone can be used to manage Barter syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child presents to the pediatric department with a complaint of nausea and vomiting. The child is malnourished, along with mild to moderate dehydration. The child had a previous history of cerebral palsy at the 5th month of age. Her serum electrolytes and ABGs are also abnormal. Bartter syndrome has been diagnosed in the child. Which of the following is more likely associated with Bartter's and Gitelman's syndrome?

choices.text: Gitelman's syndrome is less common than Bartter's syndrome
Bartter's syndrome has a milder clinical course as compared to Gitelman's syndrome
Gitelman's syndrome presents at a late age and is characterized by prominent neuromuscular signs and symptoms
Growth retardation occurs in the Gittleman syndrome

questions.solution:
Option C: Gitelman's syndrome presents at a late age and is characterized by prominent neuromuscular signs and symptoms

  • Gitelman's syndrome is more common than Bartter's syndrome and has a generally milder clinical course with a later age of presentation.
  • It is characterized by prominent neuromuscular symptoms and signs, including fatigue, weakness, carpopedal spasm, cramps, and tetany.

Features
