(PGE2)

 

 

Option A: Gitelman's syndrome is less common than Barter's syndrome

  • Gitelman's syndrome is more common than Bartter's syndrome and has a generally milder clinical course with a later age of presentation.

Option B: Barter's syndrome has a milder clinical course as compared to Gitelman's syndrome

  • Gitelman's syndrome is the milder course, not the barter syndrome

Option D: Growth retardation occurs in the Gittleman syndrome

  • Growth retardation is seen in Bartter syndrome.
  • It is usually absent in Gittleman syndrome

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child brought by her mother complains of bone pain and short stature. The mother also gives a history of 3-5 episodes of foul-smelling diarrhoea since 4 months. On Examination patient appears pale, the abdomen is soft, non-tender and non-distended, and bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory investigations show iron, folate, and vitamin D deficiency. The doctor also orders serology for IgA tissue transglutaminase, which comes back positive and a probable diagnosis of celiac disease is made. Which of the following statement is most appropriate regarding Celiac disease?

choices.text: Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries

questions.solution:
Option A: Increases risk of GI lymphoma

  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune condition caused by an abnormal adaptive immune response to gluten-containing foods.
  • Individuals may experience diarrhoea with malabsorption, fatigue, weight loss bloating and gas abdominal discomfort, nausea and vomiting constipation.
  • Extra-intestinal manifestations include iron deficiency anaemia, Short stature, delayed puberty, osteopenia, skin disorders, and neurological problems.
  • Untreated celiac disease patients, particularly those identified at an older age, have a significantly elevated chance of acquiring enteropathy-associated intestinal T cells lymphoma (EATL).
  • The mechanism behind the high correlation between EATL and celiac disease is unclear. However, antigen-driven T cell proliferation and less direct pro-proliferative effects of chronic inflammation are plausible explanations.

Option B: Gluten diet is advised

  • Complete gluten free diet is advised in these patients
  • Failure to respond to the dietary changes could lead to complications of celiac disease

Option C: Diagnosed on CT scan.

  • The best method for serological diagnosis is the enzyme-linked immunosorbent test (ELISA), which detects IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies in the blood (ELISA).
  • The intestinal biopsy obtained during endoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing celiac disease.
  • A Computerised tomography (CT) scan is not utilised to diagnose celiac disease.

Option D: Most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries

  • Undernutrition is the most common cause of malnutrition in developing countries, not celiac disease.

questions.text: A 28yrs old male patient presented with a history of two episodes of hematemesis over 48 hours. There was no history of the acid peptic disease, NSAID intake, or chronic liver disease. On examination, his heart rate was 110 beats/min & noted to be pallor. On upper GI endoscopy, findings revealed a persistent calibre artery. All of the following are true about persistent calibre artery except:

choices.text: Thermal coagulation is an effective option for the management

questions.solution:
Option D: Deep enteroscopy is useful

  • A persistent calibre artery is called Dieulafoy's lesion. It is a large calibre arteriole that runs beneath the gut mucosa and bleeds via pinpoint mucosal erosion.
  • For the management of bleeding in Dieulafoy's lesion, endoscopic therapy like thermal coagulation or band ligation is effective.
  • In case of failure to control bleeding with the above methods, angiographic embolization is used.
  • Deep enteroscopy is used in patients with diffuse small bowel pathology like vascular ectasia.

Option A: Thermal coagulation is an effective option for the management

  • Thermal coagulation is gaining popularity for treating cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) in cervical cancer screening programs in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) due to the unavailability of gas and high maintenance for cryotherapy.
  • Thermal coagulation is an alternative ablative technique using electricity to destroy the premalignant cervical lesions by heating.
  • The device is small and lightweight, making it practical in an outpatient setting with minimal complications.
  • These advantages are significant in rural and outreach settings.

Option B: Angiographic embolization is useful

  •  Angiographic embolization is an effective technique to control bleeding after blunt trauma to the liver or pelvis.
  • Its role in penetrating trauma to the abdomen has not been studied.
  • Embolization procedures stops blood flow to a specific blood vessel
  • Treatment works by placing a substance in the vessel to prevent blood from flowing through it.
  • The patient may need this procedure if the patient has excessive bleeding, a vascular malformation or a tumour.

Option C: Bleeds via pin point mucosal erosion

  • Erosive gastritis is gastric mucosal erosion caused by damage to mucosal defences.
  • It is typically acute, manifesting with bleeding, but may be subacute or chronic with few or no symptoms.
  • Diagnosis is by endoscopy.
  • Treatment is supportive, with removing the inciting cause and initiating acid-suppressant therapy.
  • Gastric erosive changes are a common cause of UGI bleeding, and hemorrhagic erosive gastritis is thought to be responsible for 10% to 20% of upper tract bleeding. Other causes that may result in gastric mucosal erosions include Crohn's disease and viral gastritis, such as cytomegalovirus or herpesvirus.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a study on the morphological spectrum of iron deficiency anaemia on blood smear of anaemic patients. All of the following are true about iron deficiency anaemia, except?

choices.text: Most common cause of anaemia in India

questions.solution:
Option A: Hyper-segmented neutrophils

  • Hypersegmented neutrophils (more than 5 lobes of neutrophils) are seen in vitamin B12 and folate deficiency.
  • Therefore, this is not correct about iron deficiency anaemia.

Option B: Microcytosis precedes hypochromia

  • In peripheral smear, the red cells are small (microcytic) and pale (hypochromic). 
  • Normal red cells with sufficient haemoglobin have a zone of central pallor measuring about one-third of the cell diameter.
  • In established iron deficiency, the zone of pallor is enlarged; haemoglobin may be seen only in a narrow peripheral rim.
  • Therefore, it is characterized by a microcytic hypochromic peripheral smear.

Option C: Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)<50%

  • The reference range for MCHC in adults is 33.4-35.5 g/dL.
  • If MCHC is below 33.4 g/dL, it specifies low MCHC.
  • Low MCHC indicates iron deficiency anaemia.

Option D: Most common cause of anaemia in India

  • Iron deficiency anaemia is the most common cause of anaemia in India.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented with complaints of 2 episodes of hematemesis. Initial investigations revealed Hb of 7.2g/dl. She was advised to have a UGI endoscopy done. Which of the following finding on upper GI endoscopy indicates the most negligible chances of re-bleeding after hematemesis episodes?
questions.solution:
Option B: Clean-based ulcer

  • Most patients with hematemesis have a re-bleed within the next 3 days of an episode.
  • UGIE is diagnostic and prognostic as a clean-based ulcer has the slightest chance of re-bleeding, while the visible bleeding vessel has the highest chance.
  • Endoscopic intervention is indicated in active bleeding, non-bleeding visible vessel, and active bleeding or visible vessel exposed after adherent clot removal.
  • These are ulcers with a clean base or with flat blood spots.

 

Option A: Adherent clot on the ulcer

  • An adherent clot is called a red, maroon, or black protuberance greater than 3 mm in diameter that could not be dislodged by forceful irrigation with water.
  • It is typically seen as a barium-filled ulcer crater's smooth or irregular filling defect.
  • Granulation tissue or debris in the ulcer may produce similar findings.
  • Symptoms may include sudden, severe pain in the belly (abdomen), usually in the upper abdomen.

 

Option C: Gastric ulcer with AV malformation

  • An arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is an abnormal tangle of blood vessels connecting arteries and veins, which disrupts normal blood flow and oxygen circulation.
  •  Arteries are responsible for taking oxygen-rich blood from the heart to the brain. Veins carry the oxygen-depleted blood back to the lungs and heart.
  • An AVM occurs when arteries in the brain connect directly to nearby veins without having the usual small vessels (capillaries) between them.
  • The exact cause of cerebral AVM is unknown. However, evidence suggests a genetic cause.

 

Option D: Visible bleeding vessel

  • There are four commonly used endoscopic techniques in treating a bleeding ulcer: injection therapy, thermal coagulation, endoscopic clipping, and, most recently, hemostatic powders that are sprayed onto the bleeding ulcer.
  • An endoscopy procedure may help to see if and where GI is bleeding and the bleeding's cause.
  • In upper GI bleeding, an IV drug known as a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is given to suppress stomach acid production.
  • Severe internal bleeding is life-threatening. Perforation or serious bleeding may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the hospital with a complaint of mucosal bleeding on trauma. She has a history of menorrhagia. On investigations, BT and PTT are prolonged. The Ristocetin assay is positive. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: von Willebrand disease

  • This patient with mucosal bleeding, menorrhagia, prolonged BT and PTT and positive ristocetin assay likely has von Willebrand disease.
  • It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder due to deficient von Willebrand factor.
  • Ristocetin fails to cause platelet agglutination, which is diagnostic of this disorder.
  • There is an increased bleeding tendency in this disorder.

Option A: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

  • In this disorder, there is immune-mediated destruction of platelets.
  • BT is elevated, but PTT is normal.
  • The ristocetin assay is negative in this disorder.

Option B: Hemophilia A

  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder resulting in factor VIII deficiency.
  • BT is normal, but PTT is elevated.
  • The ristocetin assay is negative.

Option C: Hemophilia B

  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder resulting in the deficiency of factor IX.
  • BT is normal, but PTT is elevated.
  • The ristocetin assay is negative.

questions.text: A patient arrived at the OP with blood in his stools. Hematochezia (the passage of gross blood from the rectum) is commonly associated with lower GI haemorrhage; however, it can also be caused by which one of the following?

choices.text: Bleeding from a source in the right colon
Lower GI bleeding with rapid transit of blood through the intestines

questions.solution:
Option D: Lower GI bleeding with rapid transit of blood through the intestines

  • Hematochezia is the passage of fresh blood per anus, usually in or with stools.
  • Hematochezia usually comes from a colonic site, although blood rapidly transported from the upper gastrointestinal tract can be red when passed.
  • In older patients, massive lower intestinal haemorrhage is frequently caused by a bleeding diverticulum or an arteriovenous malformation.
  • In adults, the most common causes are haemorrhoids and diverticulosis.

 

Option A: Bleeding from a source in the right colon

  • Colon bleeding is a symptom of a disorder in the digestive tract.
  • The blood often appears in stool or vomit but is not always visible, though it may cause the stool to look black or tarry.
  • The bleeding can range from mild to severe and can be life-threatening.
  • Conditions like haemorrhoids, anal fissures, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), ulcers and colorectal cancer can be caused.

 

Option B: Ingestion of bismuth

  • Bismuth subsalicylate treats diarrhoea, heartburn, and upset stomach in adults and children 12 years of age and older.
  • Bismuth subsalicylate is in a class of medications called antidiarrheal agents.
  • Side effects of bismuth:
  • abdominal pain
  • black or 'hairy' tongue.
  • clay-coloured or grey-black stools
  • constipation (may be chronic)
  • Bismuth toxicity causes delirium, psychosis, ataxia, myoclonus, and seizures.

 

Option C:  Ingestion of supplemental iron

  • Taking high doses of iron supplements (especially on an empty stomach) can cause an upset stomach, constipation, nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhoea.
  • Large amounts of iron might also cause more severe effects, including stomach lining inflammation and ulcers.
  • Iron toxicity can be classified as corrosive or cellular.
  • Ingested iron can have an extremely corrosive effect on the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa, manifesting as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, hematemesis, and diarrhoea; patients may become hypovolemic of significant fluid and blood loss.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is admitted to the emergency ward with shortness of breath. On examination, he has a water-hammer pulse. After diagnosing, the cardiologist asks his junior residents about a special type of murmur called the Austin flint murmur. Which is correct about Austin Flint's murmur?
questions.solution:
Option A: Soft, low, pitched, mid-diastolic murmur

Auscultation findings in Aortic regurgitation:

  • The aortic valve closure sound (A2 ) is usually absent in patients with severe AR.
  • A systolic ejection sound is audible in patients with BAV disease, and occasionally an S4 also may be heard.
  • The murmur of chronic AR is typically a high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo diastolic murmur, heard best in the third intercostal space along the left sternal border.
  • This murmur is brief in patients with mild AR, but as the severity increases, it generally becomes louder and longer, indeed holodiastolic.
  • When the murmur is soft, it can be heard best with the stethoscope's diaphragm, with the patient sitting up, leaning forward, and with the breath held in forced expiration.
  • In patients with AR caused by primary valvular disease, the diastolic murmur is usually louder along the left than the right sternal border.
  • However, when the murmur is louder along the right sternal border, it suggests that the AR is caused by aneurysmal dilation of the aortic root.
  • "Cooing" or musical diastolic murmurs suggest the version of an aortic cusp vibrating in the regurgitant stream.
  • A mid-systolic ejection murmur is frequently audible in isolated AR.
  • It is generally heard best at the heart's base and transmitted along the carotid arteries.
  • This murmur may be quite loud without signifying aortic obstruction.
  • A third murmur sometimes heard in patients with severe AR is the Austin Flint murmur, a soft, low-pitched, rumbling mid-to-late diastolic murmur.
  • It is probably produced by the diastolic displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve by the AR stream and is not associated with hemodynamically significant mitral obstruction.
  • The auscultatory features of AR are intensified by strenuous and sustained handgrip, which augments systemic vascular resistance.
  • In acute severe AR, the elevation of LV end-diastolic pressure may lead to early closure of the mitral valve, a soft S1, a pulse pressure that is not particularly wide, and a soft, short, early diastolic murmur of AR.

Option B: Soft low pitched, mid-systolic murmur

  • The murmur of Austin-flint is mid to late diastolic, not systolic.

Option C: Harsh high, pitched, mid-diastolic murmur

  • The Austin flint murmur is soft and low-pitched.

Option D: Harsh high, pitched, mid-systolic murmur

  • The murmur of Austin flint is soft, low pitched and mid to late diastolic

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient known case of PCOS who is being treated for infertility and was prescribed clomiphene citrate 20 days ago for ovulation induction has now presented with sudden onset of abdominal pain and distension with ascites reported on abdominal ultrasound. What is the most probable cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ovarian Hyperstimulation syndrome

  • A woman with a history of ovulation induction with/ without ovulation trigger, presenting with complaints of pain abdomen and abdominal distension, must always raise suspicion of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).
  • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is a medical complication that is completely iatrogenic and unique to stimulatory infertility treatment.
  • Its symptoms result from ovarian enlargement and fragility, extravascular fluid accumulation, and intravascular volume depletion.
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor, whose expression in granulosa cells and serum is augmented by hCG, and a variety of other inflammatory cytokines have been implicated in the pathogenesis of this disease.
  • This tends to be more severe with multiple gestations.
  • Clinical features are abdominal distension, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Management is by monitoring input and output as it is a self-limiting condition and also by:
  • Intravascular fluid intake to replenish the volume
  • Symptomatic treatment, like the tapping of the ascites and pleural effusion in cases of severity.

Option A: Uterine rupture

  • Uterine rupture is a complication of late pregnancy where a previous uterine scar (previous cesarean section scar) ruptures as the patient goes into labour. It is unlikely here as the patient is only at around day 25 of her cycle.

Option B: Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

  • Abdominal pain and distension could be a presentation of ruptured ectopic pregnancy but occur only as early as 4-6 weeks of conception. Also a history of ovulation induction points more towards OHSS. However, ruptured ectopic or ovarian cyst remains to be the most important differential here.

Option C: Multifetal pregnancy causing uterine distension

  • A multifetal pregnancy does not cause pain or abdominal distension in early pregnancy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fertility. She has been unable to conceive for 2 years despite regular intercourse with her husband twice weekly. Menarche occurs at the age of 12 years, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4 to 5 days. She is undergoing evaluation for infertility. She is being monitored for ovulation with serial ultrasounds and LH levels. Ovulation in this patient is expected to occur how many hours after an LH surge is demonstrated?
questions.solution:
Option C : 36 hours

  • The patient in the question has regular cycles, thus are expected to be ovulatory
  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.
  • The midcycle LH surge is responsible for a dramatic increase in the follicle's local concentrations of prostaglandins and proteolytic enzymes. These substances progressively weaken the follicular wall and ultimately allow a perforation to form.

Option A : 12 hours

  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.

Option B : 24 hours

  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.

Option D : 48 hours

  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 34-36 hours, and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old post-menopausal woman presents in the gynaecology clinic with complaints of vaginal spotting for 10 days. She has no other comorbidities except a known case of uterine prolapse for the last 2 years. USG reveals an endometrial thickness of 1mm and atrophic ovaries. All of the following are likely causes of her bleeding , EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A: Bleeding disorder

  • Bleeding disorders are least likely to be associated only with post-menopausal bleeding.
  • Since the woman is 60 years old and post-menopausal with complaints of vaginal bleeding for the last 10 days only, bleeding disorder is unlikely in the absence of other symptoms in the past.
  • Bleeding disorders may also manifest as heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB), intermenstrual bleeding (PMB) and post-coital bleeding (PCB).
  • Coagulopathies and bleeding disorders usually start at a young age, and women may notice symptoms at the onset of menarche.
  • Coagulation disorders also present other symptoms, such as bruising and bleeding from other sites.

Option B: Vaginal atrophy

  • Vaginal atrophy is common in menopausal women due to estrogen deficiency and can lead to postmenopausal bleeding. Local estrogen is likely to help, once malignancies are ruled out.

Option C : Decubitous ulcer

 

  • The woman, in this case, has had uterine prolapse for the last 2 years. Therefore, decubitus ulcer appears likely to be the cause of her bleeding.
  • Decubitus ulcers occur on the most dependent part of prolapse and may cause bleeding.
  • It is due to venous congestion, abrasion and localized tissue damage to exposure of the uterus outside the pelvis.

Option D : Cervical cancer

  • Cervical cancer is usually associated with post-coital bleeding but manifests as post-menopausal bleeding.
  • A post-menopausal woman presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding should be investigated thoroughly to rule out possible cervical malignancy, since it is the most common cause of postmenopausal bleeding in our country.
  • Post-coital bleeding is a typical feature of carcinoma of the cervix. In the progression of the disease, patients may also present with several distressing symptoms such as incontinence, pain and anaemia due to vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is least likely to help assess ovulation in a woman with infertility, irregular menstrual cycles, insomnia, and anxiety?
questions.solution:
Option D: Levels of oestradiol

  • Levels of estrogen start increasing in the proliferative phase, peak prior to ovulation, and then declines thereafter.
  • Measurement of estrogen levels is not done, therefore, to assess ovulation.

Option A: USG

  • USG, especially a transvaginal scan, can serially assess the growth of the follicle and its sudden shrinkage, suggesting ovulation.
  • It is done starting from day 9 when a dominant follicle should be seen, and then it is followed up for the increase in its size and subsequently rupture.
  • This follicular monitoring is also indispensable in patients with infertility on ovulation induction.

Test for ovulation

  1. Cervix mucus changes.
  2. Basal body temperature: Increases during ovulation by 0.5º F.
  3. Vaginal cytology: Vaginal smear microscopy for calculating the ratio of parabasal, intermediate and superficial cells.
  4. Serum progesterone: A simple blood test is done at D21 or 7 days before expected menses. A value of ≥ 3 ng suggests an ovulatory cycle.
  5. Endometrial biopsy: Demonstrate secretory changes in the endometrium.
  6. TVS - to see follicular rupture monitoring.
  7. Urinary LH kit.
  8. Diagnostic laparoscopy.

 

Option B: Levels of progesterone

  • Serum progesterone on day 21 of the cycle, a value >= 3ng/mL, is suggestive that ovulation has occurred.

Option C: Temperature changes

  • Progesterone is a thermogenic hormone. Secretion of progesterone following ovulation causes a temperature rise of about 0.5 to 1°F over the baseline temperature. Ovulation is assumed after 3 consecutive days of raised temperatures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old menopausal woman, frail and weak, presents in the gynecology clinic with complaints of post-coital bleeding and a history of weight loss for the last few months. She has a history of a kidney transplant a few years back and was taking prednisolone and Azathioprine. What important cause of such bleeding should be ruled out?
questions.solution:
Option A: Carcinoma Cervix

  • Since the patient is 55 years of age, malignancy must be ruled out.
  • Vaginal bleeding is the most common symptom in patients with cervix cancer.
  • It is often post-coital bleeding but may also occur as irregular or post-menopausal bleeding.
  • Patients with advanced disease may present with malodorous vaginal discharge, obstructive uropathy and renal failure.
  • Post-coital bleeding is a typical feature of carcinoma of the cervix.
  • The advanced disease also presents with pain (due to malignant infiltration of the spinal cord), incontinence (due to vesicovaginal fistulae), anaemia (from chronic vaginal bleeding) and pronounced weight loss.
  • Since this patient also presented with a history of kidney transplant and immunosuppressants such as prednisolone (corticosteroids) and Azathioprine, this may have predisposed her to malignant changes in the cervix.
  • Immunosuppressive therapy reduces the efficiency with which viruses are cleared by the immune system, making patients susceptible to Human Papillomavirus (HPV), which triggers an oncogenic process. This, in turn, leads to cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN).

Option B: Carcinoma Endometrium

Carcinoma of the cervix is most likely to present as post-coital bleeding than endometrial malignancy.

This patient  does not have any other comorbidities such as obesity, hypertension and diabetes. However in any case of postmenopausal bleeding such as this, endometrial cancer too must be ruled out, specially if endometrial thickness is > 4mm on TVS

Option C: Fibroid uterus

  • Fibroids are benign estrogen-dependent tumours, also known as leiomyoma.
  • Most fibroids are asymptomatic, but they are sometimes mostly associated with abnormal uterine bleeding, including heavy menstrual and intermenstrual bleeding.
  • Fibroids are less likely to be associated with post-coital bleeding in post-menopausal age group since these are tumors of reproductive age.

Option D: Adenomyosis

  • Adenomyosis is a uterine condition which is mostly accompanied by endometriosis. In adenomyosis, endometrial tissue and stroma are found deep within the myometrium.
  • Adenomyosis is mostly a pre-menopausal presentation.
  • 70% of women with adenomyosis present with abnormal uterine and heavy menstrual bleeding.
  • Post coital bleeding is usually not a feature

questions.text: What factor is accountable for transforming the gonad into testes, leading to the development of a male?
questions.solution:
Option A: Presence of SRY gene

  • The human gonad is a bipotential gonad till 5 weeks of intrauterine development, which implies it has the potential to develop into either ovary or testes
  • Gonads acquire male or female characteristics only after 6 weeks of development, i.e., in the 7th week of development.
  • Gonadal differentiation is an active process directed by the presence or absence of the SRY gene.
  • The presence of the SRY gene will differentiate gonads into the testis.
  • Absence will lead to the differentiation of gonads into ovaries.

 

 

Option B: Lack of SRY gene

  • Lack of SRY gene or absence of SRY gene will lead to failure of the testicle formation.

 

Option C: Presence of AMH

  • The presence of the anti-mullerian hormone (AMH) is responsible for suppressing structures that would otherwise form from the paramesonephric duct.

 

Option D: Presence of Testosterones

  • The presence of testosterone during development leads to the formation of male external characteristics.

questions.text: 18 year old female presents with an ovarian mass, her serum LDH & placental alkaline phosphate are found to be elevated. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B : The given scenario suggests the diagnosis of Dysgerminoma

  • Most common germ cell malignancy
  • Can be bilateral in 10-15 % cases (all other non epithelial ovarian tumors are unilateral)
  • High risk: dysgenetic gonads, testicular feminisation syndrome
  • Tumour markers: LDH, PLAP, (hcg may be raised in some but AFP is normal)
  • In Dysgerminoma, conservative surgery (U/L Salpingo-Oophorectomy) recommended as most patient are Young girls
  • Post operative Chemotherapy gives 90% success
  • Dysgerminoma is also very sensitive to radiotherapy.

Option A : Bilateral oophorectomy is not done here in order to conserve ovarian function and fertility.

Option C :Treatment involves unilateral surgery which is followed up with chemotherapy or radiotherapy;

Option D : Hysterectomy is not done in order to conserve reproductive function in young patients, also a concurrent hysterectomy gives no added advantage.

questions.text: An embryologist is studying the sex-determining region of the Y (SRY) chromosome. The human gonad is a bipotential gonad till the SRY gene acts upon it to form testes. The absence of this gene causes the gonad to develop into an ovary. This implies it has the potential to develop into either ovary or testes, and any deviation at this point can lead to abnormal genitalia in the offspring. The gonad remains bipotential till what period of gestation?
questions.solution:
Option A: 7th week of development

  • The human gonad is a bipotential gonad till 5 weeks of intrauterine development, which implies it has the potential to develop into either ovary or testes
  • Gonads acquire male or female characteristics only after 6 weeks of development, i.e., in the 7th week of development.
  • Gonadal differentiation is an active process directed by the presence or absence of the SRY gene.
  • The presence of the SRY gene will differentiate gonads into the testis.
  • Absence will lead to the differentiation of gonads into ovaries.

 

 

Option B: 9th week of development

  • In the 9th week, the baby's skeleton is forming.

 

Option C: 12th week of development

  • The 12th week is nearly the end of the first trimester, and the baby's vital organs and parts will be in their place.

 

Option D: 4th week of development

  • During the 4th week, the 1st pharyngeal arch begins to develop, located between the stomodeum and the 1st pharyngeal groove.

questions.text: A 60-year-old post-menopausal woman presents to the physician with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other physical examinations are unremarkable. On examination, there is purulent discharge coming from the cervix. The ultrasound of the patient suggests pus in the endometrial cavity. The symptoms of the will not be seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Carcinoma of the vulva

  • Carcinoma of the vulva is the cancer of the vulva, which is the outer portion of the female genitals. It most commonly affects the labia majora. The clitoris and labia minora are less likely to be affected.
  • Its symptoms include itching, changes in the skin and bleeding from the vulva and not pyometra
  • Pyometra implies the presence of pus in the uterus.
  • Conditions associated with pyometra  
    1. Carcinoma of the cervix (Most common cause in India)
    2. Carcinoma of endometrium
    3. Pelvic radiotherapy
    4. TB
    5. Senile endometritis

Option A: Pelvic radiotherapy

  • Pelvic radiotherapy causes inflammation which results in foul-smelling vaginal discharge and may lead to pyometra

Option B: Carcinoma of the cervix

  • Carcinoma of the cervix is associated with foul-smelling vaginal discharge and pyometra

Option D: Carcinoma of the endometrium

  • Carcinoma of the endometrium is associated with pyometra

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes complaining of heavy menstrual bleeding for the last 6 months. She started menstruation at 13 years of age and had regular menstruation until the last 6 months. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the least likely reason for abnormal bleeding at her age?
questions.solution:
Option C: Endometrial atrophy

  • Thinning of the endometrium of endometrial atrophy is a common cause of AUB or abnormal uterine bleeding in post-menopausal women not young and reproductive as in the above case.
  • Low hormone levels after menopause are responsible.
  • A table of different etiologies of abnormal uterine bleeding in the different age group are given below

 

INFANCY

Option A: Adenomyosis

  • it is a benign disease characterized by hyperplasia of the endometrial basal layer
  • peak incidence at 35–50 years 
  • The exact aetiology is unknown, though some risk factors have been identified:
    • Endometriosis
    • Uterine fibroids
    • Parity 
  • Clinical features:
    • May be asymptomatic 
    • Dysmenorrhea
    • Abnormal uterine bleeding
    • Chronic pelvic pain, aggravated during menses
    • A globular, uniformly enlarged uterus that is soft but tender on palpation

 

Option B: Fibroids

  • A benign, hormone-sensitive smooth muscle tumour of the uterus arises from  myometrium and can be submucosal, intramural, or subserosal.
  • The myometrium also develops vascular changes.
  • It is the most common benign pelvic tumor in women of reproductive age group and causes mentstrual abnormalities like menorrhagia, polymenorrhea, intermenstrual spotting etc along with pain, dysmenorrhea, pressure symptoms and infertility.

 

Option D: Polyps

  • Focal begin growth in the uterine wall, which can be sessile or pedunculated, single or multiple.
  • They contain smooth muscle cells and blood vessels
  • Prevalent in post-menopausal women and are also seen in premenopausal.
  • Usually asymptomatic, may cause irregular menstrual bleeding, spotting, menorrhagia, post-menopausal bleeding.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of itching, discomfort, and vaginal discharge for the last 2 years. She also complains of some degree of dysuria and vaginal spotting. On examination, she has vulvar growth. On a biopsy, the findings are suggestive of squamous cell cancer of the vulva. Which of the following is most  associated finding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lichen Sclerosis

  • All of the above are associated with Vulvar cancer. The etiologic agents, however, differ according to the age group.
  • Two distinct etiologic entities of squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva exist.
  • Basaloid or warty types account for 40% of vulvar squamous cell carcinomas.
    • These tend to be multifocal, usually common in younger patients.
    • This type is directly related to HPV infection, Usual type VIN (VIN), immunosuppression and cigarette smoking.
  • Keratinizing type accounts for about 60% of cases of squamous cell carcinoma.
    • These tend to be unifocal, found Predominantly in older patients, and are not related to HPV.

 

 

Basaloid or warty types

 

 Keratinizing

 
40% of squamous

 

 60 % of squamous

 
Multifocal

 

 Unifocal

 
Younger patients

 

 Older patients

 
Related to HPV

 

 Not related to HPV, related to lichen sclerosis

 
Usual VIN, immunosuppression, smoking-related

 

 Differentiated VIN, chronic inflammatory dermatosis

 

 

risk factors of vulvar cancer:

  • HPV infection
  • Herpes simplex virus type 2 infection
  • History of smoking
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Immunosuppression
  • Chronic vulvar disease
  • Previous malignancies of the lower genital tract
  • Age >60 years

 

Option B: Human papillomavirus

  • HPV is associated with the development of vulvar cancer in young and sexually active females and not post-menopausal women.

Option C: Immunosuppression

  • It can be a risk factor in the development of vulvar cancer but has no direct involvement in the development of vulvar cancer in older women.

Option D: Smoking

  • Smoking is an important risk factor for squamous carcinoma worldwide, but it is generally not directly related to the development of vulvar carcinoma in older women.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl with irregular menstrual bleeding for 3 months. Menarche at 13 years old. Cycle length varies between 35 to 45 days. Bleeding lasts for 7 to 12 days and sometimes involves heavy bleeding. Negative pregnancy test. Multiple normal ultrasounds and normal coagulation profile. Which of the following is true regarding her condition?

choices.text: Bleeding is likely to be associated with a missed pelvic pathology and an MRI should be advised
Bleeding is most likely due to estrogen breakthrough
Cycle length increases due to a longer secretory phase

questions.solution:
Option B: Bleeding is most likely due to estrogen breakthrough

  • The patient appears to have anovulatory bleeding, which is more common at the start and end of the reproductive age group, post-menarchal and premenopausal age groups.

Anovulation:

  • Absence of ovulation due to immature HPO axis (hypothalamic pituitary ovarian axis).
  • Bleeding is a type of estrogen breakthrough instead of progesterone withdrawal.
  • The absence of ovulation leads to a lack of progesterone.
  • Endometrium keeps building up in response to estrogen and finally due to ischemia, it breaks down resulting in irregular prolonged bleeding.
  • Causes of anovulation include eating disorders, stress, excessive exercise, endocrine disorders like thyroid and diabetes and PCOD.
  • The length of the luteal phase is always fixed at 14 days. The prolonged cycle length is due to a longer follicular phase, as ovulation is delayed or absent.
  • Hormonal therapy with combined or progesterone-only therapy is the first line of management.

 

Option A: Bleeding is likely associated with a missed pelvic pathology, and an MRI should be advised.

  • MRI is not required here as the most likely cause here is an immature HPO axis leading to anovulation, which will not be picked up on MRI. Multiple USG scan have already ruled out any major pelvic pathology.

 

Option C: Oral contraceptives provide no benefit

  • Oral contraceptive pills given in cyclical fashion, will regularize the patient's cycle.

 

Option D: Cycle length increases due to a longer secretory phase

  • The length of luteal phase is always fixed at 14 days, the prolonged cycle length is due to a longer follicular phase as ovulation is delayed or absent.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to gynecology OPD in an anxious state, reporting early pregnancy loss 1 day back. She reports spontaneous abortion in the 5th week of her pregnancy. She has been married for 5 months. Her HSG reveals two separate cavities of the uterus, cervix and vagina. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Uterus didelphys

  • Uterus didelphys is a complete failure of fusion of Mullerian duct resulting in two uteri, cervix, and vagina.
  • The most common type of uterus anomaly is  septate uterus which causes spontaneous abortion in the first trimester.
  • It can lead to pregnancy complications and dysmenorrhea. Few patients may have surgery to treat uterus didelphys, but most cases don't require it.

 

 

Option B: Bicornuate uterus

  • It is described as a heart-shaped uterus, having two sides instead of one hollow cavity.
  • The cervix and vagina are single

Option C: Subseptate uterus

  • It is a mild form of congenital anomaly in which a half septum is present within the uterus, not infringing on the cervix.

Option D: Unicornuate Uterus

  • A unicornuate uterus is a rare disorder which causes a female to have only half a uterus.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with the complaint of abdominal pain for the past 2 years. She states that she frequently has cramps and lower abdominal pain that lasts for a few days and is usually at the same time every month. She has not attained menarche yet, and she attained breast and pubic hair development at 12. On examination, she has a moderately tender suprapubic mass. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Imperforated hymen

  • This patient's symptoms of cyclical abdominal pain and amenorrhea suggest imperforate hymen.
  • The hymen is an embryological membrane formed by the fusion of the paramesonephric ducts and urogenital sinus.
  • Degeneration of epithelial cells leads to perforation of the central part of the hymen.
  • Failure of the hymen to perforate results in a condition called the imperforate hymen.
  • It presents with amenorrhea due to failure to menstruate.
  • Blood retention during menses stretches the vagina causing hematocolpus, which can result in an abdominal mass and be visualised as a bulging membrane at the vaginal opening.
  • Extension of the retained blood to the uterus is called hematometra.
  • Recurrent cyclical abdominal or pelvic pain occurs in the lower abdomen and vagina. This condition is called cryptomenorrhea.
  • The imperforate hymen may also lead to bowel and bladder issues.
  • The below image shows the retention of menstrual blood, which can lead to hematocolpus, hematometra and hematosalpix, which is an extension of menstrual blood to the fallopian tubes.

 

 

  • It is easily treated with a minor surgical procedure.

 

Option A: Asherman's syndrome

  • It is a condition where scar tissues, called intrauterine adhesions, form inside the uterus or cervix.
  • It occurs due to trauma to the uterine lining.
  • These adhesions obliterate the endometrial cavity and cause secondary amenorrhea.

 

Option B: Testicular feminising syndrome

  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome is due to a defect in the androgen receptor.
  • It is characterised by female external genitalia, with undeveloped vagina, scant or absent axillary and pubic hair.

 

Option D: Uterine agenesis

  • It is due to embryonic growth failure resulting in the underdevelopment of the uterus and vagina. External genitalia is normal.
  • It is a cause of primary amenorrhea.
  • Due to the absence of a uterus, affected individuals do not menstruate.
  • They have normal breast development and axillary and pubic hair growth.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents in the gynecologic OPD with her mother with the complaint of not getting her menses. Her mother says she is worried because all the girls in her school have started getting their periods regularly. On examination, breast development is normal, axillary and pubic hairs are sparse, and the vaginal opening is small and ends in a blind pouch. USG revealed an absent uterus and solid nodular structures in bilateral inguinal regions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • The ultrasound findings suggest the presence of testes, along with the sparsity of axillary and pubic hair, androgen insensitivity syndrome is the most probable diagnosis in the above case.
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome is a disorder in which the individual has a male genotype and female phenotype.
  • Testes and testosterone are present, but receptor dysfunction leads to the development of female sexual characteristics.
  • It has 3 categories depending on the degree of genital masculinisation:
    • Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS)
    • Mild androgen insensitivity syndrome (MAIS)
    • Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome (PAIS)
  • Management is symptomatic by hormone replacement therapy, genitoplasty, and genetic and psychological counselling.
  • Gonadectomy is indicated to reduce the risk of testicular neoplasm.

 

Option B: MRKH

  • Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser Syndrome (MRKH) is a Mullerian agenesis syndrome. It is XX genotype but does not have Mullerian components such as the uterus and upper vagina. But it has normal ovarian function, and normal ovaries can be visualised on ultrasound.
  •   MRKH Androgen insensitivity syndrome
    Genotype XX XY
    Gonad Ovaries Testes
    Breast development Normal Normal
    Pubic and axillary hair Normal Absent (insensitivity to testosterone)
    Vagina Shallow and blind Shallow and blind
    Uterus Absent Absent
    Vulva Normal Normal

 

Option C: Turner syndrome

  • Turner syndrome is an XO genotype with an abnormal female phenotype, i.e., ovaries, breasts, and uterus are all underdeveloped.

 

Option D: Pure gonadal dysgenesis

  • These patients have a female phenotype, and the genotype can be XX or XY. The individual fails to develop secondary sexual characteristics and presents clinically with primary amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination her vitals are normal, and systemic examination is normal however she has a blind vaginal pouch. Per rectal examination shows the absence of a uterus, which is confirmed with an ultrasound. Which of the following is the next most relevant investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B : Karyotyping

  • The patient with primary amenorrhea, here is phenotypic female with absent vagina and uterus
  • 2 most important differentials here
    • Mullerian agenesis : 46 XX
    • Testicular feminization : 46 XY
  • A Karyotyping will be the best to differentiate between the two
  MRKH Androgen insensitivity syndrome
Genotype XX XY
Gonad Ovaries Testes
Breast development Normal Normal
Pubic and axillary hair Normal Absent (insensitivity to testosterone)
Vagina Shallow and blind Shallow and blind
Uterus Absent Absent
Vulva Normal Normal
Sr Androgen levels 20-80 ng/dl 200-800 ng/dl

 

Option A : Prolactin levels may detect hyperprolactinemia which is a cause of amenorrhea, but  it is associated with galactorrhea and not a blind vaginal pouch or absent uterus.

Option C : IVP is done to rule out renal malformations which may be associated with MRKH however this needs to be done a diagnosis of MRKH is made.

Option D : FSH levels may be low in primary amenorrhea due to defect at level of hypothalamus or pituitary, however both of these would be associated with absent secondary sexual characters and not with absent uterus or vagina.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the clinic with the complaint of primary amenorrhea. Her height is 170 cm, and her weight is 45 kg. On examination, there is absent breast development; however, the vagina is normal. Puffiness of her hands and feet is also observed. Ultrasonography reveals a hypoplastic uterus and bilateral ovaries are not visualized. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Turner’s syndrome

This patient’s symptoms are consistent with turner syndrome.

Turner syndrome (45, X) is the most common karyotypic abnormality causing gonadal failure and primary amenorrhea.

Amenorrhea is the result of accelerated atresia of the follicles. The fibrotic ovaries are called streak ovaries.

It is a chromosomal disorder which results from the partial or complete absence of one of the second sex chromosomes (45 XO).

Associated stigmata with Turner syndrome include

    • Gonadal Failure
    • Short stature
    • Webbed neck
    • Shield chest
    • Cubitus valgus
    • low hair line
    • high arched palate
    • multiple pigmented nevi
    • Short fourth metacarpals
  • Gonadal dysgenesis can cause premature ovarian failure.
  • Associated medical conditions include cardiac (30% have coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve, hypertension), renal (horseshoe kidney), autoimmune (thyroiditis), increased risk of fractures and osteoporosis.
  • Most females will require hormone replacement therapy for proper breast development and begin menstruation.
  • Turner syndrome may be diagnosed before birth or shortly after birth, but in some cases, it is diagnosed during adolescence and early adulthood.  
  • The image below portrays a few clinical features associated with Turner syndrome.

Option B: Swyer syndrome

  • Swyer syndrome is much rarer.
  • It is characterised by failed development of the sex glands, i.e. testes and ovaries. Hence uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes and upper 4/5th of the vagina are made. The urogenital sinus makes the lower 1/5th vagina.
  • It is the 46XY 'female'.
  • Since there are no working androgens, there is no masculinisation and no feminisation since there is no estrogen production because the ovaries are replaced by fibrous tissue.

Option C: Mullerian agenesis

    • It is due to embryonic growth failure resulting in the underdevelopment of the uterus and vagina. External genitalia is normal.
    • Due to the absence of a uterus, affected individuals do not menstruate.
    • These individuals have a female chromosomal pattern (46 XX) and normal ovaries, due to which they develop female sexual characteristics, i.e. normal breast development and axillary and pubic hair growth.

Option D: Androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • Androgen insensitivity is a genotypic male with functional testes. Still, the androgen made by the testes is not recognised by the end organs; hence, they reach the periphery and convert to estrogens.
  • It leads to external feminisation.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented to the health care facility with a weblike neck, low-set-ear, broad chest, and high-arched palate. The clinician suspected her of having a chromosomal abnormality and referred her for karyotyping that showed that the patient has Turner syndrome with primary amenorrhea, having a karyotype of 45X0 and an infantile uterus on USG. What should be done next to manage such cases?
questions.solution:
Option A: HRT to induce puberty

45 XO = Turner syndrome (A most common form of gonadal dysgenesis)

  • The growth of the uterus depends on estrogens
  • In turner syndrome, there are streak ovaries, so less estrogen, which leads to an infantile uterus. So this leads to non-bleeding of the uterus and thus primary amenorrhea.
  • So, HRT is given to induce puberty.

Features of turner’s syndrome: -

  1. B/L streak gonads
  2. Webbing of neck
  3. Low posterior hairline
  4. Widely spaced nipple (as the breast is absent)
  5. Shield-shaped chest
  6. short 4th metacarpal
  7. Cubitus valgus
  8. CVS anomalies: M/c – Bicuspid aortic valves (coarctation of the aorta)
  9. Most common renal anomaly: - horseshoe-shaped kidney

Option B: Vaginoplasty

  • Vaginoplasty is a surgical procedure that is used to construct or repair a vagina and also to create a transgender vagina as well. However, it is of no value in patients with turner syndrome as vagina is normal

 

Option C: Clitoroplasty

  • Clitoroplasty is a surgical procedure that is performed on the clitoris, the small, visible part of female genitalia and is used to reduce the size of the genital tubercle and to give a feminine appearance without compromising future sexual function.

 

Option D: B/L gonadectomy

  • B/L gonadectomy is aprocedure for removing intraabdominal gonads in patients with complete androgen insensitivity syndrome, but it has no role in turner syndrome.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman seeks advice at the clinic regarding the use of Depo Medroxyprogesterone acetate. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: It may be associated with Irregular spotting

questions.solution:
Option A : Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate(DMPA) is given in microcrystalline aqueous suspension and is NOT FOR INTRAVENOUS USE.

Disadvantages:

  • Menstrual irregularities: amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhea, irregular spotting
  • No protection from STD and HIV.
  • Delay in return of fertility
  • Weight gain, bloating
  • Depression
  • Mastalgia
  • Osteopenia.
  • Increases LDL but does not adversely affect the blood pressure.
  • Decreases libido, causes dry vagina

DEPO-medroxyprogesterone acetate is contraindicated in women with:


Known or suspected pregnancy or as a diagnostic test for pregnancy
Undiagnosed vaginal and/or urinary tract bleeding
Known or suspected carcinoma of the breast
Undiagnosed breast pathology
Known or suspected progestin-dependent neoplasia
History of or actual thrombophlebitis or thromboembolic disorders
History of or actual cerebrovascular disorders including cerebral apoplexy
History of or actual myocardial infarction or coronary artery disease
Presence of severe or multiple risk factor(s) for arterial or venous thrombosis:
- Severe hypertension (persistent values of ≥160/100 mm Hg)
- Hereditary or acquired predisposition for venous or arterial thrombosis, such as Factor V
Leiden and Prothrombin G20210 A mutation,etc... the acquired thrombophilias
- Severe dyslipoproteinemia
- Heavy smoking (>15 cigarettes per day) and over age 35
- Diabetes mellitus with vascular involvement
Any ocular lesion arising from ophthalmic vascular disease, such as partial or complete loss of
vision or defect in visual fields
Current or history of migraine with focal aura
Active liver disease or history of or actual benign or malignant liver tumours
DEPO-PROVERA should not be used before menarche.

Option B, C : Use of DMPA is associated with menstrual irregularities: amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhea, irregular spotting.

Option D : Long term use of DMPA may lead to thromboembolism

questions.text: The occurrence of pregnancy is characterised by the persistence of the corpus luteum, which produces the most important pregnancy hormone, progesterone, till the placenta is formed and is fully functional. The placenta takes over the function of the corpus luteum for the production of the hormone at which of the following week?
questions.solution:
Option A: 8 weeks

  • The placenta starts making estrogen and progesterone after 6 weeks
  • The luteo-placental shift occurs from 6-9 weeks. This means that the placenta starts to take over the function of the corpus luteum for hormone production. By 8-9 weeks, most estrogen and progesterone in maternal circulation are from the placenta.
  • The function of the corpus luteum begins to decline after 8 wk of pregnancy, but it persists throughout pregnancy.

Corpus luteum:

  • The corpus luteum, a necessary but transient organ, is extremely important for fertility during the luteal phase.
  • When an ovarian follicle releases a mature ovum during ovulation, it releases an endocrine structure in the female ovary.
  • If the oocyte is not fertilised, the corpus luteum stops secreting hormones within 14 days following ovulation, and the resulting corpus albicans scar develops inside the ovary.
  • The corpus luteum's function is to keep the uterine environment favourable for conception and pregnancy.
  • Pregnancy-related hormones are released, and the hypothalamic-pituitary axis is controlled by blocking the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone from the hypothalamus, which reduces the levels of luteinising hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary.
  • Progesterone is the main hormone secreted by the corpus luteum. However, it also makes inhibin A and estradiol.
  • The corpus luteum will eventually regress in the absence of fertilisation.
  • Every time a woman ovulates, a corpus luteum grows, and throughout her lifetime, a woman will create a corpus luteum multiple times.

 

Option B: 12 weeks

  • The 12th week marks the end of the first trimester. Most of the hormones are now made by placenta, however the shift occurs at 8 weeks.

 

Option C: 18 weeks

  • The function of the corpus luteum is taken over by the placenta at the 8 weeks of gestation.
  • The limb movements are coordinated and can be detected.

 

Option D: 24 weeks

  • Hormones are made by placenta.
  • The chances of gestational diabetes are highest during the 24-28th week.

questions.text: An intern was asked to study a group of alcoholics to develop liver failure. Exposure to multiple outcomes can be studied in which of the following study?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option A: Cohort study

  • In a cohort study, multiple outcomes can be studied together.
  • Cohort study features are:
    • Forward-looking study
    • Prospective study
    • Cause to effect study
    • Risk factors to disease study
    • Exposure to outcome study (Hence the natural history of disease is best established).
    • Follow-up study
    • Incidence study

Other options

Option B: Case-control study

  • In a Case-control study, multiple exposures can be studied together.
  • A case-control study is a
    • Backward-looking study
    • Retrospective study
    • Effect to cause study
    • Disease to Risk factor study
    • Outcome to exposure study

Option C: Cross-sectional study

  • It is also known as the Snapshot study/ Prevalence study(as prevalence is calculated).
  • It is done at a point of time (neither forward, nor backward).
  • It is based on the primary data.
  • The strength of association cannot be calculated by the cross-sectional study.

Option D: Ecological study

  • The ecological study is done at a point of time.
  • Generally used for nutritional surveys.
    • E.g., The average fat intake of the adult population is 20gm/day in a city.
  • It can't calculate incidence, RR, OR, Strength of Association, or Prevalence.
  • The ecological study is based on secondary data (collected by someone else, and studied by the investigator).

questions.text: Emergency thoracotomy can be defined as thoracotomy "occurring either immediately at the site of injury, or in the emergency department or operating room as an integral part of the initial resuscitation process". Following emergency thoracotomy, the overall survival rates for penetrating thoracic trauma are around 9-12% but have been reported to be as high as 38%.Emergency thoracotomy is indicated following chest trauma in the following conditions except:-
questions.solution:
The correct answer is: A. Scapular and sternal fractures

Explanation for all the given options:

A. Scapular and sternal fractures: Emergency thoracotomy is not typically indicated for isolated scapular or sternal fractures. These fractures alone do not typically result in life-threatening conditions that would require immediate resuscitation through thoracotomy.

B. Esophageal perforation: Esophageal perforation can lead to mediastinitis, infection, and sepsis, which can be life-threatening. Emergency thoracotomy may be considered in cases of severe esophageal perforation with significant mediastinal contamination.

C. Penetrating injury with cardiac tamponade: Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening condition where fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart. Emergency thoracotomy may be necessary to relieve the pressure and treat the tamponade.

D. Massive Hemothorax: Massive hemothorax refers to significant blood accumulation in the pleural space, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and impaired oxygenation. Emergency thoracotomy might be required to control bleeding and address the hemothorax.

In summary, emergency thoracotomy is indicated in cases of severe trauma with life-threatening conditions such as cardiac tamponade, massive hemothorax, and esophageal perforation. Isolated scapular and sternal fractures are not typically indications for emergency thoracotomy.

questions.text: 100 individual are diagnosed with Lung cancer in a population of 100000. Out of 100 patients, 80 were smokers and 20000 were smokers in the total population. What is the population-attributable rate?
questions.solution:
Option B: 75

  • In the given question,
    • Total population: 100,000
    • Total exposed population (smokers) = 20000
    • Total non-exposed population (non-smokers) = 80000
    • Total incidence of lung cancer cases = 100/100000 = 0.001
    • Total incidence of Lung cancer among exposed = 80/20000
    • Total incidence of Lung cancer among non-exposed = 20/80000 = 0.00025
    • PAR = (Itotal - Inon-exp) / Itotal x 100 = (0.001-0.00025/0.001) x 100= 75

questions.text: In a population having mid-year population of 1000, there are 150 children less than 15 years and 50 elderly more than 65 years of age. Calculate dependency ratio?
questions.solution:
Option C: 0.25

Dependency ratio:

  • Also known as " societal dependency ratio".
  • The proportion of persons above 65 of age and children below 15 years of age are considered to be dependent on the economically productive age group (15-64 years).

Dependency ratio = (Proportion of ppl in < 15yrs of age + > 65yrs of age) / Proportion of ppl in 15-64 yrs of age

= 150+50/800

= 0.25

Learning Objective

  • Dependency ratio defined as the proportion of persons above 65 of age and children below 15 years of age are considered to be dependent on the economically productive age group (15-64 years).

questions.text: For assembling cohorts for a cohort study, all of the following considerations are taken into account, except?

choices.text: Attributable risk is of epidemiologist use
Relative risk is of epidemiologist use

questions.solution:
Answer

Option D: Relative risk is of epidemiologist use

  • Relative risk is of clinician use
  • Attributable risk is of epidemiologist use
  • Population-attributable risk is of Program manager use.

Other options

Option A: Forward-Looking study

  • This statement is correct

Option B: It is prospective

  • This statement is correct

Option C: Attributable risk is of epidemiologist use

  • This is a correct statement

questions.text: A microbiologist is preparing a vaccine in the laboratory for Mumps disease. Which of the following strain is used in the Mumps vaccine?
questions.solution:
Option A: Jeryl-Lynn

  • Jeryl-Lynn strain is used for the preparation of the mumps vaccine.
  • The various strains used for Mumps include Jeryl-Lynn, RIT-4385, Leningrad-3, L-Zagreb, and Urabe strains.

Option B: Edmonston Zagreb

  • Edmonston Zagreb strain is used for the measles vaccine.

Option C: RA 27/3

  • RA 27/3 strain is used for the Rubella vaccine.

Option D: Oka

  • Oka strain is used for the varicella-zoster virus vaccine.

questions.text: A rural PHC is giving vaccination to village children's every Saturday of the week. Vitamin A should be started for which of the following age?
questions.solution:
Option B: 9 months

  • According to NIS Vit A (1 lakh IU orally) should be started at the age of 9 months & from then, should be given every 6 months (2 lakh IU orally) till 5yrs of age.
  • Hence, a total of 9 doses of Vit A are given; i.e 17 lakh IU.

questions.text: A microbiology intern is preparing vaccines in the laboratory. On morning rounds, he was asked to explain about the hepatitis B vaccine by his senior. All of the following are true about the Hepatitis B vaccine except?

choices.text: Made by inserting the segment of the hepatitis B virus gene into an avirulent virus
Hepatitis B Vaccine is identical to natural hepatitis B surface antigen but does not contain virus DNA
Vaccine should be given at the Anterolateral side of left mid-thigh

questions.solution:
Option B: Polysaccharide-based vaccine

  • Hepatitis B is a recombinant protein vaccine, not a polysaccharide-based vaccine.
  • Other recombinant protein Vaccines – Anti-HPV vaccine, Lyme disease vaccine, Cholera toxin B vaccine.
  • Following are examples of Polysaccharide based vaccines:
    • Typhim-Vi
    • Pneumococcal vaccine
    • Meningococcal vaccine
    • Hib vaccine

Other options

Option A: Made by inserting the segment of the hepatitis B virus gene into an avirulent virus

  • Recombinant protein vaccines are recombinant DNA products created by genetic engineering, in which the virus's component (antigen) is introduced into the genome of an unaggressive virus.

Option C: Hepatitis B Vaccine is identical to natural hepatitis B surface antigen but does not contain virus DNA

  • Hepatitis B Vaccine is identical to natural hepatitis B surface antigen, but does not contain virus DNA is a true statement.

Option D: Vaccine should be given at the Anterolateral side of left mid-thigh

  • Instead of the buttock, the deltoid muscle in the upper arm or the anterolateral part of the thigh should receive the hepatitis B vaccination.

questions.text: A 59 year old female presented to the hospital with lump in her breast. On physical examination there was presence of dimpling sign. The probable diagnosis of breast cancer was made by the physician. Which of the following is not a screening test for breast cancer in India?
questions.solution:
FNAC is not a Screening test for breast cancer in India. Its maainly used as a preliminary test for Diagnosis.

SCREENING TESTS FOR BREAST CANCER IN INDIA :

  • Mammography :

Is ‘ Most sensitive and specific screening test’.

Is not indicated for age <35 years.

Is associated with 10 times radiation exposure as compared to a routine chest X ray.

  • Thermography:

Is a less sensitive screening test.

Dose not expose patient to radiation .

  • Breast self examination (BSE):

Is least sensitive and specific screening test.

Most commonlyrecommended for young individuals.

  • Palpation by physician:

Is unreliable for large breasts.

  • MRI

Ideal screening test in young individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following year is known as year of “big divide” in the history of demography of India.
questions.solution:
• The year 1921 is called the "big divide" because the absolute number of people added to the population during each decade has been increasing since 1921.
  • Only in year 1921 census, we observed decline in population.

EXTRA EDGE :-

  • First census is taken in 1871 [15 till now].
  • Census stop on 1st March at 0.00 hrs.
  • First Disability census - 1881.

questions.text: A 26 year old female visited to the OPD for taking OCPs. Which of the following is the condition in which OCPs are absolutely contraindicated?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is: B. Active liver disease

Explanation for all the given options:

A. Smoking > 10 cigarettes a day: While smoking increases the risk of cardiovascular events in women using oral contraceptive pills (OCPs), it is considered a relative contraindication rather than an absolute contraindication. It's important to carefully assess the risks and benefits for women who smoke and desire to use OCPs.

B. Active liver disease: OCPs are absolutely contraindicated in individuals with active liver disease, as they can exacerbate liver dysfunction and increase the risk of complications.

C. Diabetes mellitus: Diabetes mellitus is not an absolute contraindication for OCP use. However, careful consideration is required, especially in women with poorly controlled diabetes, as OCPs can affect glucose metabolism.

D. Mild hypertension: Mild hypertension is not an absolute contraindication for OCP use. However, blood pressure should be well-controlled before initiating OCPs, and ongoing monitoring is essential.

In summary, OCPs are absolutely contraindicated in individuals with active liver disease due to the potential for exacerbation of liver dysfunction and complications.

questions.text: A 25 year old working mother recently delivered a heathy baby in the hospital. This morning she visited the physician with concern of breastfeeding her baby as she wants to resume her work. How long can Breast milk be stored in the refrigerator (without spoiling)?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is: C. 24 hours

Here's an explanation for all the given options:

A. 8 hours: Breast milk can be stored in the refrigerator for longer than 8 hours. This option is incorrect.

B. 4 days: While breast milk can be stored in the refrigerator for a certain period, it is typically recommended to use or freeze the milk within 4 days to ensure its freshness and nutritional quality. However, this option is not the most accurate answer in terms of the maximum recommended storage duration.

C. 24 hours: Breast milk can generally be safely stored in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours. This is the correct answer. It's important to keep breast milk in the coldest part of the refrigerator (at around 32-39°F or 0-4°C) to maintain its quality. If the mother wants to store the milk for a longer duration, she should consider freezing it rather than keeping it in the refrigerator.

D. 10 days: Storing breast milk in the refrigerator for 10 days is beyond the recommended safe storage period. While breast milk can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 24 hours, if the mother needs to store it for a longer duration, it's advisable to freeze it. Frozen breast milk can be stored for several months in a regular freezer (around 0°F or -18°C) or up to a year in a deep freezer (around -4°F or -20°C).

In summary, the correct answer is C. 24 hours, as breast milk can be safely stored in the refrigerator for up to this duration. If the mother needs to store milk for a longer period, freezing is a better option. It's important to always follow proper guidelines for breast milk storage to ensure the health and safety of the baby.

questions.text: A 32-year-old vegetarian male presented to the OPD with pale skin, fatigue, and numbness. On examination, he was having vitamin deficiency for which only animal sources had to be consumed. Which of the following vitamins is deficient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Vitamin B12

  • A vegetarian male with pallor, fatigue, and numbness suggests the patient is having anemia with peripheral neuropathy, which is most likely due to B12 deficiency.
  • Vitamin B12/Cyanocobalamin is only obtainable through animal sources, therefore strict vegetarians develop B12 deficiency.

Option A: Vitamin B1

  • Since B12 only obtain through animal sources this patient is more likely to have B12 deficiency.
  • Thiamine deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy but anemia would be uncommon.
  • Given Strict vegetarian, B12 is the more likely answer.

Option B: Vitamin B2

  • Vitamin B2 deficiency can lead to angular stomatitis, cheilosis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis.

Option D: Vitamin C

  • Vitamin C deficiency is also known as "scurvy" present with bleeding gums, petechiae, poor wound healing, and corkscrew hair.

questions.text: The family life cycles a series of stages through which a family may pass over time. Arrange the following stages of family cycle in chronological sequence?

choices.text: Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Dissolution, Contraction, Complete contraction
Formation, Extension, Contraction, Complete extension, Complete contraction, Dissolution
Formation, Contraction, Complete contraction, Extension, Complete extension, Dissolution
Formation, Extension, Complete extension, Contraction, Complete contraction, Dissolution

questions.solution:
A normal family cycle is conceived as having 6 phases in the following chronological order:

Description Beginning of phase End of phase
I Formation Marriage Birth of 1st child
II Extension Birth of 1st child Birth of last child
III Complete extension Birth of last child 1st child leaves home
IV Contraction 1st child leaves home Last child leaves home
V Completed contraction Last child leaves home 1st spouse dies
VI Dissolution 1st spouse dies Death of survivor (extinction)

questions.text: In a well-educated family, all its family members are working and help each other financially. A family where all of its members are playing a part in its management is known as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option D: Communal family

  • A communal family is a family where all of its members are playing a defined part in its management.
  • It is a good example of the ‘division of labor’ an important function of the family.

Option A: Problem  family

  • It is a family which lags behind the rest of the community.
  • The underlying factors in most problem families are those of personality, relationships, backwardness, poverty, illness,
  • mental and social instability, character defects, and marital disharmony.
  •  The standards of life are generally far below the accepted minimum.
  •  The parents are unable to meet the physical and emotional needs of their children.
  •  Home life is utterly unsatisfactory.

Option B: New family 

  • Family with marriage duration < 10yrs.

Option C: 3 Generation family

  • Household with members of 3 successive generations.
  • Type of joint family & males are related by blood.

questions.text: A PSM intern was studying demographic processes. Which of the following correctly defines Movements at a socioeconomic level in society?
questions.solution:
Option C: Social mobility

  • Movements in the socioeconomic level of society are called social mobility.
  • It is one of the demographic processes.

Option A: Social equality

  • Social equality is a state where people are treated fairly and given equal chances without any discrimination.
  • Therefore, this is an incorrect choice.

Option B: Socio-Economic upliftment 

  • Socio-economic upliftment is the process of the socio-economic development of society.

Option D: Scarce resources

  • Movements in the socioeconomic level of society are called social mobility.
  • Scarce resources include money and material.
